Subject: [sfraves] WR1: Thursday night/ Friday Morning Adventure!

4PM: Caught the WESTcat 2 go 2 the HTC 2 Catch the bus 2 go 2 BART...

5:30PM: Waiting aboveground 4 Joey who i never met, but Fat Ass Brian from New Orleans wants me 2 show him a good time in Bay Area night life!  Finally showed up @ 6 something & we eat @ Subway...

7PM:  After walking down 1st Street tryin' 2 hail a cab, we finally got a cab & headed over 2 Sublounge... the Cabby was a nice Dude... grrrrr... Giants Game crowd 'caused some traffic & I was late 2 meet up w/ Jonas!

8PM: had a few drinks, like 2 I think, & like totally Groove 2 the upstairs sets... Jonas spun alota deep house, Lost spun alota ummm... Prog house was it?  Then we went down stairs to sett up... Jonas hooks up the MIC & I talk a lil' bit on it, Mic check & so forth... Lost hops on the decks again & spins trance.. it was fun!  Calamity Jane enters the basement & struts her way down 2 the DJ booth... slowly... more & more Family are in Sublounge!  Joey felt kinda like overwhelmed that he met alota people already...LoL:

"Dude," I said, "this is sooooo just the beginning Homie!  there's still more people you're gonna meet 2night!"

"Oh MY," Joey said!  LoL

9PM: Shelly spun this Awesome set upstairs containing Hip Hop, & some down tempo.. Loved it!!  The next DJ after that was strait up spinning Hip Hop!!  Downstairs there was alota house Music goin' on!!  Ms Jane broke it down & started spinning yummy breakbeats!!  Loved it!!  Hella Danicng my ass off the whole time while tryin 2 B social w/ every1 there!!  The Upstairs was getting full!  Met hella Groovy people...

10:30PM:  Got a ride w/ Heidi 2 Anu... me & Joey rode w/ Shoe in Lost in the car also... LoL... That musta been 1 of the funnest car rides I had in a loooong time!!  I heard "The detachable Penis" song 4 the 1st time & we ended up asking people in other cars outta window if they saw our detachable penises... Lol  Hello 2Day.. LoL

11:30PM:  Been hangin' out w/ Shazbot, Melissa, their friends, Seraphim, & the Anu bar hoppers... Serephim dedicated an electro clash tune in her set 2 me... "I wanna be a cowboy" & we were hopping up & down on the dancefloor like gleeful tourists from Japan or soemthing... it was fun!!  

Then Shazbot hit the decks... ok.. all I gotta say is GOOD FUCKIN SHIT!!!  I've always Loved Shaz & his house sets, but fuuuuuuuuuuckin' A man... hello 2day.. I think this set beats out all the other sets I've ever heard him spin!!!  I mean... OK... he totally spun like these Awesome electro clash tunes like in the begining of his set, then went in2 house which I was expecting anyway 'cause he is a house DJ, but OK... this kinda house he was spinning was all like bleepy Bloppy House w/ like these weird alien sounds.. I Loved it!!!  Minimal House??  Minimanl Techno??? I dunno, but it was fun!!  Me, Calamity J, & Origami were bein; total dance floor hogs & it was fun!  Oh yeah it was fun!

Joey is good @ socializing w/ people! YAY... I'm hangin' out w/ another social butterfly!! How Dope!

12AM: We walk over 2 Cloud 9... and saw Mal & Sharp... LoL.. I talk 2 Sharp about a funny story that Seraphim told me early & he just looked @ me eyes mondo wide open, nodding his head, & laughing @ the same time..LMAO... Hello 2day... Mal tells the bouncers that me & guest are on GL so we go in...

OK... so unfortunately, the Jungle that Joey was yearning 4 didn't happen that night... there was a previous event planned there & the music was all Top 40 stuff upstairs & house downstairs... but like Mal totally broke it down & spun Breakbeats that oh yeah... but I dunno... the crowd was like totally yucky, the vibe was totally plastic 23 say the least, & altough I Love & support Mal, it didn't really feel right bein' there... so we left after like an hour I think...

1AM: We're over @ End Up... Oh My Goodness... 1 of the best fuckn' bouncers in the Bay Area.. Rudy.. who I haven't seeeeeeeen in a loooooong time was bouncing @ the door & we spent like 10 minutes catching up!  LoL... he even like got me in on his GL so we could pay a 2 for 1 @ the door 2 go in... LoL

The End up was fun.. I mean... it was all like deep house while we were there, but what was funny was they hella stepped it up during the last set & things got like hella bassy, progresive, disco-ie, & fun!

We met alota Groovy people there.. Oh MY goodness man... I finally saw Charlette (the baroness) after heeeeeeeella fuckin' years & we talked & talked & talked & talked... I'm very proud of her DJ career now... but it was fun catchin' up w/ her...

3AM:  We end up leaving the end up 'cause we're both kinda beat from all the frolicing around the City.. but it was such a bad ass time!  We endup walking back up 2 market & up some in the TL 2 go 2 his pad & decided 2 take a cab 2 his place 'cause it was confussing a lil'...  LoL... our cab driver thanks us 4 bein' his 1st passengers ever 'cause he just started workin' that night! LoL

5:30AM: I'm on my way back home on BART listening 2 my walkman & scare people... LoL

7:30AM: HOme Finally... =)

OK.. so that was my adventure... LoL...



Take Care,
Peace-> O§bY {8O)

SUNDAY, May 30th, at Club 6

Breakthru presents:

AQUASKY vs.
MASTERBLASTER

Regarded as the toughest breaks act in the world Breakthru is pround to 
present their first west coast apperance of Aquasky vs. Masterblaster. The 
tracks produced on their imprint Passenger have been causing major damage 
on dancefloors for several years.

Breakbeat Room:
Aquasky vs. Masterblaster
A:Dubl w/ MC Duh [Breakthru/Groundscore]
Method One [Co-vert Ops]
Clockwork [Breakthru, Power Kingdom]
Frogger Laptop Set [Breakthru]

Hip-Hop/Dancehall Room:
Paul Nice [Bomb Recs, DITC, Power Kingdom, NYC]
Snayk Eyez [DMC 00 & 01, Scratch the Movie]
Wisdom [Beat Sauce, Power Kingdom]
Owl Boogie [Action Figures]

PRICE:
$10 b4 12a,
$15 after
TIME: 10pm-4am
MUSIC: Breakbeats and Hip-Hop
MORE INFO:
<http://www.breakthrusf.net>breakthrusf.net



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: [sfraves] WR2: Friday Night:, SubHotel was Hella Fun!

So Friday night was comin' up... I took a loooooong sleep & like woke up around 7:30 PM well.. i kept wakingup & falling asleep... but finally got up @ 7:30.. LoL

Anywaze, I called Jaze 2 C if we were still goin' 2 SubHotel 'cause man.. i miss my Jaze, so we had 2 hang out! YAY!!

So we do all the things 2 get 2 the party, map point, another check point, field trip w/ other ravers 2 the spot, & damn.. hella fun & interestring choise of a venue... LoL... Loved it!!  Oh the Mystery involved!

When we got there.. i 4got who it was on the decks spinning trance, but it was Groovy!  Danced a lil' bit, talked 2 Dfly 4 a good bit... LoL.. I was her gaurd dog whenever hse welll.. she used the bathroom once that i gaurded the door 4 her... LoL... yeah...

Oh yeah... it was Dope seein' her & Terri @ Sublounge the night b4.... YAY!

Anywaze.. Dfly goes on next.. OK... Hello 2day.. I Loved this set alot!!  She spun alota Dark EVIL trance & ya know... I seriously thought i heard some Techno tracks in there in some places!!!  OK.. but what totally tipped me off was when oh my gosh,, Hello 2day... she fuckn' dropped Hybrid is her set & I was ooooooh my goodness.. yeah!

T Kent went on next.. OK... WOW.. I LOved this set aloooooooooot! I mean.. Homeboy was on the trance tip also.. but good shit man... he dropped fuckin'; Techno is his set & spun 2 of my all time Fave techno songs.. Loveed it soooo much!!!  2 Bad alota kids @ the party don't get techno though... hmmmmm

OK... decorations were totally minimal, but nice... a few matresses in there 4 people 2 chill on...  a few lighty thingies here & there... it was fun!

OK... party people in attendance was Groovy!!  It was a really energetic, fun vibe... there was no bad energy i felt @ all... oh yeah.. & my psychic flashes haven't been 2 strong lately, so I didn't have any paranoya about bein' @ this party @ all as opposed 2 the last party Modified threw (Mr. Kent... we talked about this, OK? =)  LoL  I mean.. it was soooooo funny 'cause like as soon as i got down the stairway.. I swear man.. I heard my name called from like 15 different directions.. it was Awsesome seein' every1 who was there!!  YAY... me & Tigz hung out again!!

Thank U Modified 4 the Groovy party!!  Loved it sooooooo much!  YAY!! Ya know... OI was thinkin' @ the party that Wow... I'm partying w/ the next generation of underground kids... How Dope!  YO Mr. Kent & Mr Element.. U guys fuckin' Rock man!! Can't wait 2 party w/ y'all again soon! weeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee :P

Take Care...
Peace=->O§bY {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Shazbot @ BAD KITTY Thursday


Thanks Jonas and Shazbot for your support! You guys are funny :)

How did the event at Sublounge turnout?

Unfortunately due to an unexpected job interview (which totally sucked
ass) I couldn't make it out. I did make it back in time for Bad Kitty
though, and Shazbot rocked the house Bad Kitty stylee!

Thanks to all who have been supporting Bad Kitty in crack central -
We've had great success and great times so far, and are going to keep
the nasty electro.punk.disco.booty.trash coming...
Thursdays have definitely been going off lately, should be a great
Summer!

Next week Queen Agnes B is gracing us with her royalty, as well as a
few other filthy suprises... its all BAD.

Meow,
Snares




Forwarded Message
Date:	Wed, 26 May 2004 11:17:46 -0700
From:	"shawn allen" <shawn@alterior.net>
To:	"sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject:	BSP: Shazbot @ BAD KITTY Thursday



Plain Text Attachment [ Download File  |  Save to my Yahoo! Briefcase ]

I know, I know... there's this lovey-dovey benefit going down at the
Sublounge with a ton of well-known DJs and the entire rave scene 
hipster
collective is going to be there.

But if you want to hear something new and *different*, something a bit
naughty and dirty, or if you're just a broke-ass mofo that can't swing
the cab fare, come down to Anu Thursday night for BAD KITTY. I'll be on
'round 11:30 bringing a dastardly mix of nasty minimal techno, acid
house, some electro("clash"), and all sorts of weird stuff.

So here's your choice:

Party with a bunch of patchouli-scented ravers to music that you can
hear any other night of the week, way out in China Basin...

OR:

Rock out with your cock out to some funky shit you ain't never heard
before, and have a nice conversation with a Mission crackhead on your
way out.

I trust you'll make the right decision.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

> Party with a bunch of patchouli-scented ravers to music that you can
> hear any other night of the week, way out in China Basin...
>
> OR:
>
> Rock out with your cock out to some funky shit you ain't never heard
> before, and have a nice conversation with a Mission crackhead on your
> way out.
>
> I trust you'll make the right decision.
>
> Cheers,
> --
> shawn allen
>   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
>   phone://+1.415.577.3961
>   http://alterior.net
>   aim://shawnpallen
>

Been having email conversations with David lately.  Anyhow, what's "old" is

David Mancuso's Disco Wonderland
King of Clubs
by Tim Lawrence
May 28th, 2004 4:00 PM

The party space, with its huge mirror ball and DNA strands of multicolored 
balloons, combines Alice in Wonderland with astrophysics. "City, Country, 
City" percolates through five stacks of Klipschorn speakers and sounds so 
live that, if you close your eyes, War could be playing in the same room. 
As the percussive tempo builds, dancers regress, screaming and whooping as 
they execute spinning-top turns and syncopated jazz flicks. It could be 
1974, but it's 2004. After an agonizing hiatus, the Loft is back. And party 
host David Mancuso is refusing to change with the times.

The Loft began life in 1970 as an unnamed, one-off rent party when Mancuso, 
an antiques dealer, decided to put on a Valentine's Day bash in his 
ex-industrial home to supplement his irregular income. In a reference to 
universal love and psychedelic enlightenment, the party invites were 
inscribed with the words "Love Saves the Day," and Mancuso ended up 
spinning records from midnight until six in the morning. "The idea of being 
a DJ never crossed my mind," he says. "I only did it because I was with my 
friends and we were all into the same music."

At the end of that first night, Mancuso's guests­a definitive cross-section 
of New York's displaced citizens­made it clear that they wanted more of the 
same, and within a couple of months the host had succumbed to the 
inevitability of a weekly party. By the middle of 1971, the events were 
being referred to as the Loft. "I wasn't looking for a name," says Mancuso. 
"But people started to refer to my space as David's Loft. It was a given 
name and I accepted it."

Mancuso's subsequent influence on the dance underground is hard to 
overestimate. The Tenth Floor, the Gallery, 12 West, Reade Street, the 
Warehouse, and the Paradise Garage were modeled on his private-party 
template. Club kids such as Nicky Siano, Larry Levan, Frankie Knuckles, 
Tony Humphries, and David Morales fell under his aural spell before they 
proceeded to embark on their own turntablist adventures. Even fellow DJs 
treated Mancuso's venue like a place of worship.

Mancuso broke unconventional records like "Girl You Need a Change of Mind" 
and "Soul Makossa," yet he was always more of a party engineer than a DJ. 
He put together the best sound system in New York, spending hundreds of 
thousands of dollars on audiophile technology. He treated his dancers to a 
sumptuous buffet of energy-enhancing food and fruit punch. He decorated his 
post-industrial living spaces in the style of a make-believe children's 
party. And he defended his house party setup as if his life depended on it, 
defeating the Department of Consumer Affairs in a precedent-setting battle 
over his right to party without a cabaret license.

The party host also demonstrated a sixth sense for pioneering new 
neighborhoods in which to throw a party. Noho had yet to receive its 
designation when Mancuso moved into 647 Broadway in the mid '60s, and when 
the collapse of a neighboring hotel forced him to look for a new space in 
the summer of 1974, he moved to 99 Prince Street, overcoming the vociferous 
objections of once bohemian locals en route. "Soho vs. Disco" is how Vince 
Aletti, writing in the Voice, framed the clash. Disco won.

Mancuso's next move was calamitous. As his 10-year lease on Prince Street 
drew to a close, he decided to swap the cobbled climes of Soho for the 
virtual war zone of Alphabet City, hopeful that outright ownership of his 
new building on 3rd Street between avenues B and C would help him "leave 
the landlords behind" and ensure the future of his beloved party. Die-hard 
devotees­especially Loft women­balked at the area's notoriously heavy drug 
traffic and endemic crime, however, and even Mancuso became edgy when 
federal and city plans to rejuvenate the area evaporated. "I lost 65 
percent of my attendance overnight," he remembers.

Mancuso struggled in his 3rd Street venue until he was forced to close in 
1994. The itinerant host then tried his luck on Avenue A, followed by 
Avenue B, where a shimmering 28th-anniversary celebration contained the 
promise of rebirth until a fractious landlord forced him into yet another 
move­this time into rented accommodations that were too tiny to hold a 
house party.

The onset of AIDS, the inexorable rise of the drum machine, and the hostile 
tenure of Mayor Giuliani contributed to the impression that Mancuso had 
fallen out of sync with history. But then David Hill, co-owner of 
London-based Nuphonic Records, offered to release a compilation of Loft 
classics, and Mancuso, who needed the money and was impressed by Hill's 
perfectionist drive, agreed. The album, David Mancuso Presents the Loft, 
became Nuphonic's bestseller and triggered a wave of publicity for the club.

As Mancuso's legendary status came into focus, invitations to play in 
Japan, the U.K., Italy, and France poured in. On each trip, the roving 
"musical host" (Mancuso's preferred description) broke with conventional 
DJ'ing practice by agreeing to work with just one promoter and play just 
one party per city. "Most DJs walk into a gig and do a one- to three-hour 
slot, and that is it," he says. "To me that is a fart in a windstorm. I 
like to help build a party from scratch and create a musical direction."

Mancuso recently started to put on parties in what has oddly­given its 
history as the international capital of disco­become the toughest terrain 
of all: New York. Hiring out a hall near St. Marks Place, he has been 
attracting the young (mainly Japanese kids) as well as the old (veterans of 
the Broadway Loft). His 34th-anniversary party in February was a sellout, 
and last weekend's Memorial Day party was equally successful.

Loft babies believe that Mancuso is once again putting on the best party in 
the city. "The best dancing experiences I have ever had have been at the 
Loft," says DJ-producer Nicky Siano, who, having drifted away from the New 
York dance scene in the early 1980s, has made a fairly astonishing comeback 
himself. "The atmosphere at David's parties is second to none."

For some, the Loft has begun to show its age. "I admire David's active 
avoidance of the spotlight, and his parties still have an underground feel 
because of that," says a comparatively young DJ. "But the majority of the 
crowd is the same as it was 20 years ago, and they want to hear the old 
favorites." Others wonder if Mancuso's refusal to use a mixer is 
anachronistic­and if it would be possible for him to pump the sound system 
just a little bit harder.

But if so many new records don't measure up to the old, if mixing 
technology encourages spinners to focus on the micro-detail of how two 
records blend together rather than the broader canvas of the dancefloor 
journey, and if clubbers are suffering from unprecedented levels of 
tinnitus as a result of repeated ear beatings from second-rate sound 
systems, what is Mancuso to do?

The Loft host's obsessive pursuit of the perfect party has emerged as a 
precious antidote to the increasingly stagnant status quo. "The Loft is 
unique and irresistible," says veteran DJ-dancer Danny Krivit, whose 718 
Sessions are one of the hottest parties in the city at the moment. "It's 
about good friends meeting in a homey setting and listening to excellent 
music on a great sound system. The Loft is timeless." Mancuso has become 
not so much an idiosyncratic dinosaur as a prophet from the past who is 
pointing to a new-old future. Just by standing still.





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Another incredible mix by RV Aggelen. He is one of Cobalts upcoming fast 
rising stars. He has releases on catologs 01, and 02 on Cobalt Recordings. Soon to 
have another coming out in september as a joint release with Bash Records out 
of Berlin Germany and on Cobalt's third Release. This mix contains all 
original tracks produced by RV Aggelen. His skills are shown in this mix that will 
take you on a journey. RV Aggelen is now accepting dates world wide for booking 
information e-mail monk7923@aol.com. www.cobaltrecordings.net

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: A local punk compilation, from a local punk label...

Hey everyone out there in SFR land! 

Wow, it has been a damn long time since I posted on here, but I promise
I still lurk... Anyway, I know this isn't technically rave-related, but
I know a lot of you are fans of the punk-rock stuff. Sooo I thought I'd
take this opportunity to let you know about a local indie label (started
by two local DJs) called Agent Records, who have a new compilation CD
coming out this year. Last years' edition of this CD was really popular
(got air-play on Live105, and tons of college radio stations), and this
one is even better, plus it's super cheap (5 bucks). It's twenty-four
up-and-coming Northern California bands, seventy-four minutes of music,
and more rock than you can shake a formidably sized stick at.

Check it out here: http://www.agentrecords.com/ar03002.html for music
samples, ordering info, and naked pictures of Osby ;)

-Aaron

>>manage their party. Amateurs.

>
>Precisely why I got on the kid's ass about no cellphones. Causes more
>problems and solves nothing. Especially when you figure that most people
>will hear about the party as word of mouth and never see a BSP stating that
>they can't have a cellphone. All of a sudden you have people showing up at
>the party that are finding out they can't have their cellphone with them.
>That's going to cause drama at the door. Drama is going to mean more
>attention drawn to the party. Pissing people off that are coming to your
>party potentially results in a vengeful call to the police and the end of
>your event.
>
>If I wanted to be hardcore about people not calling friends it would be
>easy. Shuttle people in a van with blacked out windows. Drive a route that
>is longer, has more turns than needed, but thoroughly confuses the
>passengers. When they arrive, and if it's a place that no one has been to,
>most likely they won't have a clue as to where they are and thus calling
>friends does them no good.
>
>The fact is that there is no real solid answer to the problem of people
>revealing a party location. Well, there is one. You only invite people that
>you know are mindful of the type of event they're going to. From what it
>sounds like this event caters to a bunch of people that have no clue how to
>act in a renegade//ug environment. This is why selective promoting is great
>and part of that includes not posting to SFR, F8, BayRaves, DJ-D list,
>etc... =)
>

innocentchild wrote:

>>That just bullshit because they can't think of another way to
>>manage their party. Amateurs.
>> 
>>
>
>Precisely why I got on the kid's ass about no cellphones. Causes more
>problems and solves nothing. Especially when you figure that most people
>will hear about the party as word of mouth and never see a BSP stating that
>they can't have a cellphone. All of a sudden you have people showing up at
>the party that are finding out they can't have their cellphone with them.
>That's going to cause drama at the door. Drama is going to mean more
>attention drawn to the party. Pissing people off that are coming to your
>party potentially results in a vengeful call to the police and the end of
>your event.
>
>If I wanted to be hardcore about people not calling friends it would be
>easy. Shuttle people in a van with blacked out windows. Drive a route that
>is longer, has more turns than needed, but thoroughly confuses the
>passengers. When they arrive, and if it's a place that no one has been to,
>most likely they won't have a clue as to where they are and thus calling
>friends does them no good.
>
>The fact is that there is no real solid answer to the problem of people
>revealing a party location. Well, there is one. You only invite people that
>you know are mindful of the type of event they're going to. From what it
>sounds like this event caters to a bunch of people that have no clue how to
>act in a renegade//ug environment. This is why selective promoting is great
>and part of that includes not posting to SFR, F8, BayRaves, DJ-D list,
>etc... =)
>
>:: r ::

>I know a lot of you are fans of the punk-rock stuff. Sooo I thought I'd
>take this opportunity to let you know about a local indie label (started
>by two local DJs) called Agent Records, who have a new compilation CD
>coming out this year. Last years' edition of this CD was really popular
>(got air-play on Live105, and tons of college radio stations), and this
>one is even better, plus it's super cheap (5 bucks). It's twenty-four
>up-and-coming Northern California bands, seventy-four minutes of music,
>and more rock than you can shake a formidably sized stick at.

Subject: [sfraves] How Copyright Law Changed Hip Hop

--=====================_2946226==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit


How Copyright Law Changed Hip Hop

By Kembrew McLeod, <http://www.stayfreemagazine.org>Stay Free! Magazine
June 1, 2004

When Public Enemy released It Takes a Nation of Millions to Hold Us Back in 
1988, it was as if the album had landed from another planet. Nothing 
sounded like it at the time. It Takes a Nation came frontloaded with 
sirens, squeals, and squawks that augmented the chaotic, collaged backing 
tracks over which P.E. frontman Chuck D laid his politically and poetically 
radical rhymes. He rapped about white supremacy, capitalism, the music 
industry, black nationalism, and – in the case of "Caught, Can I Get a 
Witness?" – digital sampling: "CAUGHT, NOW IN COURT ' CAUSE I STOLE A BEAT 
/ THIS IS A SAMPLING SPORT / MAIL FROM THE COURTS AND JAIL / CLAIMS I STOLE 
THE BEATS THAT I RAIL ... I FOUND THIS MINERAL THAT I CALL A BEAT / I PAID 
ZERO."

In the mid- to late 1980s, hip-hop artists had a very small window of 
opportunity to run wild with the newly emerging sampling technologies 
before the record labels and lawyers started paying attention. No one took 
advantage of these technologies more effectively than Public Enemy, who put 
hundreds of sampled aural fragments into It Takes a Nation and stirred them 
up to create a new, radical sound that changed the way we hear music. But 
by 1991, no one paid zero for the records they sampled without getting 
sued. They had to pay a lot. The following is a combination of two 
interviews conducted separately with Chuck D and Hank Shocklee.

Stay Free!: What are the origins of sampling in hip-hop?

Chuck D: Sampling basically comes from the fact that rap music is not 
music. It's rap over music. So vocals were used over records in the very 
beginning stages of hip-hop. In the late 1980s, rappers were recording over 
live bands who were basically emulating the sounds off of the records. 
Eventually, you had synthesizers and samplers, which would take sounds that 
would then get arranged or looped, so rappers can still do their thing over 
it. The arrangement of sounds taken from recordings came around 1984 to 1989.

Stay Free!: Those synthesizers and samplers were expensive back then, 
especially in 1984. How did hip-hop artists get them if they didn't have a 
lot of money?

Chuck D: Not only were they expensive, but they were limited in what they 
could do – they could only sample two seconds at a time. But people were 
able to get a hold of equipment by renting time out in studios.

Stay Free!: How did the Bomb Squad [Public Enemy's production team, led by 
Shocklee] use samplers and other recording technologies to put together the 
tracks on It Takes a Nation of Millions.

Hank Shocklee:The first thing we would do is the beat, the skeleton of the 
track. The beat would actually have bits and pieces of samples already in 
it, but it would only be rhythm sections. Chuck would start writing and 
trying different ideas to see what worked. Once he got an idea, we would 
look at it and see where the track was going. Then we would just start 
adding on whatever it needed, depending on the lyrics. I kind of 
architected the whole idea. The sound has a look to me, and Public Enemy 
was all about having a sound that had its own distinct vision. We didn't 
want to use anything we considered traditional R&B stuff – bass lines and 
melodies and chord structures and things of that nature.?

Stay Free!: How did you use samplers as instruments?

Chuck D: We thought sampling was just another way of arranging sounds. Just 
like a musician would take the sounds off of an instrument and arrange them 
their own particular way. So we thought we was quite crafty with it.

Shocklee: "Don't Believe the Hype," for example – that was basically played 
with the turntable and transformed and then sampled. Some of the 
manipulation we was doing was more on the turntable, live end of it.

Stay Free!: When you were sampling from many different sources during the 
making of It Takes a Nation, were you at all worried about copyright 
clearance?

Shocklee: No. Nobody did. At the time, it wasn't even an issue. The only 
time copyright was an issue was if you actually took the entire rhythm of a 
song, as in looping, which a lot of people are doing today. You're going to 
take a track, loop the entire thing, and then that becomes the basic track 
for the song. They just paperclip a backbeat to it. But we were taking a 
horn hit here, a guitar riff there, we might take a little speech, a 
kicking snare from somewhere else. It was all bits and pieces.

Stay Free!: Did you have to license the samples in It Takes a Nation of 
Millions before it was released?

Shocklee: No, it was cleared afterwards. A lot of stuff was cleared 
afterwards. Back in the day, things was different. The copyright laws 
didn't really extend into sampling until the hip-hop artists started 
getting sued. As a matter of fact, copyright didn't start catching up with 
us until Fear of a Black Planet. That's when the copyrights and everything 
started becoming stricter because you had a lot of groups doing it and 
people were taking whole songs. It got so widespread that the record 
companies started policing the releases before they got out.

Stay Free!: With its hundreds of samples, is it possible to make a record 
like It Takes a Nation of Millions today? Would it be possible to clear 
every sample?

Shocklee: It wouldn't be impossible. It would just be very, very costly. 
The first thing that was starting to happen by the late 1980s was that the 
people were doing buyouts. You could have a buyout – meaning you could 
purchase the rights to sample a sound – for around $1,500. Then it started 
creeping up to $3,000, $3,500, $5,000, $7,500. Then they threw in this 
thing called rollover rates. If your rollover rate is every 100,000 units, 
then for every 100,000 units you sell, you have to pay an additional 
$7,500. A record that sells two million copies would kick that cost up 
twenty times. Now you're looking at one song costing you more than half of 
what you would make on your album.

Chuck D: Corporations found that hip-hop music was viable. It sold albums, 
which was the bread and butter of corporations. Since the corporations 
owned all the sounds, their lawyers began to search out people who 
illegally infringed upon their records. All the rap artists were on the big 
six record companies, so you might have some lawyers from Sony looking at 
some lawyers from BMG and some lawyers from BMG saying, "Your artist is 
doing this," so it was a tit for tat that usually made money for the 
lawyers, garnering money for the company. Very little went to the original 
artist or the publishing company.

Shocklee: By 1990, all the publishers and their lawyers started making 
moves. One big one was Bridgeport, the publishing house that owns all the 
George Clinton stuff. Once all the little guys started realizing you can 
get paid from rappers if they use your sample, it prompted the record 
companies to start investigating because now the people that they publish 
are getting paid.

Stay Free!: There's a noticeable difference in Public Enemy's sound between 
1988 and 1991. Did this have to do with the lawsuits and enforcement of 
copyright laws at the turn of the decade?

Chuck D: Public Enemy's music was affected more than anybody's because we 
were taking thousands of sounds. If you separated the sounds, they wouldn't 
have been anything – they were unrecognizable. The sounds were all collaged 
together to make a sonic wall. Public Enemy was affected because it is too 
expensive to defend against a claim. So we had to change our whole style, 
the style of It Takes a Nation and Fear of a Black Planet, by 1991.

Shocklee: We were forced to start using different organic instruments, but 
you can't really get the right kind of compression that way. A guitar 
sampled off a record is going to hit differently than a guitar sampled in 
the studio. The guitar that's sampled off a record is going to have all the 
compression that they put on the recording, the equalization. It's going to 
hit the tape harder. It's going to slap at you. Something that's organic is 
almost going to have a powder effect. It hits more like a pillow than a 
piece of wood. So those things change your mood, the feeling you can get 
off of a record. If you notice that by the early 1990s, the sound has 
gotten a lot softer.

Chuck D: Copyright laws pretty much led people like Dr. Dre to replay the 
sounds that were on records, then sample musicians imitating those records. 
That way you could get by the master clearance, but you still had to pay a 
publishing note.

Shocklee: See, there's two different copyrights: publishing and master 
recording. The publishing copyright is of the written music, the song 
structure. And the master recording is the song as it is played on a 
particular recording. Sampling violates both of these copyrights. Whereas 
if I record my own version of someone else's song, I only have to pay the 
publishing copyright. When you violate the master recording, the money just 
goes to the record company.

Chuck D: Putting a hundred small fragments into a song meant that you had a 
hundred different people to answer to. Whereas someone like EPMD might have 
taken an entire loop and stuck with it, which meant that they only had to 
pay one artist.

Stay Free!: So is that one reason why a lot of popular hip-hop songs today 
just use one hook, one primary sample, instead of a collage of different 
sounds?

Chuck D: Exactly. There's only one person to answer to. Dr. Dre changed 
things when he did The Chronic and took something like Leon Haywood's "I 
Want'a Do Something Freaky to You" and revamped it in his own way but 
basically kept the rhythm and instrumental hook intact. It's easier to 
sample a groove than it is to create a whole new collage. That entire 
collage element is out the window.

Shocklee: We're not really privy to all the laws and everything that the 
record company creates within the company. From our standpoint, it was 
looking like the record company was spying on us, so to speak.

Chuck D: The lawyers didn't seem to differentiate between the craftiness of 
it and what was blatantly taken.

Stay Free!: Switching from the past to the present, on the new Public Enemy 
album, Revolverlution, you had fans remix a few old Public Enemy tracks. 
How did you get this idea?

Chuck D: We have a powerful online community through Rapstation.com, 
PublicEnemy.com, Slamjams.com, and Bringthenoise.com. My thing was just 
looking at the community and being able to say, "Can we actually make them 
involved in the creative process?" Why not see if we can connect all these 
bedroom and basement studios, and the ocean of producers, and expand the 
Bomb Squad to a worldwide concept?

Stay Free!: As you probably know, some music fans are now sampling and 
mashing together two or more songs and trading the results online. There's 
one track by Evolution Control Committee that uses a Herb Alpert 
instrumental as the backing track for your "By the Time I Get to Arizona." 
It sounds like you're rapping over a Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass 
song. How do you feel about other people remixing your tracks without 
permission?

Chuck D: I think my feelings are obvious. I think it's great.



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] UNSF Declaration of Independence

Peter - great points..

Anyone with any illusions of SF being independent should probably consider
that your problems of homelessness, education, public services, police
corruption and crime will not just "stop" - Also, you think your sport teams
will stay? hell no, they would move to another city. Who would want to be a
part of the "fundamentalists" in SF, or for that matter United SF? So in
that regard there goes a source of major city revenue. What about local
business? Or for that matter, what about large business? I just can't see
these people sticking around. Should this go through, which I have the
highest doubts of anyone, you would be setting SF back 100's of years. Think
about how bad the US would tax the shit out of you guys to get your water,
electricity, etc. ...umm Gas prices anyone?!??! SF does not have the
greatest amounts of independent resources.

I am of the opinion that the US is in the business of adding land and
resources to it collection, not letting them secede.

Also, let's just say the it does go through, I can't imagine you believe
that you are just going to inherit whatever monetary resources that
currently exist for SF? Nope those would become the property of the US. And
raising bridge toll to $10 ain't gonna make up for it. Well for that matter,
I guess you wouldn't get any of the bridge toll; The bridges are owned by
the good ol US of A.

I know the people that are planning this probably have put some thought into
it...and I don't mean to hate on ya'll...but you can't just secede from the
US. Peter hits it right on the head, face your problems head on, don't just
run away to start over. Take people trying to add a respected third party
the election system....how long have they been at it? How much farther do
they have to go? Even if SF was a perfect utopia and you wanted this to
happen you are still talking decades of swaying public opinion...you need a
few more than 100 people to do this.

Good idea folks, but just never gonna happen...also who are you gonna turn
to when the terrorists attack? You have no military. You gonna bargain with
'em? Arm the homeless? You think cause your not with the US, you still don't
represent Christian, Western civilization? Not everyone out there lives
plur. Most can't even spell it ;)
--
DJ Jack Triumph

> officials would be as "positive" about your efforts
> once they realized it meant they wouldn't have jobs or

> solves them.  And usually the further you run the
> worse it gets.  Constructive engagement is more
> difficult and often seems totally frustrating and

> meaningful change.

     I'm confused... was this a proposal that SF would become independant of 
the US politically, or was this a proposal for SF to go to friggin war with 
US??? i mean just because a city proposed to become independant of a country 
politically doesn't mean that the country will boycott us and abandon us from all 
utilities and military defense when/if needed. look how well we treat canada, 
we trade with them all the time and if they are in trouble who's got their 
back? the US of course. i'm sure if SF somehow (althought i can't see how this 
could possibly happen) became an independent, the rest of the US would just 
roll their eyes and laugh at our leftist ways. but when push did come to shove 
and people were in trouble here, they would take us back in with a, "i told you 
so" and a slap on the wrist.      You guys make it sound like we're doomed to 
death if we did something like this. I think it's a valid proposal but i just 
don't think the majority of the population in SF really agrees with this. Yes 
there were millions of protestors here but they came from all over the place. 
SF seems to be a major hot spot for going against the grain, but when i hang 
out in the city and drive around go shopping at the mall, grab a bite to eat 
and what not, you look at those big corparate buildings downtown, you look at 
all the kids at SFSU and UCSF and you see tons of fearful people who are just as 
comformist as everyone else in the US.   They all have a republican club, the 
majority of em probably voted for arnold, aside from the haight district i 
don't see a maroity of people in SF or any city for that matter having the 
audasity to create a declration of independance from the rest of the US. 
     i do, however think it's a very cool idea and i don't agree that we'd 
have such disasterous problems with utilities and military protection against 
terrorist attacks etc.   look at the friggin places that terrorist DO attack; 
the world trade center (stocks) <--- evil, the pentagon (big government) <---- 
evil. there are reasons terrorists attack the places that they attack. a city 
that has just declared independance from the US is the safest place in the 
world to live in as far as terrorist attacks are concerned. terrorist don't attack 
places just becuse they can, they attack places that they feel are so wrong 
that it's worth giving up their life to take it down. I don't see how becoming 
independant as a city would cause the US to boycott us and change anything in 
the way things are traded in and out of the city, we're not declaring war on 
the US, we're not boycotting them, it sounds like they proposing being 
independant politically as in policies and ideogies and beliefs. if that's the case it 
sound like a great idea. but still... go walk around SF go every where and 
take a lil survery in your head, i bet you at least 6 out of every 10 people in 
this city are conformists who will not stick up for such a radical policy.   
conformists are everywhere fear is everywhere sadly enough, even on this list. 

--part1_fb.5877d613.2df050bc_boundary--

Amber n. (AM.ber) 1. http://www.iamthedj.com

See also: 1. http://www.sistersf.com

           3. http://www.norcaldjmpa.com

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Juan Atkins at Club 6

--=====================_12187935==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

Saturday June 5th

Club Six presenté

Juan Atkins
at <http://www.illstatic.com/venue_list.php?venue=Six#top>Six
9:00pm until 4am
21+ / $15

The Legends of House series returns featuring the shoguns of underground 
electronica battling it out for the hearts and minds of underground masses.

Representing the Detroit Techno Shogunate: Juan Atkins -- the godfather of 
Techno Juan Atkins truly is a legend in his own time. Appearing behind 
aliases such as Cybotron, Model 500 and Infiniti, he has released many 
classics of sublime Detroit techno, including the 1982 electro track 
"Clear." Recorded by Atkins and Rick Davis as Cybotron, this track is often 
considered the first proto-techno track. Experimenting with fusing the 
extra-terrestrial funk of Parliament Funkadelic with the futuristic rhythms 
and hard math of Kraftwerk , the Model 500 12"s laid the blueprint for 
Detroit Techno.

Along with the tracks made by two schoolmates from the grade below, Derrick 
May and Kevin Saunderson, Detroit Techno quickly made its way across the 
Atlantic and immediately sparked the emerging rave culture and soon after 
the entire global dance community. Moving through the later 80's as Model 
500, Atkins continued as one of the most prolific and sought after 
producers of electronic music throughout the 90's, culminating in the use 
of an Atkins' original as the musical bed for the 2000 launch of the Ford 
Focus 'Detroit Techno' automobile.

Along with:
Jesse Saunders The orginator of House
Andrew Jervis (Ubiquity Records, The Friday Night Sessions)
Dusty Crates (Electric Soul)
David Jeromin
and a rare opening set by Angel (b-day boy and club 6 owner)
With artwork in the lounge from: Adam Feibelman, Anita Brey, Calder Tani 
Santhai, Carissa Cabrera, Chad Hasegawa, D.Cody, Dara Sherman, David 
Johansen, David Nyquist, Donnie Martinez, Garrison Beau Scott, Garvin 
Victor Yee, Heather Weitman, Heidi Neff, Jameson Pruscia, Julie A. Miller, 
Karissa Engelstad, Kathleen King Kynthia, Randy Kochis, Ray Torres Roni 
Feldman, Saunders Hildreth

Curator: Elisabeth Starr



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"The welfare of the people in particular has always been the alibi of 
tyrants, and it provides the further advantage of giving the servants of 
tyranny a good conscience."
-Albert Camus

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

"I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_12187935==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: 'JUST SAY NO' ADS DON'T WORK

--=====================_12655327==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

 From Undernews:

'JUST SAY NO' ADS DON'T WORK
<http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/ssistory.mpl/front/2595607>http://www.chron.com/cs/CDA/ssistory.mpl/front/2595607 


SK BARDWELL, HOUSTON CHRONICLE - Anti-drug ads, which the government plans 
to spend $145 million to produce this fiscal year, do little to dissuade 
young people from taking drugs, according to research conducted by Texas 
State University at San Marcos psychology professors. Even worse, the ads 
may actually prompt some teens to experiment with drugs -- a reaction 
diametrically opposite that sought by the White House Office of National 
Drug Policy.

The study, which researchers will present Friday at a meeting of the 
American Psychological Society in Chicago, is part of a larger, ongoing 
project sponsored by the Marijuana Policy Project, a national marijuana 
policy reform organization. . .

Three of every four students reported the ads sparked thoughts that ran 
counter to the ads' message, the study showed. "For example, in response to 
ads linking drug use to the war on terror, the most frequent unanticipated 
thoughts were that marijuana should be legalized, the war on drugs has been 
ineffective, and that marijuana users should grow their own," said Czyzewska.

<P>Here's a few dozen reasons to vote for the G.<BR><BR>George W. Bush<BR>The White House, USA<BR><BR>EDUCATION AND EXPERIENCE:<BR><BR><BR>LAW ENFORCEMENT:<BR><BR>I was arrested in Kennebunkport, Maine, in 1976 for driving under the influence of alcohol. I pled guilty, paid a fine, and had my driver's license suspended for 30 days. My Texas driving record has been "lost" and is not available.<BR><BR><BR>MILITARY:<BR><BR>I joined the Texas Air National Guard and went AWOL. I refused to take a drug test or answer any questions about my drug use. By joining the Texas Air National Guard, I was able to avoid combat duty in Vietnam.<BR><BR><BR>COLLEGE:<BR><BR>I graduated from Yale University with a low C average. I was a cheerleader.<BR><BR><BR>PAST WORK EXPERIENCE:<BR><BR>I ran for U.S. Congress and lost.<BR><BR>I began my career in the oil business in Midland, Texas, in 1975. I bought an oil company, but couldn't find any oil in Texas. The company went bankrupt shortly after I sold all my stock.<BR><BR>I bought the Texas Rangers baseball team in a sweetheart deal that took and using taxpayer money.<BR><BR>With the help of my father and our right-wing friends in the oil industry (including Enron CEO Ken Lay), I was elected governor of Texas.<BR><BR><BR>ACCOMPLISHMENTS AS GOVERNOR OF TEXAS:<BR><BR>I changed Texas pollution laws to favor power and oil companies, making Texas the most polluted state in the Union.<BR><BR>During my tenure, Houston replaced Los Angeles as the most smog-ridden city in America.<BR><BR>I cut taxes and bankrupted the Texas treasury to the tune of billions in borrowed money.<BR><BR>I set the record for the most executions by any governor in American history.<BR><BR>With the help of my brother, the governor of Florida, and my father's appointments to the Supreme Court, I became President after losing by over 500,000 votes.<BR><BR><BR>ACCOMPLISHMENTS AS PRESIDENT:<BR><BR>I am the first President in U.S. history to enter office with a criminal record.<BR><BR>I invaded and occupied two countries at a continuing cost of over one Billion dollars per week.<BR><BR>I spent the U.S. surplus and effectively bankrupted the U.S. Treasury.<BR><BR>I shattered the record for the largest annual deficit in U.S. history.<BR><BR>I set an economic record for most private bankruptcies filed in any 12-month period.<BR><BR>I set the all-time record for most foreclosures in a 12-month period.<BR><BR>I'm proud that the members of my cabinet are the richest of any administration in U.S. history.<BR><BR>My "poorest millionaire," Condoleeza Rice, has a Chevron oil tanker named after her.<BR><BR>I set the record for most campaign fundraising trips by a U.S. President.<BR><BR>I am the all-time U.S. and world record-holder for receiving the most corporate campaign donations.<BR><BR>My largest lifetime campaign contributor, and one of my best friends, Kenneth Lay, presided over the largest corporate bankruptcy fraud in U.S. History, Enron.<BR><BR>My political party used Enron private jets and corporate attorneys to assure my success with the U.S. Supreme Court during my election decision.<BR><BR>I have protected my friends at Enron and Halliburton against investigation or prosecution. More time and money was spent investigating the Monica Lewinsky affair than has been spent investigating one of the biggest corporate rip-offs in history.<BR><BR>I presided over the biggest energy crisis in U.S. history and refused to intervene when corruption involving the oil industry was revealed.<BR><BR>I presided over the highest gasoline prices in U.S. history.<BR><BR>I changed the U.S. policy to allow convicted criminals to be awarded government contracts.<BR><BR>I appointed more convicted criminals to administration than any President in U.S. history.<BR><BR>I created the Ministry of Homeland Security, the largest bureaucracy in the history of the United States government.<BR><BR>I've broken more international treaties than any President in U.S. history.<BR><BR>I am the first President in U.S. history to have the United Nations remove the U.S. from the Human Rights Commission.<BR><BR>I withdrew the U.S. from the World Court of Law.<BR><BR>I refused to allow inspectors access to U.S. "prisoners of war" detainees and thereby have refused to abide by the Geneva Convention.<BR><BR>I am the first President in history to refuse United Nations election inspectors (during the 2002 U.S. election).<BR><BR>I set the record for fewest number of press conferences of any President since the advent of television.<BR><BR>I set the all-time record for most days on vacation in any one-year period.<BR><BR>After taking off the entire month of August, I presided over the worst security failure in U.S. history.<BR><BR>I garnered the most sympathy for the U.S. after the World Trade Center attacks and less than a year later made the U.S. the most hated country n the world, the largest failure of diplomacy in world history.<BR><BR>I have set the all-time record for most people worldwide to simultaneously protest me in public venues (15 million people), shattering the record for protest against any person in the history of mankind.<BR><BR>I am the first President in U.S. history to order an unprovoked, preemptive attack and the military occupation of a sovereign nation. I did so against the will of the United Nations, the majority of U.S. citizens, and the world community.<BR><BR>I have cut health care benefits for war veterans and support a cut in duty benefits for active duty troops and their families -- in war time.<BR><BR>In my State of the Union Address, I lied about our reasons for attacking Iraq, then blamed the lies on our British friends.<BR><BR>I am the first President in history to have a majority of Europeans (71%) view my presidency as the biggest threat to world peace and security.<BR><BR>I am supporting development of a nuclear "Tactical Bunker Buster," a WMD.<BR><BR>I have so far failed to fulfill my pledge to bring Osama Bin Laden to justice.<BR><BR><BR>RECORDS AND REFERENCES:<BR><BR>All records of my tenure as governor of Texas are now in my father's library, sealed and unavailable for public view.<BR><BR>All records of SEC investigations into my insider trading and my bankrupt companies are sealed in secrecy and unavailable for public view.<BR><BR>All records or minutes from meetings that I, or my Vice-President, attended regarding public energy policy are sealed in secrecy and unavailable for public review.<BR><BR><BR>PLEASE CONSIDER MY EXPERIENCE WHEN VOTING IN 2004.</P></DIV></div></html>

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Ball Pythons for sale!

I have two fat and happy Ball Pythons for sale. I'm pretty certain they're 
both males, but I'm by far not a snake expert, and I'm not really willing ot 
probe them to find out otherwise. I received them both (separately) as 
gifts, and they've been together for about 3 & 1/2 years now (with no 
babies). So either they're both really males, or they're both females (or 
they can't have kids, lol).

The older of the two is Jake, he's approx. 5 + years old. He was rescued 
from an engine block two years before I got him, and he was a little bigger 
than most Ball Python babies.

The younger is Nugget. I got him as a baby.

Neither snake has had any health issues of any kind. Jake had one bad shed 
when I first got him, but a little bath in warm water took care of it, and 
he hasn't had an issue since.

They live together in a 100 gallon tank, but feed separately (I have a small 
tank for Nugget to go into when they feed). They both eat rats - Jake can 
eat up to a medium (as long as it's not huge), and Nugget still eats small 
rats.

I am selling them together, with both tanks, a heat rock, an old heating 
pad, and wooden thingies they use to hang out on/hide under for $75. They're 
up on Craigslist right now for more - but for the SFR community I'll drop 
the price.

Anyway - if you're interested, or have any questions regarding these little 
guys, hit me off list!

Marc(O)

Well said, Sean.  Although I wasn't trying to defend Tiesto or trance in 
particular.  Just music in general.  Like Country music.  I don't listen to 
it, don't dig it, don't get it.  But somehow it still bugs me when some 
individuals blurt out "Why do people listen to that crap?"  But hey, 
everyone is entitled to their opinion.  I'm just gonna go build that bridge 
of mine and get over it :)

Rob



----Original Message Follows----
From: Sean Griffith <hatter@tmail.com>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Tiesto Tonight - Ruby Skye !!!
Date: Fri, 4 Jun 2004 18:55:05 -0700

It's because all these jaded ass ravers burnt themselves out on a couple 
years of cheese trance and ecky during trance's heydey. Now they think of 
themselves as having "outgrown" it. :) There's a certain headspace in which 
that kind of trance makes sense... And that  headspace is pretty rare these 
days.

This is an age of war and blood. Peaceful music doesn't synch with the 
collective unconscious.

...love the stuff myself.

Sean G

------------------

Here's a few dozen reasons to vote for the G.

George W. Bush
The White House, USA

EDUCATION AND EXPERIENCE:


LAW ENFORCEMENT:

I was arrested in Kennebunkport, Maine, in 1976 for driving under the 
influence of alcohol. I pled guilty, paid a fine, and had my driver's 
license suspended for 30 days. My Texas driving record has been "lost" and 
is not available.


MILITARY:

I joined the Texas Air National Guard and went AWOL. I refused to take a 
drug test or answer any questions about my drug use. By joining the Texas 
Air National Guard, I was able to avoid combat duty in Vietnam.


COLLEGE:

I graduated from Yale University with a low C average. I was a cheerleader.


PAST WORK EXPERIENCE:

I ran for U.S. Congress and lost.

I began my career in the oil business in Midland, Texas, in 1975. I bought 
an oil company, but couldn't find any oil in Texas. The company went 
bankrupt shortly after I so ld all my stock.

I bought the Texas Rangers baseball team in a sweetheart deal that took and 
using taxpayer money.

With the help of my father and our right-wing friends in the oil industry 
(including Enron CEO Ken Lay), I was elected governor of Texas.


ACCOMPLISHMENTS AS GOVERNOR OF TEXAS:

I changed Texas pollution laws to favor power and oil companies, making 
Texas the most polluted state in the Union.

During my tenure, Houston replaced Los Angeles as the most smog-ridden city 
in America.

I cut taxes and bankrupted the Texas treasury to the tune of billions in 
borrowed money.

I set the record for the most executions by any governor in American 
history.

With the help of my brother, the governor of Florida, and my father's 
appointments to the Supreme Court, I became President after losing by over 
500,000 votes.


ACCOMPLISHMENTS AS PRESIDENT:

I am the first President in U.S. history to enter office wi th a criminal 
record.

I invaded and occupied two countries at a continuing cost of over one 
Billion dollars per week.

I spent the U.S. surplus and effectively bankrupted the U.S. Treasury.

I shattered the record for the largest annual deficit in U.S. history.

I set an economic record for most private bankruptcies filed in any 12-month 
period.

I set the all-time record for most foreclosures in a 12-month period.

I'm proud that the members of my cabinet are the richest of any 
administration in U.S. history.

My "poorest millionaire," Condoleeza Rice, has a Chevron oil tanker named 
after her.

I set the record for most campaign fundraising trips by a U.S. President.

I am the all-time U.S. and world record-holder for receiving the most 
corporate campaign donations.

My largest lifetime campaign contributor, and one of my best friends, 
Kenneth Lay, presided over the largest corporate bankruptcy fraud in U.S. 
Histo ry, Enron.

My political party used Enron private jets and corporate attorneys to assure 
my success with the U.S. Supreme Court during my election decision.

I have protected my friends at Enron and Halliburton against investigation 
or prosecution. More time and money was spent investigating the Monica 
Lewinsky affair than has been spent investigating one of the biggest 
corporate rip-offs in history.

I presided over the biggest energy crisis in U.S. history and refused to 
intervene when corruption involving the oil industry was revealed.

I presided over the highest gasoline prices in U.S. history.

I changed the U.S. policy to allow convicted criminals to be awarded 
government contracts.

I appointed more convicted criminals to administration than any President in 
U.S. history.

I created the Ministry of Homeland Security, the largest bureaucracy in the 
history of the United States government.

I've broken more international treaties than any President in U.S. history.

I am the first President in U.S. history to have the United Nations remove 
the U.S. from the Human Rights Commission.

I withdrew the U.S. from the World Court of Law.

I refused to allow inspectors access to U.S. "prisoners of war" detainees 
and thereby have refused to abide by the Geneva Convention.

I am the first President in history to refuse United Nations election 
inspectors (during the 2002 U.S. election).

I set the record for fewest number of press conferences of any President 
since the advent of television.

I set the all-time record for most days on vacation in any one-year period.

After taking off the entire month of August, I presided over the worst 
security failure in U.S. history.

I garnered the most sympathy for the U.S. after the World Trade Center 
attacks and less than a year later made the U.S. the most hated country n 
the world, the largest failure of diplomac y in world history.

I have set the all-time record for most people worldwide to simultaneously 
protest me in public venues (15 million people), shattering the record for 
protest against any person in the history of mankind.

I am the first President in U.S. history to order an unprovoked, preemptive 
attack and the military occupation of a sovereign nation. I did so against 
the will of the United Nations, the majority of U.S. citizens, and the world 
community.

I have cut health care benefits for war veterans and support a cut in duty 
benefits for active duty troops and their families -- in war time.

In my State of the Union Address, I lied about our reasons for attacking 
Iraq, then blamed the lies on our British friends.

I am the first President in history to have a majority of Europeans (71%) 
view my presidency as the biggest threat to world peace and security.

I am supporting development of a nuclear "Tactical Bunker Buster," a WMD.< 
BR>
I have so far failed to fulfill my pledge to bring Osama Bin Laden to 
justice.


RECORDS AND REFERENCES:

All records of my tenure as governor of Texas are now in my father's 
library, sealed and unavailable for public view.

All records of SEC investigations into my insider trading and my bankrupt 
companies are sealed in secrecy and unavailable for public view.

All records or minutes from meetings that I, or my Vice-President, attended 
regarding public energy policy are sealed in secrecy and unavailable for 
public review.


PLEASE CONSIDER MY EXPERIENCE WHEN VOTING IN 2004.

From sfraves-return-112944-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Jun 05 20:35:16 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-112944-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 45238 invoked by uid 1103); 5 Jun 2004 20:35:16 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 45224 invoked from network); 5 Jun 2004 20:35:15 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [63.198.218.177]
X-Originating-Email: [plurranger@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: plurranger@hotmail.com
From: "Ranger -" <plurranger@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Sat, 05 Jun 2004 13:35:12 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY16-F110YLowspDKi0006f0db@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 05 Jun 2004 20:35:13.0142 (UTC) FILETIME=[9A430160:01C44B3C]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] Tiesto Review - Ruby Skye !!!

This marked my 4th time to Ruby.. seems to keep getting more expensive.. but 
the door and security rocks.. so no complaints for a club.. I can see why 
SF'rs rate it #1.  So there I am in the #1 club.. seeing #1 DJ.. amazing.  
The place was packed and it's huge, and everyone is f*cking eye candy.. I 
danced for about 5 hours straight.. off the freakin' chain.

Ruby Ske's sounds system is really amazing to me.. I didn't fully understand 
it at first.. the front stage was definitely consuming, and imaged well.. 
but the balance was odd from hight to low.. and as I started walking around 
to differnt sections it came togethet for me.. the Bass tubes or run along 
the stair cases in the back.. so that the bass can reverberate up the back 
cornsers.. fills the top and then echos forward.. which works for such a 
large space.  When you are on the main floor center.. the imaging of the 
highs comes off really loud.. but fills well with mids that hit from the 
front corners ointing forward.. as it should be.  The best sound is thus 
center rear and the lfloating light stantion(sp?) is killer.. that loopy 
thing drops and swirls and bathes people in light.. at one point I remember 
everyone raising ther hands into the light and swirling like ringlets of 
hair in the fingers.

The crowd was so beautifull.. I met a Brazillian girl from Miami that came 
here just to see tiesto spin.. I think she was a groupie.. she had all the 
after party digs and was amazing looking, and sweet.. imagine that!  
Everyone was rollin.. but noone was puddling.. ahh the adults at play, a 
fine sight indeed.  So much love and soo many people.. how does that work?

Anyway.. the intro dj DJ Bali was a little slow.. but when it came time for 
the hand-off and the crowd started chanting Tiesto.. Tiesto!!  I couldn't 
help but feel like Tiesto would have to hit the decks hard.. Bali's last 30 
minutes were sick as hell.. hard hitting tracks that had everyone jumpin.. 
Tiesto hit a little slow at first so it was alright.. but off a bit.. then 
his set from 1:30-3am was crazy.. mad skills, all over the boards.. slappin 
records.. really interacting with the crowd.  He is quite the DJ's DJ.  As 
usuall I was right up front.. it was crowded.. you had to leave now and 
again to do some real dancing, or assert some space.. but everyone let 
everyone take their turns to get their groove on and made way.. it was phat. 
  I was usually surrounded by beautiful wemon shaking their thang.. so no 
complaints their either :)

All in all I give Tiesto a 9 for small venue performance, and 8 on track 
selection, an 8 on mix effects and audience interaction, and overall a 9 for 
satisfaction.   I have to admit their was a lot of new stuff he broke out.. 
but the best tracks were the classics.  I would go see tiesto spin anytime.

Hey Ibizza Aug 2005.. if anyone else is going let me know.. I am going to 
try and do a time share.

Ranger



SFR: Ranger
Santa Cruz
plurranger@hotmail.com
Who knows where the night leads
It's dark and no one can see

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: (POL) The Signing of the Declaration of Inependence

You're cordially invited to join us, the 100th Monkey, for a historical 
event at the Really Really Free Market on Sunday, June 6th at Union 
Square, 2:30PM.

In conjunction with the Free City Movement and the Reclaim the Commons 
Mobilization, the 100th Monkey is inviting you, your friends, and even 
your enemies to come join us as we declare our independence. At 
approximately 2:30PM, stand with your fellow brothers and sister of the 
United Neighborhoods of San Francisco, and sign the Declaration of 
Independence. Come dressed for making history in whatever costume or 
lack thereof feels right to you -- and help us make history. A new 
world is possible and we pledge to make it real!

  The text of the declaration can be found at:
http://www.indybay.org/news/2004/05/1682192.php

Saturday, June 5, 2004 ** Seismic **

BUSY WEEKEND IN THE CRUZ...

We are taking SEISMIC to the Beach for an all night
bender of Breaks and such next weekend. This is the
Beach party of the summer that is not to be missed!

Join us on June 5th at Red White and Blue Beach in
Santa Cruz as we bring out the Big Outdoor Sound and
spark up the bonfire and fire dancers under the almost
full moon.

For any of you who have not been to Red White and Blue
Beach, you are in for quite a treat. It is private
campground about 6 miles north of Santa Cruz off of
Route 1. The folks who own it are kind enough to let
us set up in a beautiful spot that is surrounded by
dunes/hills that protect from the wind and the
elements.

We will be laying down the Bass Heavy Beats from
Sunrise to Sunset so bring your party shoes. It is
going to be one hell of a night.

Red White and Blue Beach is located at 5021 Coast Road
Santa Cruz CA 95060. Look for a red, white, and blue
mailbox at Scaroni Road near milepost 24.9. Go down
the Scaroni Road about a 1/4 mile. The campground
charges a $15 camping fee.

Bring:
warm clothes
sleeping bag and/or tent
booze
food
etc.

DJs include:
Murphstar - (Tactility, SEISMIC)
Benchun (False Profit, Samurai Soundsystem)
Brett Pinkin
Tyler Reed (Grand Champion Sound)
Samira (Sister SF)
Captain Morris
and more to be announced.

I look forward to seeing you all at the Beach!

http://seismicsf.org/
http://www.bobblehead.org/main/
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1395
Santa Cruz California, USA

Saturday, June 5, 2004 ** Legends of House 11.0 vs. Legends of Techno v1.0 =
Battle of the Shoguns **

Legends of House 11.0 vs. Legends of Techno v1.0
Battle of the Shoguns

JUAN ATKINS vs. JESSE SAUNDERS
The Legends of House series returns featuring the
shoguns of underground electronica battling it out for
the hearts and minds of underground masses.

Representing the Detroit Techno Shogunate: Juan Atkins
-- the godfather of Techno
Juan Atkins truly is a legend in his own time.
Appearing behind aliases such as Cybotron, Model 500
and Infiniti, he has released many classics of sublime
Detroit techno, including the 1982 electro track
"Clear." Recorded by Atkins and Rick Davis as
Cybotron, this track is often considered the first
proto-techno track. Experimenting with fusing the
extra-terrestrial funk of Parliament Funkadelic with
the futuristic rhythms and hard math of Kraftwerk ,
the Model 500 12"s laid the blueprint for Detroit
Techno.

Along with the tracks made by two schoolmates from the
grade below, Derrick May and Kevin Saunderson, Detroit
Techno quickly made its way across the Atlantic and
immediately sparked the emerging rave culture and soon
after the entire global dance community. Moving
through the later 80's as Model 500, Atkins continued
as one of the most prolific and sought after producers
of electronic music throughout the 90's, culminating
in the use of an Atkins' original as the musical bed
for the 2000 launch of the Ford Focus 'Detroit Techno'
automobile.

Along with:
Jesse Saunders The orginator of House
Andrew Jervis (Ubiquity Records, The Friday Night
Sessions)
Dusty Crates (Electric Soul)
David Jeromin
and a rare opening set by Angel (b-day boy and club 6
owner) With artwork in the lounge from: Adam Feibelman, Anita Brey, Calder =
Tani Santhai, Carissa Cabrera, Chad Hasegawa, D.Cody, Dara Sherman, David J=
ohansen, David Nyquist, Donnie Martinez, Garrison Beau Scott, Garvin Victor=
 Yee, Heather Weitman, Heidi Neff, Jameson Pruscia, Julie A. Miller, Kariss=
a Engelstad, Kathleen King Kynthia, Randy Kochis, Ray Torres Roni Feldman, =
Saunders Hildreth

Curator: Elisabeth Starr

time: 9 pm - 4 am
admission: free before 10 pm, $10 before 12 midnight,
$15 after, 21+ only
location: Club Six
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1400
San Francisco California, USA

Saturday, June 5, 2004 ** Dhamaal SoundSystem **

Saturday, June 5 Sunset Promotions presents...
Dhamaal SoundSystem.  Additional Artists: Janaka Selecta, Dhruva Ganesan, D=
J Zeph, Shabi Farooq, Ferhan Qureshi, and video by Skip Intro.  Music Type:=
 World/Cultural
Artist/Band Link: www.dhamaalsf.com

What to you get when you fuse modern banging
electronica with traditional South Asian Tablas and
Dumbek and trippy visuals?-- SF art collective
Dhamaal. They pump up the volume on the Elbo Room's
recently upgraded sound system. Dhamaal comes out from the underground scen=
e to bring the rhythm forward
along with performers: Janaka [Selekta], DJ Zeph,
Dhruva Ganesan (Dumbek/Tabla), Shabi Farooq
(Tabla/Vocal).

Dhamaal is a San Francisco-based artist collective
that aims to fuse live traditional South Asian music,
modern international electronica, and groundbreaking
visual art. Their long-running residency has been a
hidden gem in San Francisco's underground arts scene.

time: 10 pm - 1:45 am
door admission: $10, 21+ only
online tickets: www.sunsettickets.com
information: www.sunsetpromotions.net
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1398
San Francisco California, USA

Saturday, June 5, 2004 ** ** Dhamaal SoundSystem ** **

Saturday, June 5 Sunset Promotions presents...
Dhamaal SoundSystem.  Additional Artists: Janaka Selecta, Dhruva Ganesan, D=
J Zeph, Shabi Farooq, Ferhan Qureshi, and video by Skip Intro.  Music Type:=
 World/Cultural
Artist/Band Link: www.dhamaalsf.com

What to you get when you fuse modern banging
electronica with traditional South Asian Tablas and
Dumbek and trippy visuals?-- SF art collective
Dhamaal. They pump up the volume on the Elbo Room's
recently upgraded sound system. Dhamaal comes out from the underground scen=
e to bring the rhythm forward
along with performers: Janaka [Selekta], DJ Zeph,
Dhruva Ganesan (Dumbek/Tabla), Shabi Farooq
(Tabla/Vocal).

Dhamaal is a San Francisco-based artist collective
that aims to fuse live traditional South Asian music,
modern international electronica, and groundbreaking
visual art. Their long-running residency has been a
hidden gem in San Francisco's underground arts scene.

time: 10 pm - 1:45 am
door admission: $10, 21+ only
online tickets: www.sunsettickets.com
information: www.sunsetpromotions.net
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D1399
