Saturday, June 12, 2004 ** Loveworks presents: Love Injection **

Loveworks, the spark that has grown into an intense eight year inferno comb=
ining house music, art, and cutting edge atmospherics continues it=92s seri=
es of monthly audiosocial experiments and gives San Francisco a =91 LOVE IN=
JECTION =91 on Saturday June 12th =9204 at their homebase=97 the 111 Minna =
Gallery in San Francisco=92s SOMA District.  This special event will be a c=
ollaboration with SF based deep house music label LOVESLAP and features spe=
cial guest DJ's MAURICIO AVILES & CHARLES SPENCER from the label itself ( s=
ee BIOS below ! ).  Also supporting the guests is Loveworks resident dj DAV=
ID HARNESS, who is also an artist on Loveslap=92s roster; mmm=85 all the be=
tter to groove you with !  At the door will our guardian RAUL celebrating h=
is 40th birthday as well as guest services by the nicest man in security, B=
IG DAVE.  Your hosts for the evening are the inimitable NORI CASTILLO and D=
IANNA JACOBS who were instrumental in the creation of the legendary TOONTOW=
N parties as well as CAREFREE DANCING, the original house party at 177 Town=
send.   Your other hosts for the evening are TALY, JIM & NIKITA.  Also in t=
he early part of the evening, The Loveworks Classics Caf=E9 kicks off the n=
ight properly at 8pm with a special Classics Caf=E9 event starring Haight s=
treet=92s excellent Rooky=92s Records crew; featuring Rooky and DJ Goldmyne=
 spinning and selling fabulous 60's & 70's soul.  Vintage rug-cutting- come=
 "Butter your Popcorn" and "Shake your Moneymaker."  Dig it ?

Bio: MAURICIO AVILES
Born in the capitol of El Salvador in 1969, Mauricio Aviles immigrated with=
 his parents to San Francisco, California in 1973. Growing up in the Missio=
n District, he was constantly surrounded by the latin rhythms of the barrio=
=2E His father had a company that produced theatrical and musical events th=
at featured 'la cultura latina', and eventually Mauricio became involved wi=
th his father's creative enterprise, helping to produce several festivals a=
nd concerts in the Bay Area. The people and the music of this period provid=
ed the foundation for Mauricio's involvement in the City's burgeoning dance=
 scene that evolved throughout the 90's.
As a dj Mauricio's first actual gigs began at the City's bastion of undergr=
ound vibration, the EndUp. As a protege of Arron Olivares, Mauricio began f=
orming his own sounds and creating a devoted following that are still with =
him today. His next regular residencies were simultaneously Corazon, a lati=
n flavored weekly in the heart of the Mission District, and Metrojazz a ver=
y popular and original weekend event that successfully combined down tempo,=
 abstract beats and house, a hybrid that would eventually become to describ=
e the 'San Francisco Sound'.   Acknowledging the urban, afro origins of dan=
ce music, with a personal blend of his own latino roots, and a constant end=
eavor to break new ground, Mauricio's sound is hauntingly personal, emotion=
al and consistently fresh. Creating a niche within the deep house sound, hi=
s style, though ethereal, is undeniably funky and always elicits a great re=
sponse on the dance floor.  Now with an internationally successful compilat=
ion under his belt (Naked Music's Nude Dimension II), Mauricio has begun hi=
s production career with a debut single slated for release in Summer 2001. =
As an emissary for Naked Music, Mauricio has also commenced a global tour, =
ensuring that America's hottest new dance label is well represented.  Mauri=
cio has of late done production work and dj=92d under the moniker of MOVIDO=
, his project with collaborator and Loveslap label founder Charles Spencer.

Bio: DAVID HARNESS
In 1990, David began DJ'ing in his hometown of Monterey, California, at the=
 After Dark. As his popularity grew past the boundaries of Monterey, he was=
 invited to establish a residency at Tilt, and Sound Factory, in San Franci=
sco. In 1992, as David's popularity continued to grow he, along with DJ, Ru=
ben Mancias and promoter Joseph Solis opened a hip and popular club, Lift, =
at Club Dv8. David joined Bay Area legendary DJ, Pete Avila and host Foxxee=
 Brown on 'Your Mama's House', on the Bay Area's popular radio station KMEL=
 FM. Being the only "true" house mix show on any Northern California radio =
station, DJ's David Harness, Pete Avila and host Foxxee Brown have played a=
 key role in furthering House Music in the Bay Area. Also during that year,=
 David established a residency at San Francisco's legendary Club Universe. =
David Harness has quickly become one of the most well known and popular DJ'=
s in the San Francisco Bay Area club scene. David's popularity continued to=
 soar, taking him around the world; and the opportunity to play with New Yo=
rk's Legendary DJ's, Frankie Knuckles, Tony Humphries, Little Louie Vega, T=
edd Patterson, Dave Morales, London's Ricky Morrison, Danny Teneglia, Marqu=
es Wyatt- to name a few. He has appeared in articles and interviews in Bill=
board Magazine, Paper Magazine, Surface, XLR8R, Urb, Streetsounds, Sweater,=
 HX, Next and the Bay Guardian.



Bio: LOVEWORKS
Add a large helping of deep underground house music with a side of funk, a =
heap of disco, and a hint of techno, and you have the most nutritious dance=
floor experience available in San Francisco. Initially conceived by Dianna =
Jacobs and Nori Castillo of Toontown /  Carefree fame in the summer of '96,=
 Loveworks was envisioned as a refuge from the monotony of local clubs and =
superficial music, and  has become one of the bay area's most well known ni=
ghts out, while somehow remaining one it's best kept secrets.  It exists to=
 unite people of any race, social status or sexuality together in a comfort=
able and friendly club environment with music as the focal point, and in ad=
dition to it's monthly parties at the Minna Gallery, Loveworks also teams u=
p with other like minded parties around the city and has been featured at c=
lubs and parties such as Liquid, the Top, Electric, and the Endup.  Besides=
 late night dancing, Loveworks has also been involved in events for Wired M=
agazine, Apple Computer, Sony Digital, Construct Internet Design, and a hos=
t of others. Loveworks also had the honor of winning the SF Bay Guardian=92=
s =91 BEST HOUSE CLUB =91 in 1999.


Bio: 111 MINNA GALLERY
111 Minna Gallery is a dynamic =91contemporary art salon=92 that provides a=
n arena for multi-dimensional artistic expression in a community atmosphere=
=2E The goal of the =91gallery-as salon=92 concept is to nurture and suppor=
t a communal gathering of artists and a collaboration between diverse art f=
orms. This goal is achieved through six-week rotations of visual art exhibi=
tions curated by the staff combined with a variety of music and film events=
=2E =91Minna=92 is not only the name of the street on which the gallery is =
found but also translates from Japanese as "everybody," an all-inclusive te=
rm that symbolizes the embracing environment of the space. The gallery, whi=
ch also offers two bars, is crafted in an eclectic, contemporary design wit=
h ample furniture inviting guests to leisurely relax and enjoy conversation=
 among friends. The combination of art, music, film, dance and conversation=
 found at 111 Minna Gallery creates a unique gathering place for a multi-se=
nsory experience.


( contact: Nori for information and guest list questions / 866 841 9139 ext=
 2016 / loveworksdancing@onebox.com )

Thursday, June 24, 2004 ** Fuzion Presents 100% Tony Humphries, A Bay Area =
Exclusive **

House music has evolved from the soulful, gospel-inspired sounds of disco, =
and it owes its emergence to the artistry of DJ Tony Humphries. His unmista=
kable style continues to leave an irreplaceable impression on the global da=
nce music industry having entertained at over 500 venues worldwide and prod=
ucing more than 200 studio remixes. Throughout tremendous recognition, nume=
rous awards and accolades from his peers, Tony Humphries has remained humbl=
e and true to the sound of what we call house music.

Please join us for this special one night engagement, with Djs Tony Humphri=
es, David Harness, Matt Mau and Bernard Cabigon. At =93Mighty=94 Located in=
 the heart of the SF design district, within blocks of both Hwy 101 and Hwy=
 280, Mighty boasts a 6,000 square foot expanse of beautiful hardwood floor=
s, 22=88 high ceilings, exposed brick walls, and gigantic wood pillars and =
beams throughout. Sound system comes to Mighty from the legendary Sound Fac=
tory in New York City. It is a classic Richard Long & Associates system wit=
h most of the original components lovingly restored for the venue.

-------------------------------------------------
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: SFR Calendar Interface - Update: Group Memberships

Dear Group Administrators of the SFRaves.org Hyperreal Rave Interface
(SFR Calendar Group Administrators) (if applicable)

Please take the time to check your group memberships to ensure that all
applications received have been approved / not approved per the Group
Owner. Should you receive an application request from myself, please note
that it is due to my request in order to better assist you in the
administrative function of the SFR Calendar. Go ahead and add me to your
groups so that I can further enhance my ability to assist you with event
promotions, submissions and edits of the event calendar.

To check your Group Membership,

1. Login to the SFR Calendar interface using a valid account @
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/

User/Pass, Click Login

2. View the Groups Page @
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/groups

3. At the bottom of the Groups page @
http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/groups

Search for your group by entering the Group name in the Search box and
clicking the Search button.

4. Select the name of your group from the list.

5. Under Member Options, click the link following - ADMIN:  membership

6. View the Membership link to see if any new requests have been received.
If new requests have been received, the user's account name will appear.
Please select from the following options: APPROVED/NOT APPROVED and the
GROUP Membership type (2nd dropdown) - with the following options:

OWNER (GROUP ADMIN OWNER)
ADMIN (GROUP ADMIN)
USER (GROUP USER)

- Select the Change button.

7. To delete a user, select the delete button.

If you receive a request from myself to join your group, please click
APPROVE with ADMIN as the Membership type. This way I have the permissions
to assist you with any extracurricular requests to publish event
information, edit event information and perform administrative functions
to your group.

Thank you so kindly and have a great day.

Karina

Subject: [sfraves] Juan

Wow.  What is it that they say; that if you come into something with
high expectations you're usually disappointed???  Well, maybe the fact
that I heard Koroma do his thing before I heard Juan do HIS thing left a
bit of an impression, but I seriously didn't feel that J. A. was putting
much effort forward.  Was Club 6 too small a venue for him??  Was I the
only one who felt this way??  I'd seriously give 70-80% of the folks
I've had on the show better marks than what I heard tonight.

How's that for keeping it real??

SFRaves<-_->http: //www.sfraves.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: localhost.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR News: Proposed Legislation: Military Draft of 2005

Military Draft expected to start June 15, 2005

If there are children in your family, READ this.

There is pending legislation in the House and Senate (twin bills: S 89 and
HR 163) which will time the program's initiation so the draft can begin at
early as Spring 2005 -- just after the 2004 presidential election. The
administration is quietly trying to get these bills passed now, while the
public's attention is on the elections, so our action on this is needed
immediately.

See the following websites to view Bills:
http://www.hslda.org/legislation


Congress brought twin bills, S. 89 and HR 163 forward,entitled the
Universal National Service Act of 2003, "to provide for the common defense
by requiring that all young persons [age 18--26] in the United States,
including women, perform a period of military service or a period of
civilian service in furtherance of the national defense and homeland
security, and for other purposes." These active bills currently sit in the
committee on armed services.

Dodging the draft will be more difficult than those from the Vietnam era.
College and Canada will not be options. In December 2001, Canada and the
U.S. signed a "smart border declaration," which could be used to keep wou
ld-be draft dodgers in. Signed by Canada's minister of foreign aff airs,
John Manley, and U.S. Homeland Security director, Tom Ridge, the
declaration involves a 30-point plan which implements, among other things,
a "pre-clearance agreement" of people entering and departing each country.
Reforms aimed at making the draft more equitable along gender and class
lines also eliminates higher education as a shelter.
Underclassmen would only be able to postpone service until the end of
their current semester. Seniors would have until the end of the academic
year.

This plan, among other things, eliminates higher education as a shelter
and includes women in the draft.

Actions, actions, actions:
Please send this on to all the parents and teachers you know, and all the
aunts and uncles, grandparents, godparents.... And let your children know
- it's their future, and they can be a powerful voice for change!

Please also contact your representatives to ask them! why they aren't
telling their constituents about these bills -- and contact newspapers and
other media outlets to ask them why they're not covering this important
story.

The draft $28 million has been added to the 2004 selective service system
(sss) budget to prepare for a military draft that could start as early as
June 15, 2005. Selective Service must report to Bush on March 31, 2005
that the system, which has lain dormant for decades, is ready for
activation.

Please see website: http://www.sss.gov/perfplan_fy2004.html
to view the sss annual performance plan - fiscal year 2004.

The pentagon has quietly begun a public campaign to fill all 10,350 draft
board positions and 11,070 appeals board slots nationwide. Though this is
an unpopular election year topic, military experts and influential members
of congress are suggesting that if Rumsfeld's prediction of a "long, hard
slog" in Iraq and Afghanistan [and a permanent state of war on
"terrorism"] proves accurate, the U.S. may have no choice but to draft.

http://www.sss.gov/perfplan_fy2004.html


WHAT TO DO:
- Tell all your friends!!!!!
Contact your Senators & Reps and tell them to oppose these bills!!! For
the full list of Senate & House Representatives (53) and websites, go to:
http://www.visi.com/juan/congress/cgi-bin/newseek.cgi?site=ctc&state=ca!

--

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

including women, perform a period of military service or a period of

BOH!

Tonight's another bomb-ass show for y'all, chock full of rediculously phat
drum 'n' bass goodness.  check out the lineup (all times EST of course):

7-8pm - odj & jerel - yer faithful hosts bring the danger, dirtbox style.
expect anything.  well.. anything but anything not drum 'n' bass.  you
know we like the drums and basses.  werd.

8-9:30pm - illEffect - even though he was just on the show last week (for
afterhours) we haven't got completely sick and tired of this guy.  he can
throw down a mean set, complete with bouncy party tracks and turntablism
to boot, so we'll let him hang around for a little bit tonight ;)

9:30-11pm - ransom - the one and only mister harry ransom will be gracing
us with his presence tonight.  harry's a hardcore junglist soldier who's
been holdin it down around DC for FOREVAR!  plus he's a nice guy and he
likes NARUTO!  biggup to him :)

11-??am - AFTERHOURS - you know what happens when the sun goes down (or
comes up)!  dirtbox gets rowdy!

so yeah, tune yer asses in tonight, it'll be good shit as always.  biggup
all the djs on desroyer.net and jungletrain.net.  if you like our shit,
tune in to theirs as well!

Links:

AIM: dirtboxradio

Don't forget to swing by our website sometime for show archives, updated
lineups, profiles of the Kru, photos of stupid shit, and other such stuff.
it's www.dirtboxradio.com in case ya didn't know!

EZ!

-----Original Message-----
Hi All

For information:


June 4, 2004 text version


Reefer Madness: A Live Chat With Eric Schlosser

Live Audio Chat
Tuesday, June 15, 2004
3 PM Eastern/Noon Pacific

Please join me for an online chat about marijuana prohibition with renowned
author Eric Schlosser.

Bookmark this page so that you can join the chat:
http://www.drugpolicy.org/news/schlosser_chat.cfm. We will be answering
questions from listeners like you during the discussion.

If you would like to submit one, please send a message to
questions@drugpolicy.org.

Here's more information about Eric Schlosser and me:

Eric Schlosser is the author of the bestselling Fast Food Nation and Reefer
Madness, and a correspondent for Atlantic Monthly. Reefer Madness chronicles
the beginning of our government's insane war on marijuana users and condemns
the mandatory-minimum sentences that ruin so many lives.

I am the founder and executive director of the Drug Policy Alliance, the
leading organization in the United States promoting alternatives to the "war
on drugs." A professor and author, I founded the organization to advocate
for drug policies grounded in science, compassion, health and human rights.

To submit a question now please send an email to: questions@drugpolicy.org.

Thank You,



http://www.jcthedj.com

ben chun has it too...spun it @ uberzone. :-)

uberzone review: live digital percussion from the one
guy and scratching from the other...berserker madness.


Giles

>On 2004/06/06, at 22:57, Karina wrote:
>
>>Military Draft expected to start June 15, 2005
>>
>>If there are children in your family, READ this.
>>
>>There is pending legislation in the House and Senate (twin bills: S 89
>>and
>>HR 163) which will time the program's initiation so the draft can
>>begin at
>>early as Spring 2005 -- just after the 2004 presidential election. The
>>administration is quietly trying to get these bills passed now, while
>>the
>>public's attention is on the elections, so our action on this is needed
>>immediately.
>>
>>See the following websites to view Bills:
>>http://www.hslda.org/legislation
>>
>>
>>Congress brought twin bills, S. 89 and HR 163 forward,entitled the
>>Universal National Service Act of 2003, "to provide for the common
>>defense
>>by requiring that all young persons [age 18--26] in the United States,
>>including women, perform a period of military service or a period of
>>civilian service in furtherance of the national defense and homeland
>>security, and for other purposes." These active bills currently sit in
>>the
>>committee on armed services.
>>
>>Dodging the draft will be more difficult than those from the Vietnam
>>era.
>>College and Canada will not be options. In December 2001, Canada and
>>the
>>U.S. signed a "smart border declaration," which could be used to keep
>>wou
>>ld-be draft dodgers in. Signed by Canada's minister of foreign aff
>>airs,
>>John Manley, and U.S. Homeland Security director, Tom Ridge, the
>>declaration involves a 30-point plan which implements, among other
>>things,
>>a "pre-clearance agreement" of people entering and departing each
>>country.
>>Reforms aimed at making the draft more equitable along gender and class
>>lines also eliminates higher education as a shelter.
>>Underclassmen would only be able to postpone service until the end of
>>their current semester. Seniors would have until the end of the
>>academic
>>year.
>>
>>This plan, among other things, eliminates higher education as a shelter
>>and includes women in the draft.
>>
>>Actions, actions, actions:
>>Please send this on to all the parents and teachers you know, and all
>>the
>>aunts and uncles, grandparents, godparents.... And let your children
>>know
>>- it's their future, and they can be a powerful voice for change!
>>
>>Please also contact your representatives to ask them! why they aren't
>>telling their constituents about these bills -- and contact newspapers
>>and
>>other media outlets to ask them why they're not covering this important
>>story.
>>
>>The draft $28 million has been added to the 2004 selective service
>>system
>>(sss) budget to prepare for a military draft that could start as early
>>as
>>June 15, 2005. Selective Service must report to Bush on March 31, 2005
>>that the system, which has lain dormant for decades, is ready for
>>activation.
>>
>>Please see website: http://www.sss.gov/perfplan_fy2004.html
>>to view the sss annual performance plan - fiscal year 2004.
>>
>>The pentagon has quietly begun a public campaign to fill all 10,350
>>draft
>>board positions and 11,070 appeals board slots nationwide. Though this
>>is
>>an unpopular election year topic, military experts and influential
>>members
>>of congress are suggesting that if Rumsfeld's prediction of a "long,
>>hard
>>slog" in Iraq and Afghanistan [and a permanent state of war on
>>"terrorism"] proves accurate, the U.S. may have no choice but to draft.
>>
>>http://www.sss.gov/perfplan_fy2004.html
>>
>>
>>WHAT TO DO:
>>- Tell all your friends!!!!!
>>Contact your Senators & Reps and tell them to oppose these bills!!! For
>>the full list of Senate & House Representatives (53) and websites, go
>>to:
>>http://www.visi.com/juan/congress/cgi-bin/newseek.cgi? site=ctc&state=ca!
>>

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

track selection was interesting last night but he doesn't seem to be able 
to build a set and keep the dancers moving.  We left after about an hour 
into his performance.  Jesse, however, just seems to get better and better.

and letting the listeners decide "More GOA or More new psytrance?" - call in 
to vote 415.751.KUSF.

lounge next saturday night with ABSOLUM (((3d Vision records, france)))

peace, trance, and (((THUMP)))!

"hey, ig."
"yeah, supa."
"where were you yesterday?"
"i was writing my book just like everyone else."
"what do you mean?"
"well, ever since you started writing your book, i noticed that there are tons of books everywhere, and then i realized, oh, that is why no one really knows anyone anymore unless they write a book, so i decided, that is what i will do too. "

instead of any live shows, just one of the two has
been DJing here and there.

Skeptical.

Subject: [sfraves] BAILEY @ SOMA Sessions - Fri June 25

SOMA Sessions
Drum 'n Bass Fourth Fridays
AsiaSF, San Francisco, USA
http://www.somasessions.com

SOMA Sessions is San Francisco's premier weekend
Jungle/Drum 'n Bass party.  On every Fourth Friday we
invite leading hand-picked DJ talents from around the
globe to play extended sets in an intimate setting
which forms the idea of the "session"...


Friday June 25, 2004

BAILEY (Metalheadz, Swerve, Breakbeat Science - UK)
Bailey's roots in Drum & Bass stretch back to the
early days of UK pirate radio. A talented DJ whose
taste and selection span all styles of the genre, he
quickly became one of the premier DJs of the D&B
movement. In 1996 he took a residency at Goldie's
renowned Metalheadz night at the legendary Blue Note.
Over the years he has established his own radio show
every Sunday on BBC 1Xtra and joined Fabio's famous
Swerve night in London. A favorite of the San
Francisco scene, if you can't get down to this DJ you
may be dead.

Resident Support:
DJ M
SOUND:BOY


** Discount $8 presale will call tickets available now
at http://www.somasessions.com **

Tickets:  $8 presale
Hours:  10:30pm - 3am
Entry:  21+ with photo ID
Bar:  $3 drink specials all night

Sponsors:
RINSE Magazine [http://rinsemag.com]

Location:
201 Ninth Street at Howard St, San Francisco
Before the show try AsiaSF's 3-Star Cal-Asian cuisine
and nightly performances!  For Sun-Thurs dinner
reservations call 415.255.ASIA(2742) or visit
http://www.asiasf.com.

Ryan @ Citizen-7 [http://www.citizen-7.com]

.because there is another beer festival happening and ol jackie is here with the 411.

What: Belgian Ale Festival
Why: Because us American's can't seem to get it regularly, so why not have a festival and binge!
Where: The Bistro 1001 B St. Hayward Ca. - Starts at noon.
How: Well you can drive or take bart to the Hayward exit (NOT south hayward). The bistro is 2 blocks east on B St.

Why Not?

other ceiling fixtures

Subject: Re: [sfraves] voice software

You mean Stephen *HAW*king?

Erm- I use TextAloud MP3, but there's a bunch out there-

http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&ie=UTF-8&q=%2B%22text+to+speech%22+%2Bfreeware&btnG=Google+Search

An interesting note about Steven Hawking- his text-to-speech stuff is so 
old it's based in hardware.
Apparently it's in need of replacement, but the actual hardware and 
components don't exist anymore and like an analog synthesizer, software 
reproductions just can't capture his "voice" exactly...

Message-ID: <BAY8-DAV34VKi3s1wsX00026c89@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 08 Jun 2004 21:32:01.0145 (UTC) FILETIME=[08D43E90:01C44DA0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] voice software

You need Reader 6.0 or newer,

"View" menu->"Read Aloud"->"This page only"

or

"View" menu->"Read Aloud"->"To end of document"

You must have text-to-speech services installed which means Macintalk Pro in Mac 7.5-9.2,
Text-to-Speech in Mac OS 10.1 or newer and MS Text-to-Speech Agent in Windows ME/2000 (builtin to
XP)

good luck

-=dave

From sfraves-return-113003-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jun 08 23:54:06 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113003-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 43370 invoked by uid 1103); 8 Jun 2004 23:54:04 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 43355 invoked from network); 8 Jun 2004 23:54:04 -0000
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v618)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Message-Id: <1C09A0BE-B9A7-11D8-A10A-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 8 Jun 2004 16:53:58 -0700
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.618)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

This weekend, when I first heard about the protests going on about that 
biotech conference, I was rather inclined to think the protesters were 
a bunch of knuckleheads, who should be ignored more than anything else. 
  They seem to have two main arguements.  First, they argue that 
corporations profit from biotech, therefore it is evil.  *GASP* Horror 
of horrors.... well.... DUH!!!!  Now, I'll be the first to call for the 
heads of everyone at enron, halliburton, microsoft, and the like, to be 
impaled on pikes.  But dammit, it's bad deeds that cause a corporation 
to be "evil", not the act of incorporation itself.  Second is some 
ignorant scaremongering about the dangers of biotech that sound more 
like luddite superstition more than rational scientific discourse.

Today, after seeing what's happening on the streets of San Francisco, 
I'm steadfastly on the side of the protesters.

No doubt the behest of the biotech bigwigs, 'da Mayor has had the pigs 
basically excise a large chunk of SOMA from The City, cutting off all 
access to PUBLIC roads and PUBLIC sidewalks to all except the attendees 
of a conference put on by PRIVATE interests.  And many blocks 
surrounding the Moscone Center look like a bad '80s movie about life 
behind the "iron curtain", they're so swarming with the filth.  Well, 
an "iron curtain" HAS descended upon San Francisco, and it's got "SFPD" 
embroidered on every swatch of cloth.

Just like they went goosestepping through the streets, a year ago, to 
beat people up for having the "wrong" opinion about the war in Iraq, 
the MFers have decided that the conference attendees are too delicate 
to be exposed to the "wrong" opinions, and there are reports of said 
wrongly-opinioned being harassed, arrested, manhandled, and even 
beaten.  The public is being denied access to the roads and sidewalks 
we paid for.  Traffic is a nightmare.  And if you want to walk through 
SOMA, you have to detour around the area that the pigs have decided is 
sacrosanct, suitable to be walked upon only if you're in the biotech 
industry.

Though I may believe that the opinions of the protesters were ignorant 
superstition, they damn well have the right to that opinion, and they 
have the right to let people know they have that opinion, and they 
should not be persecuted for it.  And otherwise uninvolved third 
parties DAMN WELL should NOT be, in any way, hassled, diverted, or 
otherwise inconvenienced by the pigs.  Fucking drop the collective 
punishment, and the "if you're not with us you're against us" bullshit; 
if someone is endangering public safety, deal with that individual, and 
that individual ONLY; and leave the rest of us the fuck alone.  And 
don't shut down a PUBLIC right-of-way because a few of the 
high-and-mighty might find it distasteful to find that average people 
might disagree with them.

Until today, until he allowed, and possibly ordered, his uniformed 
thugs to do these things; I was ALMOST ready to start liking Gavin 
Newsom.  Until today, I was slowly but steadily getting ready to 
believe that he was not the right-wing ogre he appeared to be during 
the campaign; as, until today, he was not really behaving like one.  
Sure, the gay marriage thing was nothing more than a political stunt 
designed to win himself popularity.  He could safely pull it off, 
knowing that the forces of hate and intolerance in this state and this 
country would never allow it to stand.  But hey... anything that gets 
the neo-cons frothing at the mouth like that is A-OK in my book.

Now, I see that he really is nothing more than Willie Brown v2.0, where 
anything goes, any commons can be given away, any peoples rights 
trampled upon, so long as he gets the right payoff.  Pay for play at 
its best.... for four more years.

I'm, right now, looking at pictures of the filth manhandling people, 
roughing them up, ganging up on people, intimidating people, and more.  
The commentary on places like indymedia may be written by a bunch of 
bloody useless loonies, but photos just don't lie.  Bad science, 
specious claims about imaginary dangers, and ignorant technophobic 
superstition piss me off.  Government thugs abusing the power with 
which they were entrusted pisses me off even more.  As bad a taste as 
it would leave in my mouth, I find myself, more and more, feeling that 
I must throw my lot in with those very same indymedia types.  I'd much 
rather lose the latest and greatest biotech niftiness than lose my 
right, however malformed my opinion might be, to speak my mind, or 
simply to walk down the sidewalk and meet a friend for lunch (Which I 
had to flake on because of the SFPD swine.).

To hell with biotech.  To hell with the mayor.  And to hell with the 
police.


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Originating-IP: [206.169.32.152]

From: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
To: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>,
	"John B." <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
References: <1C09A0BE-B9A7-11D8-A10A-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 8 Jun 2004 17:08:15 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV21vvivL4MvA00078562@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 09 Jun 2004 00:06:19.0639 (UTC) FILETIME=[97525070:01C44DB5]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

I see it like this - the protestors are an annoyance and a financial
liability. If I was having an event that was going to be targeted by a bunch
of protesters you can damn well bet I would call on the city to do
somemthing about it. Last thing I would want would be for my attendees to
get harassed at the conference. The other problem is you just don't know
what protesters are going to pull these days. Because of that police forces
are acting like assholes because they expect the worst. Think about last
year when idiots decided it was a good idea to storm the bay bridge. That's
a huge problem and a bigger safety concern. The actions of such protesters
are still fresh in the minds of local authority.

What you're seeing is a zero tollerance policy. It's like the parents that
are finally getting tough on their wild kids. SF is cracking down on its
wild protestors. The way I see it the protestors are in the way. They're
costing someone money. They're a liability. Liability has to be eliminated.

:: r ::

> Until today, until he allowed, and possibly ordered, his uniformed
> thugs to do these things; I was ALMOST ready to start liking Gavin
> Newsom.  Until today, I was slowly but steadily getting ready to
> believe that he was not the right-wing ogre he appeared to be during
> the campaign; as, until today, he was not really behaving like one.
> Sure, the gay marriage thing was nothing more than a political stunt
> designed to win himself popularity.  He could safely pull it off,
> knowing that the forces of hate and intolerance in this state and this
> country would never allow it to stand.  But hey... anything that gets
> the neo-cons frothing at the mouth like that is A-OK in my book.
>
> Now, I see that he really is nothing more than Willie Brown v2.0, where
> anything goes, any commons can be given away, any peoples rights
> trampled upon, so long as he gets the right payoff.  Pay for play at
> its best.... for four more years.
>
> I'm, right now, looking at pictures of the filth manhandling people,
> roughing them up, ganging up on people, intimidating people, and more.
> The commentary on places like indymedia may be written by a bunch of
> bloody useless loonies, but photos just don't lie.  Bad science,
> specious claims about imaginary dangers, and ignorant technophobic
> superstition piss me off.  Government thugs abusing the power with
> which they were entrusted pisses me off even more.  As bad a taste as
> it would leave in my mouth, I find myself, more and more, feeling that
> I must throw my lot in with those very same indymedia types.  I'd much
> rather lose the latest and greatest biotech niftiness than lose my
> right, however malformed my opinion might be, to speak my mind, or
> simply to walk down the sidewalk and meet a friend for lunch (Which I
> had to flake on because of the SFPD swine.).
>
> To hell with biotech.  To hell with the mayor.  And to hell with the
> police.
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

--- "John B." <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com> wrote:
> This weekend, when I first heard about the protests going on
> about that 
> biotech conference, I was rather inclined to think the
> protesters were 
> a bunch of knuckleheads, who should be ignored more than
> anything else. 
>   They seem to have two main arguements.  First, they argue
> that 
> corporations profit from biotech, therefore it is evil. 
> *GASP* Horror 
> of horrors.... well.... DUH!!!!  Now, I'll be the first to
> call for the 
> heads of everyone at enron, halliburton, microsoft, and the
> like, to be 
> impaled on pikes.  But dammit, it's bad deeds that cause a
> corporation 
> to be "evil", not the act of incorporation itself.  Second is
> some 
> ignorant scaremongering about the dangers of biotech that
> sound more 
> like luddite superstition more than rational scientific
> discourse.

> got "SFPD" 
> embroidered on every swatch of cloth.

> delicate

> of said 
> wrongly-opinioned being harassed, arrested, manhandled, and
> even 
> beaten.  The public is being denied access to the roads and
> sidewalks 
> we paid for.  Traffic is a nightmare.  And if you want to

> sacrosanct, suitable to be walked upon only if you're in the

> industry.

I see it like this - the protestors are an annoyance and a financial
liability. If I was having an event that was going to be targeted by a =
bunch
of protesters you can damn well bet I would call on the city to do
somemthing about it. Last thing I would want would be for my attendees =
to
get harassed at the conference. The other problem is you just don't know
what protesters are going to pull these days. Because of that police =
forces
are acting like assholes because they expect the worst. Think about last
year when idiots decided it was a good idea to storm the bay bridge. =
That's
a huge problem and a bigger safety concern. The actions of such =
protesters
are still fresh in the minds of local authority.

What you're seeing is a zero tollerance policy. It's like the parents =
that
are finally getting tough on their wild kids. SF is cracking down on its
wild protestors. The way I see it the protestors are in the way. They're
costing someone money. They're a liability. Liability has to be =
eliminated.

In-Reply-To: <BAY9-DAV21vvivL4MvA00078562@hotmail.com>
References: <1C09A0BE-B9A7-11D8-A10A-00050209EDF8@yahoo.com> <BAY9-DAV21vvivL4MvA00078562@hotmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v618)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Cc: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 8 Jun 2004 17:20:49 -0700
To: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.618)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

Even if one accepts that line of reasoning though, it doesn't justify 
their harassment, and lumping in with the protesters, of otherwise 
uninvolved third parties.  And it doesn't justify the theft of public 
spaces from the public.

Moreover, I don't really accept said reasoning, in the first place.  No 
one has the RIGHT to make a profit.  You may have the right to TRY, but 
government should not be in the business of guaranteeing success.  And 
if the fact that people don't like your line of business creates a 
"financial liability", then too damn bad.  Be profitable enough to 
disregard said liability, deal with their concerns, or find another 
business model.  People DO, however, have the right to free speech and 
peaceful assembly.

Yes, if violence DOES break out, arrest the perpetrators of said 
violence.  But leave everyone who is not fighting, or destroying shit, 
or whatever, alone!


cya,
john

>> wrongly-opinioned being harassed, arrested, manhandled, and even
>> beaten.  The public is being denied access to the roads and sidewalks
>> we paid for.  Traffic is a nightmare.  And if you want to walk through
>> SOMA, you have to detour around the area that the pigs have decided is
>> sacrosanct, suitable to be walked upon only if you're in the biotech
>> industry.
>>
>> Though I may believe that the opinions of the protesters were ignorant
>> superstition, they damn well have the right to that opinion, and they
>> have the right to let people know they have that opinion, and they
>> should not be persecuted for it.  And otherwise uninvolved third
>> parties DAMN WELL should NOT be, in any way, hassled, diverted, or
>> otherwise inconvenienced by the pigs.  Fucking drop the collective
>> punishment, and the "if you're not with us you're against us" 
>> bullshit;
>> if someone is endangering public safety, deal with that individual, 
>> and
>> that individual ONLY; and leave the rest of us the fuck alone.  And
>> don't shut down a PUBLIC right-of-way because a few of the
>> high-and-mighty might find it distasteful to find that average people
>> might disagree with them.
>>
>> Until today, until he allowed, and possibly ordered, his uniformed
>> thugs to do these things; I was ALMOST ready to start liking Gavin
>> Newsom.  Until today, I was slowly but steadily getting ready to
>> believe that he was not the right-wing ogre he appeared to be during
>> the campaign; as, until today, he was not really behaving like one.
>> Sure, the gay marriage thing was nothing more than a political stunt
>> designed to win himself popularity.  He could safely pull it off,
>> knowing that the forces of hate and intolerance in this state and this
>> country would never allow it to stand.  But hey... anything that gets
>> the neo-cons frothing at the mouth like that is A-OK in my book.
>>
>> Now, I see that he really is nothing more than Willie Brown v2.0, 
>> where
>> anything goes, any commons can be given away, any peoples rights
>> trampled upon, so long as he gets the right payoff.  Pay for play at
>> its best.... for four more years.
>>
>> I'm, right now, looking at pictures of the filth manhandling people,
>> roughing them up, ganging up on people, intimidating people, and more.
>> The commentary on places like indymedia may be written by a bunch of
>> bloody useless loonies, but photos just don't lie.  Bad science,
>> specious claims about imaginary dangers, and ignorant technophobic
>> superstition piss me off.  Government thugs abusing the power with
>> which they were entrusted pisses me off even more.  As bad a taste as
>> it would leave in my mouth, I find myself, more and more, feeling that
>> I must throw my lot in with those very same indymedia types.  I'd much
>> rather lose the latest and greatest biotech niftiness than lose my
>> right, however malformed my opinion might be, to speak my mind, or
>> simply to walk down the sidewalk and meet a friend for lunch (Which I
>> had to flake on because of the SFPD swine.).
>>
>> To hell with biotech.  To hell with the mayor.  And to hell with the
>> police.

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>

One thing you can't forget is that a large conference brings in lots of
money to the city, it's in the mayor's and the city taxpayers best interest

-----Original Message-----
From: innocentchild [mailto:innocentchild@hotmail.com]
Sent: Tuesday, June 08, 2004 5:08 PM
To: SFRaves; John B.
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t


I see it like this - the protestors are an annoyance and a financial
liability. If I was having an event that was going to be targeted by a bunch
of protesters you can damn well bet I would call on the city to do
somemthing about it. Last thing I would want would be for my attendees to
get harassed at the conference. The other problem is you just don't know
what protesters are going to pull these days. Because of that police forces
are acting like assholes because they expect the worst. Think about last
year when idiots decided it was a good idea to storm the bay bridge. That's
a huge problem and a bigger safety concern. The actions of such protesters
are still fresh in the minds of local authority.

What you're seeing is a zero tollerance policy. It's like the parents that
are finally getting tough on their wild kids. SF is cracking down on its
wild protestors. The way I see it the protestors are in the way. They're
costing someone money. They're a liability. Liability has to be eliminated.

:: r ::

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "John B." <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
To: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Tuesday, June 08, 2004 4:53 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t


> This weekend, when I first heard about the protests going on about that
> biotech conference, I was rather inclined to think the protesters were
> a bunch of knuckleheads, who should be ignored more than anything else.
>   They seem to have two main arguements.  First, they argue that
> corporations profit from biotech, therefore it is evil.  *GASP* Horror
> of horrors.... well.... DUH!!!!  Now, I'll be the first to call for the
> heads of everyone at enron, halliburton, microsoft, and the like, to be
> impaled on pikes.  But dammit, it's bad deeds that cause a corporation
> to be "evil", not the act of incorporation itself.  Second is some
> ignorant scaremongering about the dangers of biotech that sound more
> like luddite superstition more than rational scientific discourse.
>
> Today, after seeing what's happening on the streets of San Francisco,
> I'm steadfastly on the side of the protesters.
>
> No doubt the behest of the biotech bigwigs, 'da Mayor has had the pigs
> basically excise a large chunk of SOMA from The City, cutting off all
> access to PUBLIC roads and PUBLIC sidewalks to all except the attendees
> of a conference put on by PRIVATE interests.  And many blocks
> surrounding the Moscone Center look like a bad '80s movie about life
> behind the "iron curtain", they're so swarming with the filth.  Well,
> an "iron curtain" HAS descended upon San Francisco, and it's got "SFPD"
> embroidered on every swatch of cloth.
>
> Just like they went goosestepping through the streets, a year ago, to
> beat people up for having the "wrong" opinion about the war in Iraq,
> the MFers have decided that the conference attendees are too delicate
> to be exposed to the "wrong" opinions, and there are reports of said
> wrongly-opinioned being harassed, arrested, manhandled, and even
> beaten.  The public is being denied access to the roads and sidewalks
> we paid for.  Traffic is a nightmare.  And if you want to walk through
> SOMA, you have to detour around the area that the pigs have decided is
> sacrosanct, suitable to be walked upon only if you're in the biotech
> industry.
>
> Though I may believe that the opinions of the protesters were ignorant
> superstition, they damn well have the right to that opinion, and they
> have the right to let people know they have that opinion, and they
> should not be persecuted for it.  And otherwise uninvolved third
> parties DAMN WELL should NOT be, in any way, hassled, diverted, or
> otherwise inconvenienced by the pigs.  Fucking drop the collective
> punishment, and the "if you're not with us you're against us" bullshit;
> if someone is endangering public safety, deal with that individual, and
> that individual ONLY; and leave the rest of us the fuck alone.  And
> don't shut down a PUBLIC right-of-way because a few of the
> high-and-mighty might find it distasteful to find that average people
> might disagree with them.
>
> Until today, until he allowed, and possibly ordered, his uniformed
> thugs to do these things; I was ALMOST ready to start liking Gavin
> Newsom.  Until today, I was slowly but steadily getting ready to
> believe that he was not the right-wing ogre he appeared to be during
> the campaign; as, until today, he was not really behaving like one.
> Sure, the gay marriage thing was nothing more than a political stunt
> designed to win himself popularity.  He could safely pull it off,
> knowing that the forces of hate and intolerance in this state and this
> country would never allow it to stand.  But hey... anything that gets
> the neo-cons frothing at the mouth like that is A-OK in my book.
>
> Now, I see that he really is nothing more than Willie Brown v2.0, where
> anything goes, any commons can be given away, any peoples rights
> trampled upon, so long as he gets the right payoff.  Pay for play at
> its best.... for four more years.
>
> I'm, right now, looking at pictures of the filth manhandling people,
> roughing them up, ganging up on people, intimidating people, and more.
> The commentary on places like indymedia may be written by a bunch of
> bloody useless loonies, but photos just don't lie.  Bad science,
> specious claims about imaginary dangers, and ignorant technophobic
> superstition piss me off.  Government thugs abusing the power with
> which they were entrusted pisses me off even more.  As bad a taste as

>>>> the MFers have decided that the conference attendees are too  
>>>> delicate
>>>> to be exposed to the "wrong" opinions, and there are reports of said
>>>> wrongly-opinioned being harassed, arrested, manhandled, and even
>>>> beaten.  The public is being denied access to the roads and  
>>>> sidewalks
>>>> we paid for.  Traffic is a nightmare.  And if you want to walk  
>>>> through
>>>> SOMA, you have to detour around the area that the pigs have decided  
>>>> is
>>>> sacrosanct, suitable to be walked upon only if you're in the biotech
>>>> industry.
>>>>
>>>> Though I may believe that the opinions of the protesters were  
>>>> ignorant
>>>> superstition, they damn well have the right to that opinion, and  
>>>> they
>>>> have the right to let people know they have that opinion, and they
>>>> should not be persecuted for it.  And otherwise uninvolved third
>>>> parties DAMN WELL should NOT be, in any way, hassled, diverted, or
>>>> otherwise inconvenienced by the pigs.  Fucking drop the collective
>>>> punishment, and the "if you're not with us you're against us"
>>>> bullshit;
>>>> if someone is endangering public safety, deal with that individual,
>>>> and
>>>> that individual ONLY; and leave the rest of us the fuck alone.  And
>>>> don't shut down a PUBLIC right-of-way because a few of the
>>>> high-and-mighty might find it distasteful to find that average  
>>>> people
>>>> might disagree with them.
>>>>
>>>> Until today, until he allowed, and possibly ordered, his uniformed
>>>> thugs to do these things; I was ALMOST ready to start liking Gavin
>>>> Newsom.  Until today, I was slowly but steadily getting ready to
>>>> believe that he was not the right-wing ogre he appeared to be during
>>>> the campaign; as, until today, he was not really behaving like one.
>>>> Sure, the gay marriage thing was nothing more than a political stunt
>>>> designed to win himself popularity.  He could safely pull it off,
>>>> knowing that the forces of hate and intolerance in this state and  
>>>> this
>>>> country would never allow it to stand.  But hey... anything that  
>>>> gets
>>>> the neo-cons frothing at the mouth like that is A-OK in my book.
>>>>
>>>> Now, I see that he really is nothing more than Willie Brown v2.0,
>>>> where
>>>> anything goes, any commons can be given away, any peoples rights
>>>> trampled upon, so long as he gets the right payoff.  Pay for play at
>>>> its best.... for four more years.
>>>>
>>>> I'm, right now, looking at pictures of the filth manhandling people,
>>>> roughing them up, ganging up on people, intimidating people, and  
>>>> more.
>>>> The commentary on places like indymedia may be written by a bunch of
>>>> bloody useless loonies, but photos just don't lie.  Bad science,
>>>> specious claims about imaginary dangers, and ignorant technophobic
>>>> superstition piss me off.  Government thugs abusing the power with
>>>> which they were entrusted pisses me off even more.  As bad a taste  
>>>> as
>>>> it would leave in my mouth, I find myself, more and more, feeling  
>>>> that
>>>> I must throw my lot in with those very same indymedia types.  I'd  
>>>> much
>>>> rather lose the latest and greatest biotech niftiness than lose my
>>>> right, however malformed my opinion might be, to speak my mind, or
>>>> simply to walk down the sidewalk and meet a friend for lunch (Which  
>>>> I
>>>> had to flake on because of the SFPD swine.).
>>>>
>>>> To hell with biotech.  To hell with the mayor.  And to hell with the
>>>> police.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

What does the way anyone looks have to do with the price of tea in china???

The point is this - the protestors have been on TV for DAYS talking about
how THEY wanted to "shut down the city", hence the COPS coming out in full
force.

Now, I'm not saying police being abusive is right by ANY means, but when you
are outnumbered by 10 to 1 or whatever, you tend to be a little more on the
aggro tip. Something like that could go HORRIBLY wrong in mere moments.

Personally, I don't like cops, but I understand a lot of the reasons they
act the way they do, and you really ought to take that into consideration
before you spout off about how the city and local government are trying to
fuck you over. If you're pissed about the city being shut down - look to
those who wanted it that way. If it weren't for them - that area wouldn't be
blockaded. It really is that simple.

M-

Sorry to add to the pile of NRR crap on here...  but I got a big time problem and I'm guessing that this is the list to ask this question on...
 
During a server reboot this afternoon I had a seagate cheetah (10,000 rpm, 80 pin) drive DIE on me... while the server was on!  Needless to say I'm fucked.  If I take all the other drives off the bus the host adapter will ID it... but if i put everything back in the box and turn it on... it shuts itself off about halfway through the win2k bootup with a nice loud click that you can hear all the way across the house.  So its pretty much toast.  Normally I wouldn't care except this is the fastest drive I own and consequently...  all of my music stuff was on there as was a good bit of my "day job" crap.  
 
So I'm wondering what experience you guys have had with those data recovery type places and which ones you would recommend.  If I have to come up with a couple grand to get my data off this thing then I'll sell a kidney or something...  I just need to get it back asap...  so can anybody recommend a particular company or share your experiences with me?

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

--0-382846974-1086750543=:33244
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Now I wasn't there today so I cannot comment on the action of the police. I can however comment as a person who is employed in biotech. One of the reasons that there was such a huge police force and security measures at this conference is because biotechs have been getting bombed lately. Certain radical groups no longer are concerned with the safety of people working in biotech, they are only concerned with their personal agenda. I am personally happy that there were safety precautions taken to avoid violence around this event even if it did inconvenience the city. 

"michael, the red stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com> wrote:to hell with biotech?

then you're fucking all of the patients who are receiving all
of the oncological drugs we're making. fucking all of the
people who are alive today because of recombinant technology.

it's more like, to hell with the violent and radical protesters
who have ruined peaceful protests for everyone.

m

--- "John B." wrote:
> This weekend, when I first heard about the protests going on
> about that 
> biotech conference, I was rather inclined to think the
> protesters were 
> a bunch of knuckleheads, who should be ignored more than
> anything else.

> that 
> corporations profit from biotech, therefore it is evil. 
> *GASP* Horror 
> of horrors.... well.... DUH!!!! Now, I'll be the first to
> call for the 
> heads of everyone at enron, halliburton, microsoft, and the
> like, to be 
> impaled on pikes. But dammit, it's bad deeds that cause a
> corporation 
> to be "evil", not the act of incorporation itself. Second is
> some 
> ignorant scaremongering about the dangers of biotech that
> sound more 
> like luddite superstition more than rational scientific
> discourse.
>

> Francisco, 
> I'm steadfastly on the side of the protesters.
>

> the pigs 
> basically excise a large chunk of SOMA from The City, cutting
> off all 
> access to PUBLIC roads and PUBLIC sidewalks to all except the
> attendees 
> of a conference put on by PRIVATE interests. And many blocks
> 
> surrounding the Moscone Center look like a bad '80s movie
> about life 
> behind the "iron curtain", they're so swarming with the
> filth. Well, 
> an "iron curtain" HAS descended upon San Francisco, and it's
> got "SFPD" 
> embroidered on every swatch of cloth.
> 
> Just like they went goosestepping through the streets, a year
> ago, to 
> beat people up for having the "wrong" opinion about the war
> in Iraq, 
> the MFers have decided that the conference attendees are too
> delicate 
> to be exposed to the "wrong" opinions, and there are reports
> of said 
> wrongly-opinioned being harassed, arrested, manhandled, and
> even 
> beaten. The public is being denied access to the roads and
> sidewalks 
> we paid for. Traffic is a nightmare. And if you want to
> walk through 
> SOMA, you have to detour around the area that the pigs have
> decided is 
> sacrosanct, suitable to be walked upon only if you're in the
> biotech 
> industry.
> 
> Though I may believe that the opinions of the protesters were
> ignorant 
> superstition, they damn well have the right to that opinion,
> and they 
> have the right to let people know they have that opinion, and
> they 
> should not be persecuted for it. And otherwise uninvolved
> third 
> parties DAMN WELL should NOT be, in any way, hassled,
> diverted, or 
> otherwise inconvenienced by the pigs. Fucking drop the
> collective 
> punishment, and the "if you're not with us you're against us"
> bullshit; 
> if someone is endangering public safety, deal with that
> individual, and 
> that individual ONLY; and leave the rest of us the fuck
> alone. And 
> don't shut down a PUBLIC right-of-way because a few of the 
> high-and-mighty might find it distasteful to find that
> average people 
> might disagree with them.
> 
> Until today, until he allowed, and possibly ordered, his
> uniformed 
> thugs to do these things; I was ALMOST ready to start liking
> Gavin 
> Newsom. Until today, I was slowly but steadily getting ready
> to 
> believe that he was not the right-wing ogre he appeared to be
> during 
> the campaign; as, until today, he was not really behaving
> like one. 
> Sure, the gay marriage thing was nothing more than a
> political stunt 
> designed to win himself popularity. He could safely pull it
> off, 
> knowing that the forces of hate and intolerance in this state
> and this 
> country would never allow it to stand. But hey... anything
> that gets 
> the neo-cons frothing at the mouth like that is A-OK in my
> book.
> 
> Now, I see that he really is nothing more than Willie Brown
> v2.0, where 
> anything goes, any commons can be given away, any peoples
> rights 
> trampled upon, so long as he gets the right payoff. Pay for
> play at 
> its best.... for four more years.
> 
> I'm, right now, looking at pictures of the filth manhandling
> people, 
> roughing them up, ganging up on people, intimidating people,
> and more. 
> The commentary on places like indymedia may be written by a
> bunch of 
> bloody useless loonies, but photos just don't lie. Bad
> science, 
> specious claims about imaginary dangers, and ignorant
> technophobic 
> superstition piss me off. Government thugs abusing the power
> with 
> which they were entrusted pisses me off even more. As bad a
> taste as 
> it would leave in my mouth, I find myself, more and more,
> feeling that 
> I must throw my lot in with those very same indymedia types. 
> I'd much 
> rather lose the latest and greatest biotech niftiness than
> lose my 
> right, however malformed my opinion might be, to speak my
> mind, or 
> simply to walk down the sidewalk and meet a friend for lunch

> had to flake on because of the SFPD swine.).
> 
> To hell with biotech. To hell with the mayor. And to hell
> with the 
> police.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Political electronica?

Lawgiverz (breaks DJ/producers) opened up a mix CD
last year with a George Bush speech "remixed" by
somebody from Warp Records. The mix CD isn't available
in the States, but if you ask around I'm sure somebody
was quick enough on the uptake to download the Bush
MP3 from the Warp site before they pulled it down.
They just chopped up the vocal so it has Bush saying
things like "Trusting in the sanity and restraint of
the United States is not an option" etc.

I even heard that there's a record out there which
features that modified speech pressed to vinyl, along
with another funny vocal thing and a couple excellent
breaks trax, one of them a nice bootleg. It's just a
rumor though. Probably not true.


Giles

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1409
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1409
Message-ID: <BAY8-DAV20rfDzNtjLv00027980@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 09 Jun 2004 04:40:00.0393 (UTC) FILETIME=[D2DA8790:01C44DDB]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Hard drive failure help...

only luck i've had with problems like that is by physically taking the exact same drive model and swapping the controller board, and
hoping that the controller's hard error map is minimal and hopefully lands on rarely used blocks.

steps you can try if you don't have another drive controller to swap with:

-remove all other drives off the scsi bus that it's on
-hard set the negotiation on the bus to a non-"Fast" rate
-ensure the LVD terminator is at the last connector of the cable to the backplane (replace if not.)
-place drive in a different slot of the backplane (tolerances in the cheaper chassis are not that great to begin with.)
-swap cable to the backplane with known good cable
-if the drive has a difficult time spinning up, while holding the drive from the top, manually give the entire drive (with cables
attached) a spin with your wrist in the direction of rotation just as it tries to start, then abruptly spinning the other direction,
then backing off slowly at the end of the backspin (hard to explain, but you get the idea.)
-if using a shitty SCSI3-to-SCA adapter, go shoot yourself in the head and be thankful it lasted as long as it did :P
-pay your web hosting bill ;)

good luck man !

ps- if anybody out there has a 36GB IBM DRHS with SCSI3 interface, i would *KILL* if i could borrow it in order to slurp 30GB of
less-traded MP3s and OGGs from 2002-2003 off a drive those controller board pysically got shorted against an adjacent drive case
(dooh !)

-=dave

be.

DNA and how we're creating a new world while the one we live in has been

of gods but not accepting the responsibility of one. Really good track.

Subject: re: [sfraves] Skills 1999 sat. /1998 fri.

The story goes like this...

"1999" party is planned where the F-8 and Skills folks play music only
from the "1999 era" (i.e., 1998 thru 2000).

"1999" sells out.

"1998" party is planned with the same DJs in the same spot the day before.
 Same "1999 era" theme, only now maybe it'll be music from 1997 thru 1999,
LOL.

There was enough music released over those years for the DJs to play
different material each night.  Doesn't mean, though, that the sycophants
who attend BOTH parties won't hear some percentage of redundant tuneage. 
Of course, anyone who goes to both events probably doesn't care if they
hear "Imagine" or "Synaethesia" 14 times over the course of the weekend. 
Poor souls.  LOL.  ;-)

C.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Political electronica?

Coldcut had some subtle politicism in a few of their tracks like "Atomic
Moog 2000" and "Timber," and more overt politics in tunes like "Every Home
a Prison," on which Jello Biafra did some spoken-word stuff.

C.

> You could also go back into the Orbital catalog... "Choice" has the

> additional spicy rhetoric.

Everytime there is any talk of a protest, there is always at least 5 news
helicopters hovering above the city.  I mean, if I am a protester, the 
helicopter cameras are almost *daring* me to put on a show for them...

-troy

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

I blame the media too, but for a different reason.
Genetically modified food is a serious political issue
in Europe and England, in some places it's second only
in terms of popular concern to the invasion of Iraq.
Over here it's like thirty-forth on the list, after
what flavor of low-carb milkshake some chick from
American Idol prefers.

(Damn that political electronica thread...! Whoever
you are, you got me going now...)

Anyway...I also blame the protestors...for being LAME
boring wankers...in the EU they have protestors with
actual balls, and brains to boot...they've been
destroying entire fields full of genetically modified
crops...they got caught in England and after massive
protests in favor of the protestors who were caught,
the judge let them off, saying destroying GM crops was
in the public interest. I shit you not...

Anyway, GMO is bad, and protesting without knowing
what the fuck you're talking about is also bad.

If you want to make scientists look bad in the media,
acting stupid is not the way to do it.


Giles

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

No one "dares" protestors to act like idiots.

Speaking of the news though - I saw a snippet last night where one of the
Biotech attendees got street interviewed. He said something to the effect
of - it's so funny how misguided these people are. Most have no idea what
the Biotech industry is really about. I can't tell you how many protestors
I've seen wearing something as simple as prescription glasses that were
almost certainly improved by the Biotech industry somewhere along the line.

Not an exact quote mind you - but you get the jist. I'm not saying big
industry doesn't do a lot of shady shit - but trying to make safer food to
eat, and easier/more effective ways to improve peoples health is HARDLY
evil.

If people want everything so natural - why do they wear clothes made from
factories, or use anything that isn't 100% natural? Hypocrisy at it's very
finest.

Reminds me of the vegan punk rockers that used to harass me at shows back in
the day about eating meat - all the while sporting leather shoes. MORONS.

M-

From: georgeC <newstylesound@yahoo.com>

  Giles Bowkizzo <gilesbowkizzo@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <40C7AA8B.1020908@scosol.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

Well, I'd have to say, "nature" is, at this point, a loooong way ahead
of us as far as genetics goes.  Genetically modifying something with a
totally clear picture of what's going to happen, and no nasty side
effects- now that'll be cool.  I don't think we're quite there yet.

Plus, it seems like Monsanto et al is more interested in big $$$ and
attempting to quash the truth about these f'ed up crops than in the
impact they seem to be having.  Some of these experiments bear good
fruit, pardon the pun, but there have been some famous failures that
were happily sold to the public- and some of them have helped to edge
their natural variants out of existance, or close to it.

Organic stuff tastes a hell of a lot better anyhow :)

Someday I hope they crack the Cannibis genome..  Imagine what we could
do then... ;)

-G

I just wanna say thanx to everybody that sent me suggestions for my lil problem.
 
I got a good number of suggestions of putting the thing in the freezer overnight...  so i did...  at first it didnt boot but one of the emails suggested turning it over etc... so eventually i would up putting it upside down cocked at a 45 degree angle and sure enough it fired up and sped along like a bat out of hell.  Only took a couple of minutes to copy the entire 36 gigs.  So whatever the problem was the freezer thing fixed it!
 
So umm thanx guys... you saved me a grip of cash (and probably an organ or two =).
 
Keep it wet & hard...
XXX,
p a t

--0-773135723-1086833649=:404--

In a message dated 6/9/2004 8:12:57 PM Pacific Daylight Time,  
SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com writes:

Seeing  as I'm fairly sure that these are both for-profit parties, and  
not  benefits, it would be entirely inappropriate, IMO, for them to play   
Imagine.  And such pretense on their part would leave quite the  sour  
taste in my mouth.


I also associate "Imagine" with benefits such as Unity parties (forever  
among my top 10 parties); however, the fact is, it was a very popular song  around 
1999 and was played at many parties during that time. It was almost a  cliche 
that if Mars closed a Home Base massive, he would play Imagine and they  
would turn the lights on. He'd dance around in the audience. It was a great way  
to close a party, with everybody seeing each other in the light for the first  
time, and enjoying one final song as a community before heading back to the  
outside world.
 
So, really, it would be incredibly appropriate to play "Imagine." The real  
enemy isn't people who want to play the song, it's people who would have it  
banned. I'm talking about how Clear Channel Communications sent out a list of  
songs its stations couldn't play after Sept. 11 2001, and "Imagine" was one of  
the songs (the John Lennon original).. 
 
I'm going to 1999 and am looking forward to seeing a lot of old  friends.

-------------------------------1086847595--

Received: (qmail 91632 invoked from network); 10 Jun 2004 17:50:57 -0000
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v618)
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-DAV22bqV0tpw4S0008217f@hotmail.com>
References: <20040610003509.22899.qmail@web60309.mail.yahoo.com> <BAY9-DAV22bqV0tpw4S0008217f@hotmail.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Message-Id: <B7C9B084-BB06-11D8-B219-0003937E2222@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: Philip.X.Diaz <st_indigo@earthlink.net>
Date: Thu, 10 Jun 2004 10:50:53 -0700
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.618)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Biotech Bullsh*t

Blind faith in technology has lead us up the creek before, and I think 
that rather than being against all biotech (which would be ridiculous), 
the protests are more to do with how biotech crops, products, 
medicines, etc. are pushed on the public with increasingly less 
oversight and testing. Faith in our technology combined with inadequate 
testing has given us such Great Things as Thialomide, MTBE, leaded 
gasoline, and DDT, just to name a few.

sure, some of the protesters have their heads up their asses, but i 
think there's a good argument to be made for more testing and 
oversight.  sadly nowadays, a big stink (blocking traffic, for one) has 
to be made before anyone notices - unless, of course, you have a 
multi-million $ advertising and PR budget.

the bottom line is that we can't trust corporations to police 
themselves, and there needs to be more accountability and testing 
before the products of this powerful technology should be released. the 
biotech convention is a perfect place to bring these issues to light.  
It sucks that it's inconvenient for people living/working downtown, but 
it's our responsibility as citizens of this country to protest and 
speak up when necessary.

-Philip-


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

"that's great, ig, the title of your book."
"glad you like it, supa. what is the title of your book?"
"i don't know yet. i was hoping that it would be universally understood, but then, i realized that while it is possible to be universally understood, it would be impossible to stop the influx of social disease to follow. social disease is, afterall, also a means of self-expression, and also, a basic human right."

Philip.X.Diaz wrote:
 > Blind faith in technology has lead us up the creek before, and I =
think
 > that rather than being against all biotech (which would be =
ridiculous),
 > the protests are more to do with how biotech crops, products, =
medicines,
 > etc. are pushed on the public with increasingly less oversight and
 > testing. Faith in our technology combined with inadequate testing has
 > given us such Great Things as Thialomide, MTBE, leaded gasoline, and
 > DDT, just to name a few.

True enough- there have certainly been some testing-oversights- but I'm=20
afraid that as development speeds up, things will just get bogged down.
There's an entire industry today wrapped around getting new drugs to=20
people because the FDA's procedures take so ridiculously long.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Skills 1999 sat. /1998 fri.

the 'vs' thing is a matter of technicalities i do believe.  to start, mars
actually doesn't play the bay too often anymore.  when he does, its
primarily at the f8 or skills parties and he and mystre have different
timeslots.  i don't think they've done a 'vs' - meaning both of them
spinning the same timeslot on the same decks since the "mystre is returning
from europe" (or wherever he went a few years back) party.

element
http://www.modifiedproductions.com
