Message-Id: <33F9E858-BE9A-11D8-9E6C-000A95A4FAE2@sbcglobal.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: Josh Wolf <inthecity@sbcglobal.net>
Date: Tue, 15 Jun 2004 00:04:11 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.618)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Bio-Tech and Reclaim the Streets...

I just got around to reading the discourse on the list about the 
bio-tech protests, and I can't really say that I agree with what I 
heard -- I was one of the protester's after all -- but I totally 
understand the sentiment I sensed regarding the biotech industry. For 
me, it's not a matter of Bio-Tech being bad -- but a matter of adequate 
safety measures being implemented. Bio-Tech is a new field of science 
that has potential to cause significant ecological destruction. Sure, 
it has potential to make certain diseases obsolete, and in some wacked 
out world-view could eventually solve world-hunger -- but these are 
only possibilities. It has the REAL ability to destroy entire plant 
species through Terminator Technologies, and it has the REAL ability to 
bring about drug treatments that prove dangerous to human populations 
as has been proven the case regarding GMO Insulin.

As we live in a capitalist system, it is the corporation's vested 
interest to get these products out as quickly and cheaply as possible, 
and additional testing cuts into profit margins, slows down the 
products introduction to the market, and risks further development 
costs should the product be proven unsafe. It's like in Fight Club, If 
the cost of the recall is greater than the projected costs to settle 
lawsuits they don't do one.

It was not so much biotechnology that I was protesting this first week 
of June as I was protesting the corporate power behind the 
biotechnology industry. I've always been in support of new and emerging 
science, but I also hold the sentiment that money and wealth can result 
in devastating consequences. If Hearst can start a war by publishing a 
newspaper, what makes you so sure an unchecked biotech company wont 
bring about ecological destruction of epic proportions. I'm not saying 
it will, I'm just saying it could.

On another note, most of the arrests happened at Reclaim the Streets, a 
party held not to protest bio-tech but to celebrate our human right to 
dance where we want, how we want, and when we want and without permits. 
Reclaim the Streets is in protest of such legislation as the RAVE ACT 
and it seems that we as a rave community should show our support for 
myself and the other protests at the Reclaim the Streets gathering. If 
not for our politics, then at least for our mutual belief in a right to 
dance!

What follows is my experience with Reclaim the Commons and the Reclaim 
the Streets on June 8th and a description of the Temporary Autonomous 
Zones or TAZ that came about during the mobilization. Your thoughts are 
encouraged. For more info on TAZ -- check out:

http://www.hermetic.com/bey/taz3.html#labelTAZ

                                                          ***

We created, not one, but at least five temporary autonomous zones. 
First there was the free Free State in golden gate park -- I wasn't 
able to attend but I've heard it went off quite well.

  Secondly, there was the Really Really Free Market in the heart of SF 
Capitalism -- this event embodied much of what this movement was about 
and I was thrilled to be there for it. I hope this is only the first of 
many free markets in San Francisco -- anyone want to help organize the 
second for July 4th and make it the first Sunday of the month?

  The third TAZ was the convergence center itself, how many of us felt 
like that became our second home while it was buzzing with activity? 
How fucking awesome was that? What can we do to resurrect that space? I 
know I would love to see that building become a community center of 
sorts, The Perma-Culture Center, maybe?

  The Fourth and Fifth TAZ's came about by sheer synchronistic chance. 
At Fourth between Howard and Mission, on the morning of June 8th, a 
celebratory space gave birth as we took over that block for our true 
celebration of bio-diversity. We danced, the drummers played, yarn was 
strung about the block as we showed the world the realization of our 
mantra, "Welcome to Possible." Free Food was brought to us by Food Not 
Bombs and we relished in our utopia until the police decided that the 
delegates were about to go to lunch and forcefully removed us from the 
streets. Shouting, swinging and snarling the police herded us onto the 
sidewalk as we fled back to our safe spaces including the welcome 
Center at 960 Howard.

  At Fifth and Market arose the Fifth and final temporary autonomous 
zone I encountered during Reclaim the Commons. As The Mutant Street 
Party began its journey down Market, everything felt a little bit 
uncertain. Our Parade began at the edge of UN Plaza and it wasn't long 
before the cops had flanked our group, first guiding us off of Market 
St. towards the Tenderloin and then chasing us back onto Market again 
as we neared our final destination at Fifth and Market. As the Cops 
surrounded us on all sides we all began to get a little tense waiting 
for the police to give the order that we all know so well by now, "As 
an officer of the San Francisco Traffic Department I'm ordering you 
back onto the Sidewalk. If you refuse to do so, you will be arrested," 
but the order never came. Tentatively we resumed our celebration in 
spite of the menacing officers that had surrounded us on all sides by 
now. Suddenly we heard what we thought would be our orders to disperse. 
We were ready to go on our way, perhaps to resume on a sidewalk plaza 
somewhere nearby, or perhaps to dissipate back to the welcome center...

  "Do Not Attempt To Cross The Police Line, If You Do So You WIll Be 
Struck By Police Batons. YOU ARE ALL UNDER ARREST."

  What the fuck? We wondered, dazed and albeit a little bit confused. 
What happened to the order to disperse? Weren't we supposed to get an 
opportunity to flea to the sidewalks in defeat? People who just 
happened to be crossing the street as our entourage neared Fifth and 
Market were now under arrest along with several passers-by that just 
happened to join into a street festival they encountered. This is San 
Francisco after all, parades, block parties, and protests are basically 
safe and common-place events. All of us, were now under arrest.

  Realizing our fate, a true celebration of life erupted as the music 
rose up once again. We danced. We chanted, we started a limbo and we 
celebrated our freedom and rejoiced in our solidarity. People with 
extra cigarettes shared with those that had run out, what little food 
and water some of us had brought was passed around freely. Once again, 
inside a police line we realized possible, and some people smoked pot 
in front of the police, safely under arrest.

  Of course, the celebration did not last long and the police quickly 
seized our sound system. They made us wait for several hours while the 
police seemed to do nothing but eat snack food and drink bottled water 
while we grew tired and thirsty. It was approximately 6:15 in the 
evening when we were told that we were under arrest, by 11:30PM I was 
still waiting to be taken into the paddy-wagon and I wasn't the last. 
For over 5 hours, we were denied both water, as well as a means to 
comfortably and legally relieve ourselves.

  And still, despite all these efforts on the part of local law 
enforcement, everyone was in quite good spirits in the holding facility 
outside 850 Bryant as those of us who were unable to participate in 
jail solidarity waited to be processed. As they called out for the John 
Does, we raised our fists and sang "Solidarity Forever" not knowing 
when we'd see our friends again.

  Getting out of jail, there were people all around us -- helping us 
with food, and water and love -- it was a great feeling having you all 
outside the jail with your support. And I'm glad I was able to be there 
when all our John and Jane Does were finally released.

  Reclaim the Commons was not June 3rd through 9th, Reclaim the Commons 
was our declaration in action. "Reclaim the Commons. Take it back! 
Seeds will grow when the empires crack!"
____________________________________________
"Don't hate the media, become the media."- Jello Biafra

Subject: [sfraves] Love parade: The Love is Coming...




>From: Loveparade SF News <info@loveparadesf.org>
>To: lovelist@loveparadesf.org
>Subject: [lovelist] The Love is Coming...
>Date: Mon, 14 Jun 2004 18:41:15 -0700
>
>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE: June 3, 2004
>Contact: Joshua Smith
>President (415) 820-1449
>joshua.smith@loveparadesf.org
>
>First U.S. Loveparade Planned for October
>
>World's largest electronic music parade comes to San Francisco
>
>SAN FRANCISCO — The world's largest electronic music festival and parade is 
>coming to San Francisco on October 2, 2004. First held in Berlin in 1989, 
>Loveparade San Francisco is expected to draw thousands of revelers to the 
>Bay Area for a celebration of electronic music with a mission of fostering 
>tolerance, respect and understanding between nations.
>
>San Francisco has long been a desired location for huge, outdoor, eclectic 
>events, including the worlds' largest Gay pride celebration and the famous 
>Castro Halloween and Folsom Street Fair parties. Loveparade promises to be 
>an event of the same caliber, drawing a colorful and diverse audience while 
>increasing the existing tourist draw to the city.
>
>This is the first time Loveparade has been held in the United States; 
>similar events are regularly held in other cities around the globe, 
>including Mexico City, Cape Town, and Tel Aviv.
>
>The event has garnered excitement from the business community and beyond. 
>California Assemblymember Mark Leno was among those to recently offer his 
>congratulations on the city's acquisition of the parade, calling it a 
>"momentous and historic" celebration. "I commend your commitment to create 
>an international community where music, dance, love and diversity can 
>creatively flourish."
>
>International DJ/Producer Paul Van Dyk stated, "I was very excited when I 
>heard that the Loveparade will take place in North America for the first 
>time. I am sure that the positive and peaceful vibe of this event will be 
>an extra feature in the amazing cultural life of San Francisco and is going 
>to become an annual highlight."
>
>The Loveparade will begin along San Francisco's scenic Embarcadero and make 
>its way through the South of Market area. It will end along the waterfront 
>in the newly redeveloped Mission Bay district with a daylong celebration 
>featuring music, dancers, and a variety of vendor booths. Top local and 
>international DJs will also be featured at the waterfront festival, as well 
>as on the floats as they make their way along the parade route. For more 
>information please visit www.loveparadesf.org.
>

>>including Mexico City, Cape Town, and Tel Aviv.
>>
>>The event has garnered excitement from the business community and beyond. 
>>California Assemblymember Mark Leno was among those to recently offer his 
>>congratulations on the city's acquisition of the parade, calling it a 
>>"momentous and historic" celebration. "I commend your commitment to create 
>>an international community where music, dance, love and diversity can 
>>creatively flourish."
>>
>>International DJ/Producer Paul Van Dyk stated, "I was very excited when I 
>>heard that the Loveparade will take place in North America for the first 
>>time. I am sure that the positive and peaceful vibe of this event will be 
>>an extra feature in the amazing cultural life of San Francisco and is 
>>going to become an annual highlight."
>>
>>The Loveparade will begin along San Francisco's scenic Embarcadero and 
>>make its way through the South of Market area. It will end along the 
>>waterfront in the newly redeveloped Mission Bay district with a daylong 
>>celebration featuring music, dancers, and a variety of vendor booths. Top 
>>local and international DJs will also be featured at the waterfront 
>>festival, as well as on the floats as they make their way along the parade 
>>route. For more information please visit www.loveparadesf.org.
>>
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bio-Tech and Reclaim the Streets...

Hi there, all

   Josh, do you have any links to studies about the dangers of
GMO insulin that you mention here? Thanks...

--- Josh Wolf <inthecity@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
> I just got around to reading the discourse on the list about
> the 
> bio-tech protests, and I can't really say that I agree with
> what I 
> heard -- I was one of the protester's after all -- but I
> totally 
> understand the sentiment I sensed regarding the biotech
> industry. For 
> me, it's not a matter of Bio-Tech being bad -- but a matter of
> adequate 
> safety measures being implemented. Bio-Tech is a new field of
> science 
> that has potential to cause significant ecological
> destruction. Sure, 
> it has potential to make certain diseases obsolete, and in
> some wacked 
> out world-view could eventually solve world-hunger -- but
> these are 
> only possibilities. It has the REAL ability to destroy entire
> plant 
> species through Terminator Technologies, and it has the REAL
> ability to 
> bring about drug treatments that prove dangerous to human
> populations 
> as has been proven the case regarding GMO Insulin.
> 
> As we live in a capitalist system, it is the corporation's
> vested 
> interest to get these products out as quickly and cheaply as
> possible, 
> and additional testing cuts into profit margins, slows down
> the 
> products introduction to the market, and risks further
> development 
> costs should the product be proven unsafe. It's like in Fight
> Club, If 
> the cost of the recall is greater than the projected costs to
> settle 
> lawsuits they don't do one.
> 
> It was not so much biotechnology that I was protesting this
> first week 
> of June as I was protesting the corporate power behind the 
> biotechnology industry. I've always been in support of new and
> emerging 
> science, but I also hold the sentiment that money and wealth
> can result 
> in devastating consequences. If Hearst can start a war by
> publishing a 
> newspaper, what makes you so sure an unchecked biotech company
> wont 
> bring about ecological destruction of epic proportions. I'm
> not saying 
> it will, I'm just saying it could.
> 
> On another note, most of the arrests happened at Reclaim the
> Streets, a 
> party held not to protest bio-tech but to celebrate our human
> right to 
> dance where we want, how we want, and when we want and without
> permits. 
> Reclaim the Streets is in protest of such legislation as the
> RAVE ACT 
> and it seems that we as a rave community should show our
> support for 
> myself and the other protests at the Reclaim the Streets
> gathering. If 
> not for our politics, then at least for our mutual belief in a
> right to 
> dance!
> 
> What follows is my experience with Reclaim the Commons and the
> Reclaim 
> the Streets on June 8th and a description of the Temporary
> Autonomous 
> Zones or TAZ that came about during the mobilization. Your
> thoughts are 
> encouraged. For more info on TAZ -- check out:
> 
> http://www.hermetic.com/bey/taz3.html#labelTAZ
> 
>                                                           ***
> 
> We created, not one, but at least five temporary autonomous
> zones. 
> First there was the free Free State in golden gate park -- I
> wasn't 
> able to attend but I've heard it went off quite well.
> 
>   Secondly, there was the Really Really Free Market in the
> heart of SF 
> Capitalism -- this event embodied much of what this movement
> was about 
> and I was thrilled to be there for it. I hope this is only the
> first of 
> many free markets in San Francisco -- anyone want to help
> organize the 
> second for July 4th and make it the first Sunday of the month?
> 
>   The third TAZ was the convergence center itself, how many of
> us felt 
> like that became our second home while it was buzzing with
> activity? 
> How fucking awesome was that? What can we do to resurrect that
> space? I 
> know I would love to see that building become a community
> center of 
> sorts, The Perma-Culture Center, maybe?
> 
>   The Fourth and Fifth TAZ's came about by sheer synchronistic
> chance. 
> At Fourth between Howard and Mission, on the morning of June
> 8th, a 
> celebratory space gave birth as we took over that block for
> our true 
> celebration of bio-diversity. We danced, the drummers played,
> yarn was 
> strung about the block as we showed the world the realization
> of our 
> mantra, "Welcome to Possible." Free Food was brought to us by
> Food Not 
> Bombs and we relished in our utopia until the police decided
> that the 
> delegates were about to go to lunch and forcefully removed us
> from the 
> streets. Shouting, swinging and snarling the police herded us
> onto the 
> sidewalk as we fled back to our safe spaces including the
> welcome 
> Center at 960 Howard.
> 
>   At Fifth and Market arose the Fifth and final temporary
> autonomous 
> zone I encountered during Reclaim the Commons. As The Mutant
> Street 
> Party began its journey down Market, everything felt a little
> bit 
> uncertain. Our Parade began at the edge of UN Plaza and it
> wasn't long 
> before the cops had flanked our group, first guiding us off of
> Market 
> St. towards the Tenderloin and then chasing us back onto
> Market again 
> as we neared our final destination at Fifth and Market. As the
> Cops 
> surrounded us on all sides we all began to get a little tense
> waiting 
> for the police to give the order that we all know so well by
> now, "As 
> an officer of the San Francisco Traffic Department I'm
> ordering you 
> back onto the Sidewalk. If you refuse to do so, you will be
> arrested," 
> but the order never came. Tentatively we resumed our
> celebration in 
> spite of the menacing officers that had surrounded us on all
> sides by 
> now. Suddenly we heard what we thought would be our orders to
> disperse. 
> We were ready to go on our way, perhaps to resume on a
> sidewalk plaza 
> somewhere nearby, or perhaps to dissipate back to the welcome
> center...
> 
>   "Do Not Attempt To Cross The Police Line, If You Do So You
> WIll Be 
> Struck By Police Batons. YOU ARE ALL UNDER ARREST."
> 
>   What the fuck? We wondered, dazed and albeit a little bit
> confused. 
> What happened to the order to disperse? Weren't we supposed to
> get an 
> opportunity to flea to the sidewalks in defeat? People who
> just 
> happened to be crossing the street as our entourage neared
> Fifth and 
> Market were now under arrest along with several passers-by
> that just 
> happened to join into a street festival they encountered. This
> is San 
> Francisco after all, parades, block parties, and protests are
> basically 
> safe and common-place events. All of us, were now under
> arrest.
> 
>   Realizing our fate, a true celebration of life erupted as
> the music 
> rose up once again. We danced. We chanted, we started a limbo
> and we 
> celebrated our freedom and rejoiced in our solidarity. People
> with 
> extra cigarettes shared with those that had run out, what
> little food 
> and water some of us had brought was passed around freely.
> Once again, 
> inside a police line we realized possible, and some people
> smoked pot 
> in front of the police, safely under arrest.
> 
>   Of course, the celebration did not last long and the police
> quickly 
> seized our sound system. They made us wait for several hours
> while the 
> police seemed to do nothing but eat snack food and drink
> bottled water 
> while we grew tired and thirsty. It was approximately 6:15 in
> the 
> evening when we were told that we were under arrest, by
> 11:30PM I was 
> still waiting to be taken into the paddy-wagon and I wasn't
> the last. 
> For over 5 hours, we were denied both water, as well as a
> means to 
> comfortably and legally relieve ourselves.
> 
>   And still, despite all these efforts on the part of local
> law 
> enforcement, everyone was in quite good spirits in the holding
> facility 
> outside 850 Bryant as those of us who were unable to
> participate in 
> jail solidarity waited to be processed. As they called out for
> the John 
> Does, we raised our fists and sang "Solidarity Forever" not
> knowing 
> when we'd see our friends again.
> 
>   Getting out of jail, there were people all around us --
> helping us 
> with food, and water and love -- it was a great feeling having
> you all 
> outside the jail with your support. And I'm glad I was able to
> be there 
> when all our John and Jane Does were finally released.
> 
>   Reclaim the Commons was not June 3rd through 9th, Reclaim
> the Commons 
> was our declaration in action. "Reclaim the Commons. Take it
> back! 
> Seeds will grow when the empires crack!"
> ____________________________________________
> "Don't hate the media, become the media."- Jello Biafra
> 
> 
>
---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> 
> 


=====

>> the
>> bio-tech protests, and I can't really say that I agree with
>> what I
>> heard -- I was one of the protester's after all -- but I
>> totally
>> understand the sentiment I sensed regarding the biotech
>> industry. For
>> me, it's not a matter of Bio-Tech being bad -- but a matter of
>> adequate
>> safety measures being implemented. Bio-Tech is a new field of
>> science
>> that has potential to cause significant ecological
>> destruction. Sure,
>> it has potential to make certain diseases obsolete, and in
>> some wacked
>> out world-view could eventually solve world-hunger -- but
>> these are
>> only possibilities. It has the REAL ability to destroy entire
>> plant
>> species through Terminator Technologies, and it has the REAL
>> ability to
>> bring about drug treatments that prove dangerous to human
>> populations
>> as has been proven the case regarding GMO Insulin.
>>
>> As we live in a capitalist system, it is the corporation's
>> vested
>> interest to get these products out as quickly and cheaply as
>> possible,

>> costs should the product be proven unsafe. It's like in Fight

>To: Cookie aka The Girl <cookieakathegirl@hotmail.com>, 
>sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] visiting san fran - any weeklies to check out?
>Date: Tue, 15 Jun 2004 10:30:04 -0700 (PDT)
>
>The obvious Tuesday choice would be Phuturo at the Top
>I think...
>
>--- Cookie aka The Girl <cookieakathegirl@hotmail.com>
>wrote:

mixing deejay pull that evening too. He was in rare form.

Subject: [sfraves] Guest List Offer for SFRaves Members 


Dear SFRaves,

I would like to extend a special invitation to SFRaves members:

The promoter of this event has requested that I offer you a special Guest
List selected for SFRaves members to attend an event of creative
proportion:

June 18th (Friday) - Urbanology by Urban Couture Hosts of the evening:
Geno Giovanni, Jose C, Tommy, Blyssful Fantasyes, Clandestine, the XOX
models, and Ladies of Persuasive Productionz: Miss Teen Latina USA - Erica
Martinez, Melissa Marie, Felicia Marie, Durina Marie. Room One [hosted by
Basco - House/80's/Breaks/Dance]: RECKLESS RYAN, JACK LACORTE vs. KUE,
KORMARA, DUY PHAM vs. MURPHY, DJ BANGIN' B, JOSE CARILLO vs. RICHIE
PELAYO. Room Two [Hosted by MC Fish and Ravenous - Hip Hop/Reggae/R&B]: J
ESPINOZA, DJ MANIAKAL vs. ANTHONY A, REZZ, JEST-ONE, DEREK MIZUNO, DNOKS
vs. DRUSKO. Urbanology will feature a 3 hour fashion show on an extended
cat walk with over 10 hip west coast designers. There will also be two
rooms of music, an art show, B-Boy showcases, comedian performances, a
multimedia showcase and much more! Get ready for a night of strutting,
styling, schmoozing, shopping, and grooving. Doors open at 8pm with shows
throughout the night. Artist showcase: Dee Jae Paeste, Maria Speranza,
Tammi, and more. Multimedia Showcase: Next Trend Technologies, nVidia, and
more. B-Boy/Dance Showcase:  DSD1 Crew, Rythem Raskalz, United by Style,
and more. Comedian Performances: Nelson Rodriquez, Wise Crack Jack, and
more. Urbanology will be held on the second floor in the beautiful Crowne
Plaza Hotel @ 777 Bellow Drive, Milpitas, CA on Friday, June 18th starting
at 8:00pm. Get $18 presales @ groovetickets.com to ensure entry and so you
don't end up paying $20 at the door! Also, VIP tickets include: reserved
front row fashion show seating, free clothes, cds, after party access,
raffle tickets, and much more for $40.  --

The special prices for this guest list are a significant discount over the
standard cost:

$10 for 18+ and $5 for 21+, meaning = save 8 bucks for 18+ and 15 bucks
off the regular prices of presale and door by being added to this list.

Please send me an email with your first and last name, age (or whether you
are 18+ or 21+) and I will ensure you are added to the list. I need to
submit the list by tomorrow evening (Wednesday) in order to take advantage
of this offer for your behalf.

Please direct all guest list inquiries to: karina@hyperreal.org /
karina@sfraves.org and a reply with more instructions will be sent back to
your address.

Thanks!

Karina

-bri

From sfraves-return-113186-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Jun 15 23:28:12 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113186-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 75511 invoked by uid 1103); 15 Jun 2004 23:28:11 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 75497 invoked from network); 15 Jun 2004 23:28:11 -0000
Date: Tue, 15 Jun 2004 16:28:49 -0700
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v553)
Cc: drXeNo@drxeno.net,
 sfraves@hyperreal.org
To: Josh Wolf <inthecity@sbcglobal.net>
From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
In-Reply-To: <C7EC3304-BEEF-11D8-9E6C-000A95A4FAE2@sbcglobal.net>
Message-Id: <C1174FEF-BF23-11D8-B6C6-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bio-Tech and Reclaim the Streets...

Josh,

	I won't argue with you about GE Insulin since I haven't studied it, 
but I do want to offer a correction on a couple side points you made 
here:

>>> As we live in a capitalist system, it is the corporation's
>>> vested
>>> interest to get these products out as quickly and cheaply as
>>> possible,
>>> and additional testing cuts into profit margins, slows down
>>> the
>>> products introduction to the market, and risks further
>>> development
>>> costs should the product be proven unsafe.

	First of all, we don't really live in a capitalist system. The United 
States has a mixed economy that is part capitalist and part socialist 
(see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States#Economy).

	For example, Tax Freedom Day in the United States this year fell on 
April 11. That's the day when the average American had finally earned 
enough money to pay off her total tax bill for the year (see 
http://www.taxfoundation.org/taxfreedomday.html). This means that 
almost a third of the year in the U.S. is spent paying for the burden 
of government, or in other words, the U.S. is about one third socialist.

	It has also been argued convincingly that measures such as Tax Freedom 
Day do not take into account all the hidden costs of government 
regulations and barriers to entrepreneurship and economic growth, and 
that in reality the U.S. economy is about half socialist.

	Second, in your analysis of the motives of corporations above, you 
neglect to mention the fact that companies have a significant interest 
not only in avoiding expensive lawsuits over unsafe products, but in 
protecting their reputations. The cost of a lawsuit alleging harm 
caused by a product costs a company much more than just the dollar 
amount involved -- it hurts the company's products in the eyes of 
consumers, costing lost sales.

	Ultimately, companies are accountable to the public. They have to 
compete by offering products or services people want at prices they are 
voluntarily willing to pay, or they will go out of business.

	Governments, on the other hand, have no similar accountability. Even 
if people do not like what a government is doing, they cannot simply 
withhold their support, because government backs up its demands for 
payment of taxes and compliance with its laws by using armed force to 
threaten confiscation of money or property, imprisonment, and 
ultimately death.
	
Peace, love & liberty,
						<<< Starchild >>>


On Tuesday, June 15, 2004, at 10:16  AM, Josh Wolf wrote:

> Links regarding GE Insulin:
>
> http://members.tripod.com/diabetics_world/fox131.htm
> http://www.primalseeds.org/news260400.htm
> http://www.netlink.de/gen/Zeitung/2000/000414a.html
> http://www.gene.ch/genet/1999/Aug/msg00029.html
>
> On Jun 15, 2004, at 8:44 AM, dr_XeNo wrote:
>
>> Hi there, all
>>
>>    Josh, do you have any links to studies about the dangers of
>> GMO insulin that you mention here? Thanks...
>>
>> --- Josh Wolf <inthecity@sbcglobal.net> wrote:
>>> I just got around to reading the discourse on the list about
>>> the
>>> bio-tech protests, and I can't really say that I agree with
>>> what I
>>> heard -- I was one of the protester's after all -- but I
>>> totally
>>> understand the sentiment I sensed regarding the biotech
>>> industry. For
>>> me, it's not a matter of Bio-Tech being bad -- but a matter of
>>> adequate
>>> safety measures being implemented. Bio-Tech is a new field of
>>> science
>>> that has potential to cause significant ecological
>>> destruction. Sure,
>>> it has potential to make certain diseases obsolete, and in
>>> some wacked
>>> out world-view could eventually solve world-hunger -- but
>>> these are
>>> only possibilities. It has the REAL ability to destroy entire
>>> plant
>>> species through Terminator Technologies, and it has the REAL
>>> ability to
>>> bring about drug treatments that prove dangerous to human
>>> populations
>>> as has been proven the case regarding GMO Insulin.
>>>
>>> As we live in a capitalist system, it is the corporation's
>>> vested
>>> interest to get these products out as quickly and cheaply as
>>> possible,
>>> and additional testing cuts into profit margins, slows down
>>> the
>>> products introduction to the market, and risks further
>>> development
>>> costs should the product be proven unsafe. It's like in Fight
>>> Club, If
>>> the cost of the recall is greater than the projected costs to
>>> settle
>>> lawsuits they don't do one.
>>>
>>> It was not so much biotechnology that I was protesting this
>>> first week
>>> of June as I was protesting the corporate power behind the
>>> biotechnology industry. I've always been in support of new and
>>> emerging
>>> science, but I also hold the sentiment that money and wealth
>>> can result
>>> in devastating consequences. If Hearst can start a war by
>>> publishing a
>>> newspaper, what makes you so sure an unchecked biotech company
>>> wont
>>> bring about ecological destruction of epic proportions. I'm
>>> not saying
>>> it will, I'm just saying it could.
>>>
>>> On another note, most of the arrests happened at Reclaim the
>>> Streets, a
>>> party held not to protest bio-tech but to celebrate our human
>>> right to
>>> dance where we want, how we want, and when we want and without
>>> permits.
>>> Reclaim the Streets is in protest of such legislation as the
>>> RAVE ACT
>>> and it seems that we as a rave community should show our
>>> support for
>>> myself and the other protests at the Reclaim the Streets
>>> gathering. If
>>> not for our politics, then at least for our mutual belief in a
>>> right to
>>> dance!
>>>
>>> What follows is my experience with Reclaim the Commons and the
>>> Reclaim
>>> the Streets on June 8th and a description of the Temporary
>>> Autonomous
>>> Zones or TAZ that came about during the mobilization. Your
>>> thoughts are
>>> encouraged. For more info on TAZ -- check out:
>>>
>>> http://www.hermetic.com/bey/taz3.html#labelTAZ
>>>
>>>                                                           ***
>>>
>>> We created, not one, but at least five temporary autonomous
>>> zones.
>>> First there was the free Free State in golden gate park -- I
>>> wasn't
>>> able to attend but I've heard it went off quite well.
>>>
>>>   Secondly, there was the Really Really Free Market in the
>>> heart of SF
>>> Capitalism -- this event embodied much of what this movement
>>> was about
>>> and I was thrilled to be there for it. I hope this is only the
>>> first of
>>> many free markets in San Francisco -- anyone want to help
>>> organize the
>>> second for July 4th and make it the first Sunday of the month?
>>>
>>>   The third TAZ was the convergence center itself, how many of
>>> us felt
>>> like that became our second home while it was buzzing with
>>> activity?
>>> How fucking awesome was that? What can we do to resurrect that
>>> space? I
>>> know I would love to see that building become a community
>>> center of
>>> sorts, The Perma-Culture Center, maybe?
>>>
>>>   The Fourth and Fifth TAZ's came about by sheer synchronistic
>>> chance.
>>> At Fourth between Howard and Mission, on the morning of June
>>> 8th, a
>>> celebratory space gave birth as we took over that block for
>>> our true
>>> celebration of bio-diversity. We danced, the drummers played,
>>> yarn was
>>> strung about the block as we showed the world the realization
>>> of our
>>> mantra, "Welcome to Possible." Free Food was brought to us by
>>> Food Not
>>> Bombs and we relished in our utopia until the police decided
>>> that the
>>> delegates were about to go to lunch and forcefully removed us
>>> from the
>>> streets. Shouting, swinging and snarling the police herded us
>>> onto the
>>> sidewalk as we fled back to our safe spaces including the
>>> welcome
>>> Center at 960 Howard.
>>>
>>>   At Fifth and Market arose the Fifth and final temporary
>>> autonomous
>>> zone I encountered during Reclaim the Commons. As The Mutant
>>> Street
>>> Party began its journey down Market, everything felt a little
>>> bit
>>> uncertain. Our Parade began at the edge of UN Plaza and it
>>> wasn't long
>>> before the cops had flanked our group, first guiding us off of
>>> Market
>>> St. towards the Tenderloin and then chasing us back onto
>>> Market again
>>> as we neared our final destination at Fifth and Market. As the
>>> Cops
>>> surrounded us on all sides we all began to get a little tense
>>> waiting
>>> for the police to give the order that we all know so well by
>>> now, "As
>>> an officer of the San Francisco Traffic Department I'm
>>> ordering you
>>> back onto the Sidewalk. If you refuse to do so, you will be
>>> arrested,"
>>> but the order never came. Tentatively we resumed our
>>> celebration in
>>> spite of the menacing officers that had surrounded us on all
>>> sides by
>>> now. Suddenly we heard what we thought would be our orders to
>>> disperse.
>>> We were ready to go on our way, perhaps to resume on a
>>> sidewalk plaza
>>> somewhere nearby, or perhaps to dissipate back to the welcome
>>> center...
>>>
>>>   "Do Not Attempt To Cross The Police Line, If You Do So You
>>> WIll Be
>>> Struck By Police Batons. YOU ARE ALL UNDER ARREST."
>>>
>>>   What the fuck? We wondered, dazed and albeit a little bit
>>> confused.
>>> What happened to the order to disperse? Weren't we supposed to
>>> get an
>>> opportunity to flea to the sidewalks in defeat? People who
>>> just
>>> happened to be crossing the street as our entourage neared
>>> Fifth and
>>> Market were now under arrest along with several passers-by
>>> that just
>>> happened to join into a street festival they encountered. This
>>> is San
>>> Francisco after all, parades, block parties, and protests are
>>> basically
>>> safe and common-place events. All of us, were now under
>>> arrest.
>>>
>>>   Realizing our fate, a true celebration of life erupted as
>>> the music
>>> rose up once again. We danced. We chanted, we started a limbo
>>> and we
>>> celebrated our freedom and rejoiced in our solidarity. People
>>> with
>>> extra cigarettes shared with those that had run out, what
>>> little food
>>> and water some of us had brought was passed around freely.
>>> Once again,
>>> inside a police line we realized possible, and some people
>>> smoked pot
>>> in front of the police, safely under arrest.
>>>
>>>   Of course, the celebration did not last long and the police
>>> quickly
>>> seized our sound system. They made us wait for several hours
>>> while the
>>> police seemed to do nothing but eat snack food and drink
>>> bottled water
>>> while we grew tired and thirsty. It was approximately 6:15 in
>>> the
>>> evening when we were told that we were under arrest, by
>>> 11:30PM I was
>>> still waiting to be taken into the paddy-wagon and I wasn't
>>> the last.
>>> For over 5 hours, we were denied both water, as well as a
>>> means to
>>> comfortably and legally relieve ourselves.
>>>
>>>   And still, despite all these efforts on the part of local
>>> law
>>> enforcement, everyone was in quite good spirits in the holding
>>> facility
>>> outside 850 Bryant as those of us who were unable to
>>> participate in
>>> jail solidarity waited to be processed. As they called out for
>>> the John
>>> Does, we raised our fists and sang "Solidarity Forever" not
>>> knowing
>>> when we'd see our friends again.
>>>
>>>   Getting out of jail, there were people all around us --
>>> helping us
>>> with food, and water and love -- it was a great feeling having
>>> you all
>>> outside the jail with your support. And I'm glad I was able to
>>> be there
>>> when all our John and Jane Does were finally released.
>>>
>>>   Reclaim the Commons was not June 3rd through 9th, Reclaim
>>> the Commons
>>> was our declaration in action. "Reclaim the Commons. Take it
>>> back!
>>> Seeds will grow when the empires crack!"
>>> ____________________________________________
>>> "Don't hate the media, become the media."- Jello Biafra
>>>
>>>
>>>

pass along.

					<<< Starchild >>>


Thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak my mind. I lost my
job this past year.

When Clinton was president, I worked in a prosperous enterprise. But
in the last year, we had to close our operations.

Far worse, I lost two of my sons in Bush's evil war in Iraq. They
gave their lives for their country, and for what?

My pain at losing my sons is indescribable.

While it is trivial next to the loss of my sons, I regret to say that
I also lost my homes. I simply have nothing left.

I am a senior citizen with various medical problems -- and I'm a
shut-in. I'm not in a position to begin a new career. I was reduced
to the point of homelessness -- all because of President Bush.

And when the authorities found me in my modest, borrowed hovel, did
they have any compassion for my misfortune and ailments? No, I was
arrested

If I had any money left, I would donate most of it to the Democratic
party. If Al Gore had been elected in 2000, I guarantee you, I would
still have a job, my homes, and most importantly, my sons.

And if we can get Kerry elected, I may be restored to a position of
dignity.

Sincerely,

Saddam Hussein


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

     well i'm registered and i plan to vote for Kerry i voted Gore last time 
and i'm still pissed about that, but anyway i might be moving to Vancouver 
B.C. in January reguardless of weather Bush wins or not and it's actually not a 
politicaly driven decision, it's just because i want to go to school there and 
it's much cheaper economically than San Fran yet on top of that it's cleaner 
and more polite than anywhere i've ever been in my life. And for a place so 
clean and polite can you believe it's nickname is "new amsterdam" because they 
grow tons of weed there. John Kerry has some great points if you ever listen to 
the man talk... and somebody has to stand up to Bush right?? i mean you can't 
beat bush just by not voting for bush, you have to vote for Kerry, period. I 
don't consider myself a democrat or anything else, it's just that realistically 
someone has to BEAT bush, they have to get the MAJORITY of votes (actually 
they have to get the majority of states too) and although most ravers and other 
radical groups of people would not like someone as moderately conservative as 
Kerry be president, ya still gotta vote for him. then maybe next term around 
we can dick around with 3rd party candidates (hell i wouldn't be surprized if a 
3rd party won in the next term or the one   after that) but now is not the 
time. The negatives people say about Kerry only make me want to vote for him 
more. people say things like oh he was a War protestor he had long hair. He left 
one of his war metals from vietnam on the steps of a capital building. oooo 
what a bad guy. on the radio Rush Limbaugh plays a clip from a John Kerry speech 
where kerry says he wants to stop the bush cabinet's plan to make more 
nuclear weapons because they send a bad message out to other nations who we're tr
ying to take them away from. Rush Limbaugh says "Don't these democrats 
understand?? we have to make nuclear weapons so that we don't have to use them! Because 
we're the good guys!" yea and i suppose the rest of the world is just supposed 
to trust us right? or else boom! come on guys does that sound like 
imperialistic agenda or what? Kerry has the courage to stop a plan already in effect to 
make more nuclear weapons and he wants to work more cooperatively with forgn 
leaders. Bush has no international comunication skills, he declined a debate 
with Sadam Husien before the war had to break out. He didn't even have the 
decency to have a national debate and show the world who was right and who was 
wrong before he decided to kill people. Bush is a pussy, period. but somebody has 
to actually beat him and that person has to be Kerry. It's like all this talk 
about how bad Bush is, lets concentrate on the man that has to beat him, talk 
about something positive. the pistons didn't beat the lakers because they hate 
shaq and kobe they beat them because they were a much more wholesome, 
complete team and they believed in themselves... anyways my rant is over take a deep 
breath,   peace - jaze

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <C1174FEF-BF23-11D8-B6C6-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Bio-Tech and Reclaim the Streets...

quoth Starchild:
> Second, in your analysis of the motives of corporations above, you
> neglect to mention the fact that companies have a significant interest
> not only in avoiding expensive lawsuits over unsafe products, but in
> protecting their reputations. The cost of a lawsuit alleging harm
> caused by a product costs a company much more than just the dollar
> amount involved -- it hurts the company's products in the eyes of
> consumers, costing lost sales.

Actually, it's widely understood that many corporations knowingly break
the law because they know that it's cheaper to settle in or out of court
than to pass up the profits they gain from doing so. Then they hire
lobbyists to push "tort reform" so that caps can be placed on the
monetary value of the damage they do to society. "Reputation" means
little in this country, where a large percentage of the population can't
be bothered to read the news regularly. And the media tends not to
report issues of corporate responsibility unless it's a national scandal
(Enron, Tyco, et al). Billions of dollars are paid by corporations every
year in out-of-court settlements so that they can avoid public backlash.
These days, "reputation" is really just a matter of how well (and often)
products and services are advertised.

> Ultimately, companies are accountable to the public. They have to
> compete by offering products or services people want at prices they
> are voluntarily willing to pay, or they will go out of business.

Gimme a break. Having the lowest prices isn't being "accountable" to the
public. Corporations are ultimately accountable *only* to their
stockholders. If the stockholders demand that a company take action to
realize a profit, the company leadership has little choice in the
matter. The market has no built-in social responsibility. It's only as
responsible as the stockholders and the law dictate that it must be.

And since most stockholders aren't in the least bit socially responsible
themselves, we have to rely on the law to keep corporations in check.
But the corporate lobby is so strong now that they're essentially
rewriting the law in their favor.

> Governments, on the other hand, have no similar accountability.

You've got the whole thing backwards. Govermnent-run businesses are the
only ones that *are* publically accountable. If you don't like the way
that a particular public service is being run, you can appeal to your
representatives to change it. Most public services were originally built
to run at a loss so that they *can* address public complaints more
easily (and without having to lay off employees or cut back services).
Corporations, on the other hand, are bound to the task of making a
profit for their shareholders, so the only (legal) way you'll influence
their decisions is by boycotting them. Boycotting a public service
wouldn't really do anyone much good (especially the people that it
aims to help).

> Even if people do not like what a government is doing, they cannot
> simply withhold their support, because government backs up its demands
> for payment of taxes and compliance with its laws by using armed force
> to threaten confiscation of money or property, imprisonment, and
> ultimately death.

That's why everyone needs to get more involved in government. Taxes
exist because nobody is willing to participate. It's a vicious circle,
and the only way to break out of it is to get directly involved. I'll
tell you one thing, putting public services in the hands of private
corporations isn't going to solve anything. You get what you pay for,
and American corporations excel at offering cheap goods, low-wage jobs
without benefits, and huge profits for the already-wealthy.

Tonight's the last night to catch The Corporation at the Castro Theatre.
If you're interested in the subject of corporate responsibility (or lack
thereof), I would highly recommend it:

<http://castrotheatre.com/p-list.html#corporation>
<http://thecorporation.com/>

Cheerio,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

word, what is this Ayn Rand bullshit? the only real functional
restraint on the criminal activity of corporations is the amount of
rioting people do. go see "The Corporation," now playing at The
Castro, and burn your copy of "Atlas Shrugged." I loved that book when
I was 17, in fact I practically memorized it, but I'm not 17 any more,
and I don't think you are either, Starchild. Where do you get this
ridiculous bullshit? there's only one type of organization in America
which is less trustworthy or more dangerous than the corporation, and
it's the fucking Mafia.

you Libertarians are all like ooh government this oooh government that
but in case you haven't noticed, Enron vs. California, who won?
please! big part of the reason I moved to the middle of nowhere. I got
an energy bill for $30 one month and it was $300 the next month. fuck
that, you can bill my Desert Eagle.


Giles

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR mercenary ranting

Does anyone really think that every 7-11 is corporately owned?

They are owned by local, private franchisees for the most part. Just like a 
mom and pop store is except for the mandatory franchise and advertising 
percentage they have to pay to the corporation. Most 7-11 owners money does 
stay in the local economy (unless they are sending it all back to family 
members somewhere else in the world).

AUDi,
Gavin

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Call today to stop government torture

> ===================================
> URGENT ACTION ITEM
> FROM THE LIBERTARIAN PARTY
> 2600 Virginia Avenue, NW, Suite 100
> Washington DC 20037
> World Wide Web: http://www.LP.org
> ===================================
> June 16, 2004
> ===================================
>
> U.S. Senate set to vote today
> on bill reinstituting ban on torture
>
> Dear Libertarian:
>
> We urgently need your help to pass a Senate bill that would reaffirm
> the U.S. ban on torture. The bill, sponsored by U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin,
> D-IL, is expected to come up for a vote TODAY -- Wednesday, June 16.
>
> We're asking everyone who gets this e-mail to IMMEDIATELY pick up the
> phone and call your two U.S. Senators at (202) 224-3121. Ask him or her
> to support the Durbin Amendment to S. 2400, the Defense Authorization
> bill for Fiscal 2005. Then forward this e-mail to several friends and
> ask them call immediately as well.
>
> Last week secret Defense and Justice Department memos leaked to the
> press asserted that the president has the power to authorize physical
> and psychological torture, despite longstanding U.S. laws to the
> contrary.  One chilling Defense Department memo detailed by the Wall
> Street Journal said: "Sometimes the greater good for society will be
> accomplished by violating the literal language of the criminal law."
>
> Then, in an appearance before the Senate Judiciary Committee, Attorney
> General John Ashcroft arrogantly refused to release the memos to
> Congress.
>
> As the Libertarian Party pointed out in its June 10 press release, not
> only is "legalized torture" uncivilized and un-American, it could
> backfire. The same logic could be used by foreign governments to
> justify torturing captured U.S. troops or American civilians overseas.
>
> On Monday the Libertarian Party joined a coalition of over 25
> organizations working to reinstitute the ban on torture, including the
> Rutherford Institute, Amnesty International USA, the Bill of Rights
> Defense Committee, the Center for National Security Studies, People for
> the American Way, the Center for Democracy and Technology, the National
> Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers and the National Black Police
> Association.
>
> Our immediate goal is to help pass the Durbin amendment, which would
> require the Defense Department to issue regulations prohibiting torture
> and report those regulations to Congress.
>
> Please pick up the phone IMMEDIATELY and call your two U.S. Senators at
> (202) 224-3121. Ask them to vote YES on the Durbin Amendment to S.
> 2400, the Defense Authorization bill for Fiscal 2005. Then forward this
> e-mail to several friends and ask them to call immediately as well.
>
> Thank you!
>
> Joseph Seehusen
> National Executive Director
> Libertarian Party

On Wednesday, June 16, 2004, at 11:00  AM, Giles Bowkett wrote:

> On Wed, 16 Jun 2004 10:19:04 -0700, shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net> 
> wrote:
>>
>> quoth Starchild:
>>> Second, in your analysis of the motives of corporations above, you
>>> neglect to mention the fact that companies have a significant 
>>> interest
>>> not only in avoiding expensive lawsuits over unsafe products, but in
>>> protecting their reputations. The cost of a lawsuit alleging harm
>>> caused by a product costs a company much more than just the dollar
>>> amount involved -- it hurts the company's products in the eyes of
>>> consumers, costing lost sales.
>>
>> Actually, it's widely understood that many corporations knowingly 
>> break
>> the law because they know that it's cheaper to settle in or out of 
>> court
>> than to pass up the profits they gain from doing so. Then they hire
>> lobbyists to push "tort reform" so that caps can be placed on the
>> monetary value of the damage they do to society.
>
> word, what is this Ayn Rand bullshit? the only real functional
> restraint on the criminal activity of corporations is the amount of
> rioting people do. go see "The Corporation," now playing at The
> Castro, and burn your copy of "Atlas Shrugged." I loved that book when
> I was 17, in fact I practically memorized it, but I'm not 17 any more,
> and I don't think you are either, Starchild.

	As a matter of fact, the last time I was at The Castro was to watch 
Ayn Rand's "We The Living."  8)  Great film, banned in Italy under the 
fascist Mussollini government. Sorry you don't appreciate her any more. 
There's few authors whose ideas are more despised and feared by the 
political elite. Those who haven't read "Atlas Shrugged" ought to.

> Where do you get this
> ridiculous bullshit? there's only one type of organization in America
> which is less trustworthy or more dangerous than the corporation, and
> it's the fucking Mafia.

	I'm not a big fan of corporations, but it's sheer cluelessness to say 
they're more dangerous or out of control than government. The U.S. 
government is profit-oriented and expansionist just like a corporation, 
but instead of limiting their goals to making money, its political 
executives and directors want to control virtually your entire life. 
Furthermore they have the armed force of the law and a perceived social 
mandate to back up their greed for money and power.

> you Libertarians are all like ooh government this oooh government that
> but in case you haven't noticed, Enron vs. California, who won?

	Hmm, well, let me see now. Enron is out of business and a number of 
its executives are facing prosecution and prison. But the government of 
California is bigger and more powerful than ever, despite having ripped 
off many more people for a whole lot more money than Enron ever did. 
The people running California's government won't pay the bill for the 
Enron debacle, even though they were ultimately responsible. Ordinary 
ratepayers like you and me will pay.

> please! big part of the reason I moved to the middle of nowhere. I got
> an energy bill for $30 one month and it was $300 the next month. fuck
> that, you can bill my Desert Eagle.

	If government didn't restrict individuals from producing energy 
themselves and getting credit for whatever they add to the grid, your 
energy bills would be a lot lower. Blame the government-created energy 
cartel; Enron was only part of that system, not the cause of it.

> Giles
>
>
> ps: http://www.thecorporation.tv
> pps: nothing personal, I admire you for taking a stand and
> representing your beliefs etc., but I think you need to bring those
> beliefs down to earth once in a while. it's all well and good to be a
> Starchild but politics is about what actually happens on the surface
> of the planet.

	Oh, come on. I'm sure you agree with me once in a while. If you don't, 
then you must agree with the Republicans on a whole lot of issues.  8)

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

doesn't show up as a 'new/unread' msg, if you want 2 c it u have 2 go
2 your 'all mail' msgs folder/link 2 c it, i've already written google
about this repeatedly on the beta bug report feedback link which i'm
no longer seeing this very minute.

name/date/size which is bullshit, i should be able to both search
**AND** sort, they're like Apple as far as this goes in terms of
dictating of what's 'best' for me.

folders/directories so gerin dahl gets her own very special rioooom 2
werk her majic in, but i've figgered out a
super-special-extra-great-fine-kludgy-werk-around 4 that which

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Poll reveals hostility to US and support for rebel cleric

--=====================_10459059==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed


Poll reveals hostility to US and support for rebel cleric


By Anne Penketh Diplomatic Editor


17 June 2004

The Bush administration's last remaining justification for the invasion of 
Iraq has been demolished by a private poll revealing that only 2 per cent 
of Iraqis regard the occupying forces as liberators.

The poll results are devastating for both President George Bush and Tony 
Blair, who are fond of saying that future generations of Iraqis will thank 
them for liberating their country. Tony Blair has consistently said that 
history will prove him right for engineering the downfall of a cruel 
tyrant, even if weapons of mass destruction were not found.

President Bush, giving a pep-talk to American soldiers in Florida 
yesterday, said: "We have come not to conquer, but to liberate people and 
we will stand with them until their freedom is secure."

Yet the main findings of the poll, which was commissioned by the US-led 
Coalition Provisional Authority (CPA) last month and which was leaked 
yesterday, reveal that only 2 per cent of the Iraqis polled in mid-May see 
coalition troops as liberators, while 92 per cent said they were occupiers. 
In a crumb of comfort for the coalition, only 3 per cent expressed support 
for Saddam Hussein.

A total of 54 per cent believed that all Americans behaved like the guards 
at Abu Ghraib. But 71 per cent of those polled in face-to-face interviews 
in six Iraqi cities said they were surprised by the guards' behaviour.

http://news.independent.co.uk/world/americas/story.jsp?story=532337



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."

rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."

Date: Wed, 16 Jun 2004 23:22:47 -0600
From: Giles Bowkett <gilesb@gmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <a90b89a604061621575a14bda8@mail.gmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
References: <000a01c4540a$30f1dde0$3f032a42@Dinningroom> <403F98CC-C018-11D8-8A92-000A958CF7B6@earthlink.net> <a90b89a604061621575a14bda8@mail.gmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) Call today to stop government torture

This shit makes me so tired. Actually I've been up for over 36 hours,
so it's only fair to point out that lack of sleep makes me tired too.
And insomnia, insomnia really makes me tired. But! All I really want
to say about all these issues is that if you find yourself thinking
about them and wondering about them and developing all sorts of
opinions about them, and everybody is going to have that experience in
the near future, then one great thing you could do is to get a copy of
the book "Divine Tragedy" by Paul William Roberts. It's an amazing
book by an amazing journalist, it's all about his three visits to
Iraq, twice before Desert Storm in the late 80s, and once actually
during Desert Storm. He had to sneak into the country disguised as a
Bedouin, but some Iraqi soldiers figured out that he was a Westerner.
They caught him, stripped him, tied him up bare-ass naked in a
basement, and left him there for four hours. And then they freed him.
They give him his clothes back and they even give him his Rolex back
and then they tell him how much they like him and how wonderful they
think he is. And he looks at the Bedouin smugglers who had brought him
into the country like, what the fuck is going on? And the Bedouins
tell him that when the Iraqis took all his stuff, they started
dividing it up, and then they found his first aid kit and come to the
conclusion that he was some kind of doctor. And when he had gotten
dressed again and put his Rolex back on they brought him casualty
affter civilian casualty. They brought him an 8-yr-old girl who had
her leg blown off, and he's supposed to help this girl, and he's got a
Band-Aid, a jar of iodine, and a bottle of whiskey.

It's not all sad, tho -- there are some very funny parts too. And you
learn a lot about what Iraq is really like.

Good book. I recommend it.


Giles


ps: the Army is experiencing an abnormally high suicide rate among
infantrymen in Iraq. if this issue really matters to you, get in
contact with somebody over there and send them something nice just to
let them know you give a fuck.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) Call today to stop government torture

Apollo wrote:

> never missed voting in an election since i was eligible.  even voted 
> when i was out of the country.  freedom without responsibility is shit.
>
> love,
> apollo

Amen to that. 

During the past Primary Election, I was discouraged by the fact that I 
was one of three people at my work (55 employees) that voted. I found 
that most people weren't even registered.  The number one reason for not 
registering:  the fear of increasing their chances of being called in 
for jury duty.  As a registered voter for about a decade, I did not feel 
that I had experienced a higher frequency of jury duty notices than 
anyone else. 

A couple months ago, I wanted to throw some outdoor events where people 
could register to vote.   However I feared that those who rejected the 
offer would return the same response -- jury duty.  Assuming those who 
wished to vote would already be registered, I felt that my best tactic 
was to test the validity of the theory: does registering to vote 
increase one's chances of being called in for jury duty?  This prompted 
me to ask the State Secretary elections department 
(http://ss.ca.gov/elections/elections.htm) of the connection, if any, 
that existed between voter registration and jury duty.  I was surprised 
that I even got a response (1 point - California, 0 points - AT&T 
wireless, but that is an entirely different matter).  My interpretation 
is that anything is game, DMV records are the primary source.  I've 
attached the email below for you to decipher this for yourself.

I do not endorse the adage, "you're damned if you do, you're damned if 
you don't." 

When I was young, I was embarrassed by the fact that my Mom saved 
pennies -- she would even pick them off the street. Her childhood was 
when a penny was worth a little more.  One penny might not have been 
enough for a candy bar, but 5 were (?).  I don't know how much 537 
pennies could have bought in the 50's, but that was the margin that 
decided the 2000 Presidential Election (source: CNN 
http://www.cnn.com/2000/ALLPOLITICS/stories/11/27/presidential.election/).

Obviously, there are those abroad that are really pissed at our 
government.  Their rage has surpassed even the most basic foundation of 
human decency.  Whether the invasion of Iraq was justified depends on 
your point of view.  IMHO, military action should be used sparingly as a 
last resort when all other paths have been exhausted.  "The purpose of 
politics [is to], to bring people together when they cannot control each 
other and they must work together."  (Bill Clinton, Cornell University 
5/29). 

I am not an activist.  I am not one dictate what one should do or not 
do. Choose as you will.  Keep in mind that our definition of inalienable 
rights are constantly being redefined by our government from 
inauguration to inauguration alongside our international policies.  
Consider the hostages whose last memory is that of a bullet collecting 
it's toll  Or a cold knife blade dredging through the outer layers of 
your neck, severing all the muscles and tissue that once supported life, 
struggling through the resistance of your vertebrae until you scream no 
longer.  What if you could have done something to prevent all of this?

-li

PS One of the scariest websites I have come across -> 
http://unansweredquestions.org.  Information is only as good as the 
source, so if you decide to check it out, use discretion. Do your 
research.  Understanding the problem is the first step in solving it 
whether it is debugging software or learning blunt to fakie rocks.  Try 
to connect the dots and see what kind of picture you draw.

--- Elections Web Mail <Elections@ss.ca.gov> wrote:
> From: Elections Web Mail <Elections@ss.ca.gov>
> To: "'deejay_li@yahoo.com'" <deejay_li@yahoo.com>
> Subject: voter sign up event
> Date: Wed, 12 May 2004 10:24:04 -0700

> 
> 
> Thank you for your email. Secretary of State Kevin Shelley has asked the
> Elections Division to respond. 
> 
> The Code of Civil Procedure, section 197 states the following:
> 
> (a) All persons selected for jury service shall be selected at
> random, from a source or sources inclusive of a representative cross
> section of the population of the area served by the court.  Sources
> may include, in addition to other lists, customer mailing lists,
> telephone directories, or utility company lists.
>    (b) The list of registered voters and the Department of Motor
> Vehicles' list of licensed drivers and identification cardholders
> resident within the area served by the court, are appropriate source
> lists for selection of jurors.  These two source lists, when
> substantially purged of duplicate names, shall be considered
> inclusive of a representative cross section of the population, within
> the meaning of subdivision (a).
>    (c) The Department of Motor Vehicles shall furnish the jury
> commissioner of each county with the current list of the names,
> addresses, and other identifying information of persons residing in
> the county who are age 18 years or older and who are holders of a
> current driver's license or identification card issued pursuant to
> Article 3 (commencing with Section  12800) of, or Article 5
> (commencing with Section 13000) of, Chapter 1 of Division 6 of the
> Vehicle Code.  The conditions under which these lists shall be
> compiled semiannually shall be determined by the director, consistent
> with any rules which may be adopted by the Judicial Council.  This
> service shall be provided by the Department of Motor Vehicles
> pursuant to Section 1812 of the Vehicle Code.  The jury commissioner
> shall not disclose the information furnished by the Department of
> Motor Vehicles pursuant to this section to any person, organization,
> or agency.
> 
> 
> Sincerely,
> Elections Web Mail Representative

--0-692293743-1087495215=:76899
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed

One problem with this country, is that in order for us to truly be a=20
'democracy' - we would have to do away with the electoral college (hence -=
=20
we are a republic - in which the people give elected representatives and=20
officials the power to govern for them.). Unless you are a voting line=20
republican or democrat (or the party in majority power in a state)  and=20
are hand selected by these political parties to vote as part of the=20
electoral college, your popular vote is merely a paun in determining who=20
gets voted into the executive branch. The electoral candidates determine=20
who becomes president, not the average voter. Our forefathers thought that=
=20
the voters (us) were too stupid and illiterate to make the "proper"=20
decision of who governs us at the executive level.

Interesting articles on the electoral college:

1) Debate over the electoral college:

http://encarta.msn.com/text_761576768___11/Electoral_College.html

"...The most common criticism of the electoral college, and in particular=
=20
the winner-take-all system, is that it makes possible =93the wrong=20
winner=94=97that is, a candidate who did not win the popular election. Thes=
e=20
critics say the winner-take-all system is largely responsible for the=20
possibility that a candidate can be elected president even though he or=20
she polls fewer popular votes than the opponent. If a candidate receives a=
=20
minority of the popular vote nationally but carries a sufficient number of=
=20
states to ensure a majority of the electoral votes, the candidate is=20
elected. As a result the will of the majority can be frustrated through=20
the normal operation of the electoral college.

Basic democratic principles, the critics argue, suggest that the people=20
ought to be able to decide directly who should govern them. They point to=
=20
the dispute caused by the election of 1876 and also to the elections of=20
1888 and 2000. In the 1888 election Democrat Grover Cleveland, the=20
defeated candidate, polled about 100,000 more popular votes than=20
Republican Benjamin Harrison. In the states that Cleveland carried,=20
however, he received only 168 electoral votes to Harrison=92s 233. Harrison=
=20
won key states having large numbers of electoral votes by narrow margins=20
and lost states having fewer electoral votes by large margins. In the=20
highly disputed 2000 election, Democrat Al Gore, the losing candidate, won=
=20
more than 500,000 more popular votes than Republican George W. Bush, but=20
Bush won the presidency by capturing 271 electoral votes to Gore=92s 266...=
"

2) http://www.ivillage.com/ivillage/election2004/pages/0,,613975_615961,00.=
html?arrivalSA=3D1&cobrandRef=3D0&arrival_freqCap=3D1&pba=3Dadid=3D9075119

"Q. What is the Electoral College?

A. The Electoral College is the state-by-state voting system that we use=20
to elect the president and vice president of the United States. It's part=
=20
of our Constitution and was introduced as a compromise to settle the=20
debate over letting the popular vote (aka, the people) choose a president=
=20
(which was thought to be too reckless), versus giving Congress the power=20
to decide alone (which was thought to be too close to a monarchy system of=
=20
government). The result? An Electoral College system that would allow the=
=20
people to vote for electors, who would then cast their votes for the=20
candidates.

Here's how it works: Even though you usually see the names of the=20
candidates on the ballot when you vote for president, you are actually=20
voting for the electors who have pledged to vote for their presidential=20
candidate. (In some states, both names are listed on the ballot.) Together=
=20
as a whole, these electors are referred to as the Electoral College.

Who are the electors? Contrary to popular thought, the Electoral College=20
is NOT made up of your elected officials; this honor usually goes to=20
people who are nominated at party conventions, in primary elections or by=
=20
party organizations. Rules vary from state to state. There are 538=20
electors in all, split among all 50 states and Washington D.C. But not all=
=20
states get the same number of electoral votes. In order to represent the=20
will of the people fairly, the states with the largest populations get the=
=20
most votes. For example, Colorado gets eight, while California gets 54.

On Election Day, the popular votes are cast and counted. But that's only=20
one step. Six weeks later, each state's electors gather to cast a vote on=
=20
behalf of their state as a unit. Unlike the popular vote, each state=20
devotes all of its electoral votes to one party. For example, California=20
can't split its votes and give 30 electoral votes to one party and 24 to=20
the other. One party will receive all 54 votes, regardless of how the=20
popular vote might have been divided. In the end, the candidate who=20
receives an "absolute majority" (270) of the electoral votes -- not the=20
popular vote -- wins the presidency.

Note: Most of the time, electors cast their votes for the candidate who=20
has received the most votes in that particular state. However, there have=
=20
been times when electors have voted contrary to the people's decision,=20
which is entirely legal."

3) http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761576768_2/Electoral_College.html

4) History of the Electoral College

http://wv.essortment.com/whathistoryele_rggl.htm

"...When the country was founded over 200 years ago, there was concern by=
=20
the Founding Fathers that the voters weren't smart enough to make "proper"=
=20
decisions when voting for the president. (Well, there was little trust=20
allowing the people vote for their Senator, too, as senate seats were=20
appointed by the individual state's leaders, a practice that continued=20
until 1920.) Despite the fact that very few were given the right to vote=20
in the earliest years -- only male landowners over the age of 21 could=20
vote -- the Founding Fathers decided to write the Electoral College into=20
the Constitution..."
  --=20

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: localhost 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Homage to a legend: Ethan

I am SO taken back over a decade by listening to Ethan's flawless music. 
His mixing is wicked, his style unique and beat-cutting, his energy and 
music selection magnifique. I would highly recommend giving your ears some 
music they might be starving to hear: Ethan's archives... I have been 
listening to them for some time and appreciate every one of his mixes -

http://www.bass-station.com/ethan/audio/

>From his site: 
"Feel free to stream them, rip them, burn them and otherwise enjoy them, 
just don't profit from them, please. My thanks and respect to the talented 
producers that made the music I've mixed here."

I love all of his sets, especially "ACID TEST" - acid house
Acid Test  	Acid House, Trousers  	May 1994

http://www.bass-station.com/ethan/audio/Ethan-Acid_Test.mp3

Other sets on this page: (for those who want to check out his other 
styles)

Set  				Style  			Date
Live @ Waldos 			House, Breaks 		October 2003
Live @ Delve 			House 			March 2003
Live @ RhythMethod 		House 			February 2003
Live @ Sweet Campout III 	House, Breaks 	October 2002
Live @ ASR's FUSE 		West Coast House 	May 2002
Live @ Persistence (vs. AndyW) 	Techno 			May 2002
Calculated Risk 		Acid Techno 		January 2002
Live @ Earthdance 		House 			October 2001
Live @ FnF Campout VI 		House 			August 2001
Live @ OODE V 			House, Progressive House May 2001
Live @ Sunset 			House 			March 2001
Electrosis 			Techno, Electro 	October 2000
Live @ Sweet 			Acid Techno 		October 1999
Live @ Topica 			Acid Techno	 	July 1998
Live @ Disco Dave's 		Thumpy Trance 		November 1997
Live @ Mad  (Disk 1)  (Disk 2) 	Trance 			September 1997
Live @ FnF (Joe's Birthday) 	Progressive Trance 	July 1996
Live @ Tribal Future 		Tech House 		June 1996
Technosis  (Disk 1)  (Disk 2) 	Acid Trance 	June 1995
Acid Test 			Acid House, Trousers

Book this man if you have a chance... He played for the SFRaves 10 Year 
Anniversary and his set from the party is available @
http://sfraves.org/history/10/2-ethan.mp3

Bumping into the morning, Karina

My yellow-stained fortress.  Just read an article about ministry's new =
album
coming out in June.  I so cant wait, it better be a proper return to =
they're
old sound.  Also in that article I read that Al is gonna be doing a new
Revolting Cocks album.WOO HOO, I've been waiting to hear something new =
from
them for a long time.  Wonder if he'll actually tour as the RevCo.  =
Probably
not, but I can still hope and dream.  Either way so long as I don't miss
Ministry when they come around touring again.  Last 2 times I've missed =
em,
and didn't even know till the day after when someone would mention it to =
me.
Must keep a vigilant eye on their webpage for concert dates.  Is it just =
me
or does they're seem to be a bit of a resurgence of the industrial =
sound?
Seeing KMFDM roll through so much the last couple of years, Einstersien
Neubauten and just yesterday Sister Machine Gun played, kinda upset =
about
missing them, but I'd be hating today if I did go.  Gonna pass on KMFDM =
next
week, only cause the last 2 shows of theirs that I caught really let me
down, the crowds just don't seem that too into the concert anymore, they
just stand there and stare.  What's the fun in that?  Hopefully Skinny =
Puppy
next month brings out the true hardcores and shit gets crazy.*crosses
fingers* Now I hear NIN has a new album coming out soon, and this new
Ministry album (which between now and the 22nd of june you can stream =
the
whole album at VH1.com), and Skinny Puppies new album, anyone out there =
have
any other industrial updates that I might have missed, I love industrial =
and
would greatly appreciate any further detail on any industrial bands.  =
Guess
it all goes back to the 20 year life cycle in which everything repeats
itself every 20 years.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Welcome to my mattress...

Too bad Ministry has sucked royal ass since the album with "New World Order" 
on it. Once they went all metal and did away with the majority of synths 
(live) they turned into a total yawn-fest. The new SKinny Puppy is "eh". Not 
horrible - but by far not exciting. And Trent and NIN (IMH) only really had 
two decent albums - Pretty Hate Machine and Downward Spiral - the other ones 
were riding that same "replace the midi w/guitars" formula, or were just 
plain wussy. YUCK.

Whatever happened to Frontline Assembly? They managed to stay pretty decent 
throughout, and Rhys Fulber's work w/ Fear Factory (for hybrid 
industrial/metal) was pretty good.

:)

M-
