Subject: [sfraves] Re: Differences between republic and democracy

Karina,

	Thanks for the info about the Electoral College. But the EC is =
not the =20
key feature that makes the United States a republic rather than a =20
democracy.

	And just to make it plain to the non poli-sci types, the words =20=

"republic" and "democracy" do not have any particular relation to the =20=

Republican and Democratic parties, they are just different models of =20
government.

	In a republic, what the government can do is limited. There are =20=

built-in safeguards for the rights of minorities (and by "minorities" I =20=

am not referring to blacks, Hispanics, Asians, etc., though they could =20=

be examples, but of anyone who happens to be in the minority when =20
holding a particular view).

	Under pure democracy, on the other hand, whatever the majority =
wants =20
can be done. If 51% of the people want to have the other 49% loaded =20
onto trains and shipped off to concentration camps, they could legally =20=

do it. (Doesn't mean it would be likely to happen, but it would be =20
legal).

	That's why most people who properly understand these two terms =
prefer =20
that the U.S. be a republic rather than a democracy. The country =20
started out as a republic, but has been moving toward a democracy over =20=

time as the checks and balances that keep government from getting too =20=

powerful have broken down.

	There are a ton of websites out there which further elaborate on =
the =20
differences between a republic and a democracy. Here are a few of them:

http://www.learn-usa.com/transformation_process/roa022.htm
http://www.angelfire.com/pa/sergeman/cliches/democracy.html
http://www.insightmag.com/news/2002/01/07/Correspondence/The-=20
Differences.Between.A.Republic.And.A.Democracy-160264.shtml
http://www.garymcleod.org/republic.htm
http://www.wealth4freedom.com/truth/13/DEMvsREPUB.htm
http://www.lexrex.com/enlightened/AmericanIdeal/aspects/demrep.html
http://www.2ampd.net/Articles/Riley/sr01.htm
http://presys.com/~ekklesia/rvd.htm
http://www.couplescompany.com/Features/Politics/Structure1.htm
http://www.mindcontrolforums.com/dvsr.htm
http://www.fff.org/freedom/0796c.asp
http://www2.america.net/~wmorris/definitions.html

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>


On Thursday, June 17, 2004, at 11:00  AM, Karina wrote:

> One problem with this country, is that in order for us to truly be a =20=

> 'democracy' - we would have to do away with the electoral college =20
> (hence - we are a republic - in which the people give elected =20
> representatives and officials the power to govern for them.). Unless =20=

> you are a voting line republican or democrat (or the party in majority =
=20
> power in a state)  and are hand selected by these political parties to =
=20
> vote as part of the electoral college, your popular vote is merely a =20=

> paun in determining who gets voted into the executive branch. The =20
> electoral candidates determine who becomes president, not the average =20=

> voter. Our forefathers thought that the voters (us) were too stupid =20=

> and illiterate to make the "proper" decision of who governs us at the =20=

> executive level.
>
> Interesting articles on the electoral college:
>
> 1) Debate over the electoral college:
>
> http://encarta.msn.com/text_761576768___11/Electoral_College.html
>
> "...The most common criticism of the electoral college, and in =20
> particular the winner-take-all system, is that it makes possible =93the =
=20
> wrong winner=94=97that is, a candidate who did not win the popular =20
> election. These critics say the winner-take-all system is largely =20
> responsible for the possibility that a candidate can be elected =20
> president even though he or she polls fewer popular votes than the =20
> opponent. If a candidate receives a minority of the popular vote =20
> nationally but carries a sufficient number of states to ensure a =20
> majority of the electoral votes, the candidate is elected. As a result =
=20
> the will of the majority can be frustrated through the normal =20
> operation of the electoral college.
>
> Basic democratic principles, the critics argue, suggest that the =20
> people ought to be able to decide directly who should govern them. =20
> They point to the dispute caused by the election of 1876 and also to =20=

> the elections of 1888 and 2000. In the 1888 election Democrat Grover =20=

> Cleveland, the defeated candidate, polled about 100,000 more popular =20=

> votes than Republican Benjamin Harrison. In the states that Cleveland =20=

> carried, however, he received only 168 electoral votes to Harrison=92s =
=20
> 233. Harrison won key states having large numbers of electoral votes =20=

> by narrow margins and lost states having fewer electoral votes by =20
> large margins. In the highly disputed 2000 election, Democrat Al Gore, =
=20
> the losing candidate, won more than 500,000 more popular votes than =20=

> Republican George W. Bush, but Bush won the presidency by capturing =20=

> 271 electoral votes to Gore=92s 266..."
>
> 2) =20
> http://www.ivillage.com/ivillage/election2004/pages/=20
> =
0,,613975_615961,00.html?arrivalSA=3D1&cobrandRef=3D0&arrival_freqCap=3D1&=
pba=20
> =3Dadid=3D9075119
>
> "Q. What is the Electoral College?
>
> A. The Electoral College is the state-by-state voting system that we =20=

> use to elect the president and vice president of the United States. =20=

> It's part of our Constitution and was introduced as a compromise to =20=

> settle the debate over letting the popular vote (aka, the people) =20
> choose a president (which was thought to be too reckless), versus =20
> giving Congress the power to decide alone (which was thought to be too =
=20
> close to a monarchy system of government). The result? An Electoral =20=

> College system that would allow the people to vote for electors, who =20=

> would then cast their votes for the candidates.
>
> Here's how it works: Even though you usually see the names of the =20
> candidates on the ballot when you vote for president, you are actually =
=20
> voting for the electors who have pledged to vote for their =20
> presidential candidate. (In some states, both names are listed on the =20=

> ballot.) Together as a whole, these electors are referred to as the =20=

> Electoral College.
>
> Who are the electors? Contrary to popular thought, the Electoral =20
> College is NOT made up of your elected officials; this honor usually =20=

> goes to people who are nominated at party conventions, in primary =20
> elections or by party organizations. Rules vary from state to state. =20=

> There are 538 electors in all, split among all 50 states and =20
> Washington D.C. But not all states get the same number of electoral =20=

> votes. In order to represent the will of the people fairly, the states =
=20
> with the largest populations get the most votes. For example, Colorado =
=20
> gets eight, while California gets 54.
>
> On Election Day, the popular votes are cast and counted. But that's =20=

> only one step. Six weeks later, each state's electors gather to cast a =
=20
> vote on behalf of their state as a unit. Unlike the popular vote, each =
=20
> state devotes all of its electoral votes to one party. For example, =20=

> California can't split its votes and give 30 electoral votes to one =20=

> party and 24 to the other. One party will receive all 54 votes, =20
> regardless of how the popular vote might have been divided. In the =20
> end, the candidate who receives an "absolute majority" (270) of the =20=

> electoral votes -- not the popular vote -- wins the presidency.
>
> Note: Most of the time, electors cast their votes for the candidate =20=

> who has received the most votes in that particular state. However, =20
> there have been times when electors have voted contrary to the =20
> people's decision, which is entirely legal."
>
> 3) =20
> http://encarta.msn.com/encyclopedia_761576768_2/Electoral_College.html
>
> 4) History of the Electoral College
>
> http://wv.essortment.com/whathistoryele_rggl.htm
>
> "...When the country was founded over 200 years ago, there was concern =
=20
> by the Founding Fathers that the voters weren't smart enough to make =20=

> "proper" decisions when voting for the president. (Well, there was =20
> little trust allowing the people vote for their Senator, too, as =20
> senate seats were appointed by the individual state's leaders, a =20
> practice that continued until 1920.) Despite the fact that very few =20=

> were given the right to vote in the earliest years -- only male =20
> landowners over the age of 21 could vote -- the Founding Fathers =20
> decided to write the Electoral College into the Constitution..."
>  -- **************************************************************
> ******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************
> If there is a sin against life, it consists perhaps not so
> much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
> & in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
> -- Albert Camus -- *******************************************
> **************************************************************

On Wednesday, June 16, 2004, at 04:47  PM, Jonas R. wrote:

> i think that we should police ourselves before we go to foreign lands.
> there is plenty of torture within our borders.
>
> i don't tell my next door neighbor how to live or raise her kids, what
> gives our country the right to police others?

	Well, not directly you don't (tell your next door neighbor how to live 
or raise her kids). We do it indirectly by voting for politicians who 
make laws telling her how to live, and by supporting those laws. 
Amounts to the same thing as if we went next door and did it ourselves.

	Not to pick on you, just hoping someone reading this may start to get 
the whole non-aggression thing.

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Showtime reality TV show "American Candidate" merges with real politics

> Report from Badnarik rally, June 12, Keene, NH
>
> On a perfect, 72 degree Saturday, in Keene, New Hampshire, Showtime
> filmed what will be the second episode of their mini-series reality
> show, American Candidate. The show will pick one "American
> Candidate" based on call in votes after the filming of the show, as
> the "people's choice" for President.
>
> The location of the filming was in Railroad Square, right behind
> where the Free State Project's first television commercial was shot.
> Keene mayor Michael Blastos, as well as talk show host Montel
> Williams hosted the show.
>
> Twelve "American Candidates" took the stage, and spoke to the
> assembled crowd, each concentrating on foreign issues, terrorism,
> and the war in Iraq.
>
> The candidates had diverse views. But one candidate is familiar to
> libertarians around the nation. Richard Mack.
>
> Not only were people rallying for their choice of "American
> Candidate", but rallying for their favorite candidate following more
> traditional methods of ascent to the oval office.
>
> Not surprisingly in the Democratic center of New Hampshire, Kerry
> supporters were the most numerous. But the second largest crowd was
> not for George Bush, but for Libertarian Michael Badnarik.
>
> Supporters of Badnarik made their voices heard and signs seen for
> national television, in a way even the Republicans could not match.
> The state chapter of the Marijuana Policy Project was also holding a
> rally there, and they quickly merged with the Badnarik supporters.
> Many of the people who came out to cheer on Badnarik and Mack donned
> themselves in MPP shirts, and the MPP supporters held Badnarik
> signs.
>
> By the end of Richard Mack's address to the audience, a large part
> of the audience was chanting "Back Mack! Back Mack!", Richard Mack's
> campaign slogan for his time on the show. Even Kerry supporters were
> cheering as Mack talked about the harm done to national security by
> the war in Iraq.
>
> And the many television cameras at the taping were paying special
> attention to the Badnarik supporters there. Every ten minutes, it
> seemed, another camera was carefully filming the activities of the
> assembled group.
>
> Waving handmade "I Like Mike" signs, and (for parts of the show),
> holding a 10'x2' "I Like Mike - Badnarik.org" sign, Badnarik
> supporters were very evident in the crowd, and should be well seen
> in the national television broadcast.
>
> At the end of the filming, the MPP became the first organization to
> endorse an American Candidate, holding a press conference to
> announce their support of Richard Mack.
>
> The filming will continue around the country for several weeks.
>
> Posted at:  http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Badnarik2004/
>
> ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
> Michael Badnarik for President Campaign HQ ----- 
> http://www.Badnarik.org
> Badnarik2004 Meetup In Your Town ----- http://Badnarik2004.Meetup.com
> Badnarik2004 Webring -- http://S.webring.com/hub?ring=Badnarik2004webr
>
>            Donate TODAY to Show Support with $5.00 to $200.00!
> http://www.Amazon.com/gp/misc/flag.html?pid=P3DB7FT10BFQCB&v=Detail
>
>               "Lighting the fires of Liberty, one heart at a time!"
> ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

Subject: [sfraves] Fwd: : gmail as file sharing tool

I got this intuitively when I first heard about gmail, a friend does a
much better job of explicitly laying 'the plan' below.

bear in mind that all such swapping needs to be done off-list.

nic

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: joe
Date: Thu, 17 Jun 2004 13:36:58 -0700
Subject: RG: gmail as file sharing tool
To: @hyperreal.org


Ravers-

As you know, I just got this shiny new gmail account.  There is a
certain feature of gmail that I think many of us will like.

They let you attach files of up to 10 megs.  That's very important.
Most single music tracks will fit in 10 megs. Which means you can
*email music* with gmail.

That fact, along with the 1000 megs they give you for storage, allows
you to use gmail as a kind of p2p client.  You take a CD and rip it to
individual tracks, and send each one on a seperate email.  Poof!  You
just emailed an entire CD.  By using the .cc feature, you can send
that same CD to anyone on a list.  And because it's on Google's
server, you aren't burying somebody.  They can just delete it if they
don't want it.

This adds a new dimension to Internet file trading.  For one, you
share with your friends on a private line.  That kind of file trading
*may* in fact be legal.  Nobody can detect these trades anyway,
because you aren't broadcasting it to the whole Internet.  For two,
it's fast!  Normally a p2p trade is limited by network bandwidth, and
whoever was slowest between you and whoever was serving the file.  Now
it's just you and the Google servers, and they didn't skimp on the
pipes.  As an example, I'm happy to get speeds of 20k/s up and down on
WinMX, even though my broadband connection goes a lot higher.  I sent
myself a CD this morning as a test, and I was seeing 180k/s.  That's
SICK.  And for files over the 10meg limit, there are tools (WinRAR)
that can break large files into smaller parts.

That's it.  Because of the fast access, great privacy, 1000meg storage
and 10meg attachments, not to mention the .cc function, gmail makes an
outstanding file sharing client.  It won't replace your standard
clients, for example you can't search for songs on gmail, but these
new features make it a nice addition to anyone's toolbox.

Oh yeah, gmail accounts are free.  If you have the means, I highly
recommend picking one up.

Joe


--
================================================
snappy one-liner goes here

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: "Raise the Roof" benefit - tonight

Come on out to Cloud 9 this evening for some great music for a great 
cause. All proceeds from this event will benefit a homeless family 
directly in the form of rent.  The idea is to supplement their income 
until they can get back on their feet, breaking the cycle of 
homelessness, one family at a time.

Check out the 1-by-1 website for more info: http://www.1-by-1.org

I'm on at midnight.  Hope to see you there!

-Philip-


*********************************


"Raise the Roof!"

a 1-by-1 benefit to house a 28 year old homeless woman and her 10 year 
old son


Friday, June 18th
9:00 p.m. to 2:00 a.m.

at Cloud 9 - 34 7th Street (at Market)

with DJs:
M3, Tuhin Roy, Monty Luke, Indigo, and Lorax


$15 cover - 100% of proceeds benefit the family directly in the form of 
rent

For more details about 1-by-1 and our sponsored family, go to: 
http://www.1-by-1.org/Cloud9.asp

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ATP : BSP Carl Cos - Mezzanine July 9th

Friday, 7/9/2004
Presale: $15.00
Ticket Sales Stop at 5:00:00 PM (PST) 7/9/2004

Talent: Carl Cox; Jeffrey Allen

Info: ALL PRESALE TICKETHOLDERS MUST ARRIVE BY MIDNIGHT.
Doors Open at: 10:00 PM
Doors Close at: 4:00 AM
Ages: 21 and up
Mezzanine
444 Jessie St
San Francisco, CA 94103

15 bux.. and @ Mezzanine.. I haven't been there yet but the reviews are 
hillarious:

http://sanfrancisco.citysearch.com/profile/911000/?cslink=cs_boc_ew_3_4
The only negative to Mezzanine is that it draws several "professional 
clubber" types - you know who I'm talking about. The type that acts like 
they are better than you and have a right to prime dance floor real estate 
because they have been to all the world's "best clubs and have seen the best 
DJs." They are so into the "subversive club scene" that they are the 
mainstream. I heard some dude say something like "Whoa, this club is so 
alive, I am flashing back to when DJ Vladimir dropped the beats at Le Loco 
in Paris in the July of '99. That changed my life." Barf.



SFR: Ranger
Santa Cruz
plurranger@hotmail.com

It's dark and no one can see

Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cos - Mezzanine July 9th

I've never really dug Carl Cox, he played at one of the first real big
parties I went to in Seattle and his set kinda sucked.  Donald glaude =
played
right before him and was way better.  He was playing on 3 decks and his
beats were slipping occasionally, I can understand monitoring 3 tables =
can
be tricky.  But then to have mixes out of phase so one cuts out way to =
early
and shit like that, that just plain sucks and sound shitty.  He was =
rockin
like everyone else in the crowd but I didn't see why, his mixing really =
left
me wondering how the hell he got the #1 dj rating for so long.  I have =
like
4 of his cd's and they all suck...no energy, doesn't seem to go anywhere =
and
mixes out of phase.  Guess it's all about how you promote yourself.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cos - Mezzanine July 9th

Strange, I have the CD Carlcox Live at the Crowbar and its really a =
great set with damn near perfect mixing. My only problem is that the =
type of progressive house/trance/techno/tribal music he plays is rather =
boring to listen to unless you are into drum circles and songs without =
melody or chord progressions. I could see it being a blast to dance to =
though.

BTW - I think in order to really enjoy repatative percussive music on a =
religious level you have to experience a drum circle. By far one of the =
most religious experiences of my life was when I was going to school in =
Cal Poly SLO and we were hanging out at a party near Avila beach, we all =
took our handmaid drums, hiked to a top of a mountain overlooking the =
beach and coastal mountains. We played and danced around for hours. The =
music would peak and then come back down, peak and then come back down. =
We were litteraly screaming at the peaks. It still gives me chills =
today.

Steve Osteen
Progressive DJ/Producer
www.tussinspace.com

From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
To: "Buck Murdock" <sinfulsalavation@hotmail.com>,"michael, the red 
stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cos - Mezzanine July 9th
Date: Fri, 18 Jun 2004 12:36:53 -0700

Strange, I have the CD Carlcox Live at the Crowbar and its really a great 
set with damn near perfect mixing. My only problem is that the type of 
progressive house/trance/techno/tribal music he plays is rather boring to 
listen to unless you are into drum circles and songs without melody or chord 
progressions. I could see it being a blast to dance to though.

BTW - I think in order to really enjoy repatative percussive music on a 
religious level you have to experience a drum circle. By far one of the most 
religious experiences of my life was when I was going to school in Cal Poly 
SLO and we were hanging out at a party near Avila beach, we all took our 
handmaid drums, hiked to a top of a mountain overlooking the beach and 
coastal mountains. We played and danced around for hours. The music would 
peak and then come back down, peak and then come back down. We were 
litteraly screaming at the peaks. It still gives me chills today.

Steve Osteen
Progressive DJ/Producer
www.tussinspace.com



-----Original Message-----
From: Buck Murdock [mailto:sinfulsalavation@hotmail.com]
Sent: Friday, June 18, 2004 12:26 PM
To: 'michael, the red stickman'; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cos - Mezzanine July 9th


I've never really dug Carl Cox, he played at one of the first real big
parties I went to in Seattle and his set kinda sucked.  Donald glaude played
right before him and was way better.  He was playing on 3 decks and his
beats were slipping occasionally, I can understand monitoring 3 tables can
be tricky.  But then to have mixes out of phase so one cuts out way to early
and shit like that, that just plain sucks and sound shitty.  He was rockin
like everyone else in the crowd but I didn't see why, his mixing really left
me wondering how the hell he got the #1 dj rating for so long.  I have like
4 of his cd's and they all suck...no energy, doesn't seem to go anywhere and
mixes out of phase.  Guess it's all about how you promote yourself.

Date: Fri, 18 Jun 2004 13:34:47 -0700

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY1-F58OzHHHlWJLWr0006dbf7@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 18 Jun 2004 20:34:47.0608 (UTC) FILETIME=[B2699380:01C45573]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cox - Mezzanine July 9th

>Strange, I have the CD Carlcox Live at the Crowbar and its really a great 
>set with damn near >perfect mixing. My only problem is that the type of 
>progressive house/trance/techno/tribal music >he plays is rather boring to 
>listen to unless you are into drum circles and songs without melody or 
> >chord progressions. I could see it being a blast to dance to though.

It's just called TECHNO (AKA real party music) and what you're not 
understanding is it's not about the song, it's about the track.

I love that CD even though it's a bit loose and one catastrphic mix stays 
off for almost a minute. If I had heard that track live I would probably 
still be having flashbacks.

Carl is off the hook. Even if it gets a bit loose some times (he's the only 
one I give any mixing slack to) and plays the occasional horrible anthemy 
track, he always plays the best music and knows what to do with it. Not like 
the rest of the world's top 10 that have been getting over on limited skill 
and huge name recognition for years. My man is over 40 years old and still 
parties just as hard while he's in the booth as anyone on the floor when he 
plays. He puts in madd work behind the decks and has been getting better 
technicly, and musicly, as he gets older. Carl's obviously staying true to 
his soul too, otherwise he'd be back playing acid & progressive house and 
trance like he used to and everyone else has gone back to for the paycheck. 
My man's the Rolling Stones of dance music.

Besides, he makes mainstream clubber girls dig techno... That's all that 
should really matter.

- Gavin Varitech
(916) 733-1615 - Info/Bookings
(916) 412-3313 - Contact
www.djvaritech.net  www.techwesttribe.com

System: "UNITED" (July 4, 2004) -invitation only
System: "DRUM CIRCLES" (Sept 5, 2004)
System: "A NEW WORLD" (Oct 10, 2004)

Neverending & In Tha Mix underground collaboration- AUG 8th





>From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
>To: "Buck Murdock" <sinfulsalavation@hotmail.com>,"michael, the red 
>stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cos - Mezzanine July 9th
>Date: Fri, 18 Jun 2004 12:36:53 -0700
>
>Strange, I have the CD Carlcox Live at the Crowbar and its really a great 
>set with damn near perfect mixing. My only problem is that the type of 
>progressive house/trance/techno/tribal music he plays is rather boring to 
>listen to unless you are into drum circles and songs without melody or 
>chord progressions. I could see it being a blast to dance to though.
>
>BTW - I think in order to really enjoy repatative percussive music on a 
>religious level you have to experience a drum circle. By far one of the 
>most religious experiences of my life was when I was going to school in Cal 
>Poly SLO and we were hanging out at a party near Avila beach, we all took 
>our handmaid drums, hiked to a top of a mountain overlooking the beach and 
>coastal mountains. We played and danced around for hours. The music would 
>peak and then come back down, peak and then come back down. We were 
>litteraly screaming at the peaks. It still gives me chills today.
>
>Steve Osteen
>Progressive DJ/Producer
>www.tussinspace.com
>
>
>
>-----Original Message-----
>From: Buck Murdock [mailto:sinfulsalavation@hotmail.com]

>
>I've never really dug Carl Cox, he played at one of the first real big
>parties I went to in Seattle and his set kinda sucked.  Donald glaude 
>played
>right before him and was way better.  He was playing on 3 decks and his
>beats were slipping occasionally, I can understand monitoring 3 tables can
>be tricky.  But then to have mixes out of phase so one cuts out way to 
>early
>and shit like that, that just plain sucks and sound shitty.  He was rockin
>like everyone else in the crowd but I didn't see why, his mixing really 
>left
>me wondering how the hell he got the #1 dj rating for so long.  I have like
>4 of his cd's and they all suck...no energy, doesn't seem to go anywhere 
>and
>mixes out of phase.  Guess it's all about how you promote yourself.
>

Saturday June 19, 2004
Dishonorable Discharge

Presented by the Tenderloft

The last 2 1/2 years have been a blast- thanks to all
for coming to our events! This will be our last. We're
coming with a lineup of all TL residents (past and
present) and we're gonna bring it back to the basics.
Join us one last time to witness the dishonorable
discharge of the TL for crimes against boredom. Peace
out!

L. Doggindahouzz
Frat Boy
GBA
Smex
DJ Tonic
DJ Yap
DJ M
DJ Brad Pitt

Drum 'n Bass + Techno + House + Breaks + Hip-Hop

Neuralocity

brigade

San Francisco

>From: "Steve Osteen" <SOsteen@pinnaclesys.com>
>To: "Buck Murdock" <sinfulsalavation@hotmail.com>,"michael, the red 
>stickman" <red_stickman@yahoo.com>,<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cos - Mezzanine July 9th
>Date: Fri, 18 Jun 2004 12:36:53 -0700
>
>Strange, I have the CD Carlcox Live at the Crowbar and its really a great 
>set with damn near perfect mixing. My only problem is that the type of 
>progressive house/trance/techno/tribal music he plays is rather boring to 
>listen to unless you are into drum circles and songs without melody or 
>chord progressions. I could see it being a blast to dance to though.
>
>BTW - I think in order to really enjoy repatative percussive music on a 
>religious level you have to experience a drum circle. By far one of the 
>most religious experiences of my life was when I was going to school in Cal 
>Poly SLO and we were hanging out at a party near Avila beach, we all took 
>our handmaid drums, hiked to a top of a mountain overlooking the beach and 
>coastal mountains. We played and danced around for hours. The music would 
>peak and then come back down, peak and then come back down. We were 
>litteraly screaming at the peaks. It still gives me chills today.
>
>Steve Osteen
>Progressive DJ/Producer
>www.tussinspace.com
>
>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cox - Mezzanine July 9th

>From: "Gavin Varitech" <nesound@hotmail.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: RE: [sfraves] PAT : BSP Carl Cox - Mezzanine July 9th
>Date: Fri, 18 Jun 2004 13:34:47 -0700
>
>>Strange, I have the CD Carlcox Live at the Crowbar and its really a great 
>>set with damn near >perfect mixing. My only problem is that the type of 
>>progressive house/trance/techno/tribal music >he plays is rather boring to 
>>listen to unless you are into drum circles and songs without melody or 
>> >chord progressions. I could see it being a blast to dance to though.
>
>It's just called TECHNO (AKA real party music) and what you're not 
>understanding is it's not about the song, it's about the track.
>
>I love that CD even though it's a bit loose and one catastrphic mix stays 
>off for almost a minute. If I had heard that track live I would probably 
>still be having flashbacks.
>
>Carl is off the hook. Even if it gets a bit loose some times (he's the only 
>one I give any mixing slack to) and plays the occasional horrible anthemy 
>track, he always plays the best music and knows what to do with it. Not 
>like the rest of the world's top 10 that have been getting over on limited 
>skill and huge name recognition for years. My man is over 40 years old and 
>still parties just as hard while he's in the booth as anyone on the floor 
>when he plays. He puts in madd work behind the decks and has been getting 
>better technicly, and musicly, as he gets older. Carl's obviously staying 
>true to his soul too, otherwise he'd be back playing acid & progressive 
>house and trance like he used to and everyone else has gone back to for the 
>paycheck. My man's the Rolling Stones of dance music.
>
>Besides, he makes mainstream clubber girls dig techno... That's all that 
>should really matter.
>
>- Gavin Varitech
>(916) 733-1615 - Info/Bookings
>(916) 412-3313 - Contact
>www.djvaritech.net  www.techwesttribe.com
>
>System: "UNITED" (July 4, 2004) -invitation only
>System: "DRUM CIRCLES" (Sept 5, 2004)
>System: "A NEW WORLD" (Oct 10, 2004)
>
>Neverending & In Tha Mix underground collaboration- AUG 8th

bridge

5)  Myria was a hottie for an alien

only about 15 episodes deep, plenty more to go.  if anyone wants to come 
over and watch some robotech, just lemme know!

Last Epiphany one of my last mixes was some of the fastest, hardest shit I
own at +8 mixed with Deities.

Resurrection coming in stereo... if you say so.
andyw

p.s. And on the good not good thing... Psalm 69 was their last decent
album, but I wouldn't say everything before that was good ("with Sympathy"
is on a lot of people's worst albums of all time lists).  Land of Rape and
Honey is probably the best in terms of just completely blowing my mind
when it came out, the production on "Mind" is was amazing when it came out
as well (Thieves by Ministry and Tim Omen by Skinny Puppy just slayed on
using samplers to play stuff that couldn't possibly be played on real
drums and guitars in a way that was immediate and accessible, helping
establish digital samplers as more than just a tool for theft).

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Welcome to my mattress...

I have a friend who threw down Thieves in a chill house set somehow.  I =
was
just grooving listening to the funky beats and all of the sudden I start =
to
think...wait a minute I know that sound coming up...what the hell is
it...hmmm, it kinda sounds like ministry and I walked over to the decks =
and
there he was smoothly squeezing in some Thieves action, it was awesome I
think me and a few of my friends we're the only ones screaming and =
getting
into it...everyone else kinda looked at him like he was crazy for going =
from
funky into crunchy, but that's the best part of being a dj, playing what =
you
wanna hear...hehehe.  I agree with ya on the albums though, with =
sympathy
sucked ass...even al wont put any claim to it...which is fucking awesome =
and
funny.  Mind and Land are really tied with me, a lot of times I get the =
2
confused cause they're somewhat similar, but not.  Psalm I really liked,
granted it wasn't as synth oriented like the previous 2, but the way he =
can
make those guitars sound like machines ina factory and the shear speed =
and
angst in that album just make it rock.  Filth Pig kinda sucked, never =
could
really get into it, and Darkside was just horrible.  But then again I =
guess
if you're writing an album will having major heroin withdrawls it might
conflict with your creativity and metal stability.  He wrote this new =
one
clean and sober *at least that's what all the sources say, and I'd =
believe
it now, he's getting old, needs to get off the junk* anyway, he wrote it
sober and I think it sounds pretty good, being clean for a while I bet
helped him focus more on the music rather than on the pain he was =
feeling
inside.

-----Original Message-----
From: AndyW [mailto:andy@saturn5.com]=20
Sent: Friday, June 18, 2004 3:14 PM

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Welcome to my mattress...


Last Epiphany one of my last mixes was some of the fastest, hardest shit =
I
own at +8 mixed with Deities.

Resurrection coming in stereo... if you say so.
andyw

p.s. And on the good not good thing... Psalm 69 was their last decent
album, but I wouldn't say everything before that was good ("with =
Sympathy"
is on a lot of people's worst albums of all time lists).  Land of Rape =
and
Honey is probably the best in terms of just completely blowing my mind
when it came out, the production on "Mind" is was amazing when it came =
out
as well (Thieves by Ministry and Tim Omen by Skinny Puppy just slayed on
using samplers to play stuff that couldn't possibly be played on real
drums and guitars in a way that was immediate and accessible, helping
establish digital samplers as more than just a tool for theft).

Ministry, Wax Trax!, and house...

they were putting something in the water in Chicago back in those
days, man. sounds like a good thing, but you weren't there, man. I was
there, for real, y0. all those industrial kids were actually bringing
power tools into school and having impromptu jam sessions in the
hallways. it was fucking crazy, man. I was THERE. smashing on lockers
and waving drills in the air. it was wild!

uhh...yeah...I was, uh, like THERE...man...

-- 
Giles Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com

Subject: [sfraves] BSP:  Tonight!!!


Yes, ladies and gentleman.  your friend JZ is having reconstructive ACL 
surgery on her left knee. "How is she gonna dance?" I wonder the same 
question myself.  For those of you who do not know Jenny...She has been 
dancing her cute, loud and wonderful little ass off in the SF party scene 
since 1996.  She is such a wonderful spirit, I am so glad to call her my 
best friend.  If you know JZ, you know how much dancing means to her, for 
you who do not know her, she has been dancing as a way of expression and 
release for waaaaay long, even choreographing many dances in HS and college. 
  When she told me about this my heart sank....it sucks..
But we are going to help DAMN IT!!! hahahaha


Think happy, healing thoughts for her and please come and support her as she 
cannot work for a good month and a half or so.  This is a fundraising party 
to help cover medical costs.

So here it is Ladies and gentle-men
Friday, June 18th Friends and lovers of the infamous Jenny Zubiate are 
helping her out!!!!!

Shazbot (Moksha Tribe, Teknotika @ newstylesound)

acct.

www.hydrogirl.com/party/directions.html

yerba buena island
Much Love to you all, I hope you are well and hope to see you soon
thank you!!
Danny

hey, i've been unsubbed for a while and i gotta tell ya, nothing made
coming back feel more like home than having that first Geri Dahl post
come flying over the transom and landing in my brain's lap.

in these uncertain times it was one of the more reassuring things I've
had happen that the werld hadn't gone completely off its rocker.

in a weird way, i kinda missed her

she's totally innocuous and not a troll and not an instigator and
pretty harmless and she doesn't spew that right-wing vitriol that some
"ravers" on other lists and here do.

that have issues with mental illness, in a schiz sort of way.

I mean c'mon, their heroes in this Bush Admin are the very same ones
that want to get them locked up, courtesy of the RAVE Act.

If there was ever a group that needed to 'check their premises,' it's them.

I'm waiting with bated breath for Geri's next installment.

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

From: DISCONNECT4@aol.com
Message-ID: <1d2.23f5b6d2.2e05ac97@aol.com>
Date: Sat, 19 Jun 2004 10:49:59 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_1d2.23f5b6d2.2e05ac97_boundary"
X-Mailer: Thunderbird - Mac OS X sub 24
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] don't sleep on TELIC

--part1_1d2.23f5b6d2.2e05ac97_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit


     shouts out to the telic people for making good on their quest to provide 
quality venues and insuring the successful future of bay area raves. their 
latest location 'TELIC' opening up only roughly a month ago has already garnered 
a small cult following. the space is reminiscent to the former large 
warehouse ill-named "second and crack" aka second and jackson in oakland ( the venue 
owners i believe were not to be blamed for the fall BTW.. excessive flyering 
outside the venue, littering, graffiti, fed up city officials, and promoting to 
the wrong demographic have all been cited as reasons for second & jackson's 
demise. fun while it lasted `;)), yet TELIC i feel doesn't share the same 
psychosomatic grime. 

     The TELIC space is a clean space with a certain sense of class and is 
easily rocked by small affordable soundsystems. so far the vibe is of nostalgia 
for warehouse raves in the past ( the mid 90s were ten years ago?!) and a hair 
of apprehension on how long will such a great space last. but as to keep 
their declarations public, sidewalk chalk is/was provided for the graffers and 
staff early on for those who felt the need to express their beliefs or marks. the 
telic staff, by means of the chalked up walls, also seemed to want to to let 
the patrons know that the ethos and morality of rave is present with Peace 
Love Unity and Respect. The vibe of the space for the moment is actually governed 
by those principles and no haters seem to ever be present.

     i see the only drawbacks to the space are the fact that so many ravers/ 
promoters still have a bad taste in their mouths left over from the tongue 
chewing massives in past years to trust such a venue that might just seem to them 
like another 'happy trance cavern'. although most of the music heard there is 
trance and its relatives, the space has so much potential for other genres to 
flourish in a space for which those genres were originally designed. specific 
genres including house breaks and techno seem to stand out the most in a 
space where the reverb is a major factor in the space's charm & appeal (think 
pro-jex, Spank & LA Williams tracks). trance, which already has a fair amount of 
reverb on it, finds it's emotional content deadened by being cancelled out by 
the space's natural reverb and makes it sound wayyy too clean and flat. sharp 
funky beats seem to play off of that space and add to the whole environment 
(don't get me wrong, some of my best friends play trance`;P).

      as an example donalde glaude showed up from seemingly nowhere as a 
follow up to his ruby skye gig last night to rally 4:30 am heads back up into a 
stomping frenzy. (props to audio metamorphosis et-al.) his techno/prog-house 
beats banging the walls, -accentuating his style with the usual hypnotic groove 
that most of today's electronic music seems to lack. 
     The future for the space is unknown, but for sure there TELIC is a great 
venue that just begs for suitable promotion by people who respect TELIC's 
ideals and can offer a space for local and international talent. in short, 
TELIC's the kind of space that makes me happy to be a raver again. `;)


::much respect::

sean ocean
DJ Disconnect
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
DEF
+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
www.defsf.com "a west coast techno alliance"


4152586886

--part1_1d2.23f5b6d2.2e05ac97_boundary--

Dina/Dragn'fly, last night at Telic you told me the same thing about the  
movie Groove and John Digweed playing an underground (which, I admit, seemed  
like one of the few unlikely things in the movie) and how we were being treated  
to a very similar thing. Donald Glaude rocks!  Wow ... he looked like he  was 
having a FANTASTIC time. He was spinning with his elbows and behind his  back, 
and working the mixer with his NOSE !  I'd seen him spin a couple  times but 
never up close like he was last night.Even at 6 am he had people  jumping up 
in the air. I'm sure everybody went home happy!  

Three cheers for Donald, all the DJs, and the Telic crew!  
wow
amazed  
:)
John

>governed
>by those principles and no haters seem to ever be present.
>
>      i see the only drawbacks to the space are the fact that so many 
>ravers/
>promoters still have a bad taste in their mouths left over from the tongue
>chewing massives in past years to trust such a venue that might just seem 
>to them
>like another 'happy trance cavern'. although most of the music heard there 
>is
>trance and its relatives, the space has so much potential for other genres 
>to
>flourish in a space for which those genres were originally designed. 
>specific
>genres including house breaks and techno seem to stand out the most in a
>space where the reverb is a major factor in the space's charm & appeal 
>(think
>pro-jex, Spank & LA Williams tracks). trance, which already has a fair 
>amount of
>reverb on it, finds it's emotional content deadened by being cancelled out 
>by
>the space's natural reverb and makes it sound wayyy too clean and flat. 
>sharp
>funky beats seem to play off of that space and add to the whole environment
>(don't get me wrong, some of my best friends play trance`;P).
>
>       as an example donalde glaude showed up from seemingly nowhere as a
>follow up to his ruby skye gig last night to rally 4:30 am heads back up 
>into a
>stomping frenzy. (props to audio metamorphosis et-al.) his 
>techno/prog-house
>beats banging the walls, -accentuating his style with the usual hypnotic 
>groove
>that most of today's electronic music seems to lack.
>      The future for the space is unknown, but for sure there TELIC is a 
>great
>venue that just begs for suitable promotion by people who respect TELIC's
>ideals and can offer a space for local and international talent. in short,
>TELIC's the kind of space that makes me happy to be a raver again. `;)
>
>
>::much respect::
>
>sean ocean
>DJ Disconnect
>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
>DEF
>+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
>www.defsf.com "a west coast techno alliance"
>
>
>4152586886

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 73580 invoked from network); 21 Jun 2004 02:01:42 -0000
Message-ID: <40D6419B.6000102@waxwrecka.com>
Date: Sun, 20 Jun 2004 19:02:03 -0700
From: Li Sasaki <li@waxwrecka.com>
User-Agent: Mozilla Thunderbird 0.7 (Windows/20040616)
X-Accept-Language: en-us, en
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] review: shazbot "the control structure"

It's been almost 3 years since I bought my last techno record, but I 
still appreciate the music.  I ran through Sean's (aka Shazbot) latest 
CD, "The Control Structure" twice before being totally captivated by the 
seamless fusion of soulful, minimal techno and deep, techy house.  I say 
it took two times because the first time I listened to it I was at work 
listening at low levels through crappy computer speakers.  The second 
time I was able to experience the low rolling, bluesy bass notes of the 
first track "Gbbbump" by Jeff Samuel continuing on through a well 
contemplated set of peaks and valleys like the high speed straightaways 
and enigmatic corkscrews of a well engineered rollercoaster ride.  The 
heavy stompers, tracks: 6. "Drowning," by Jeremy P. Caulfield,  9. "Clip 
Zwei," by Oliver Hacke and  11. "Outhouse ( Beaty Tool Mix)" were at the 
top of my "grooving in the car on the way to work" list -- reaffirming 
my belief that time travel *is* possible. "The Control Structure" 
blurred the lines between techno and SF deep house, extracting the raw 
essence of each and drawing a whole new mental picture. 

The good news is that I think you may still be able to get a copy. 

His email be: shazbot | @t | alterior.net

-li

--

From sfraves-return-113367-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jun 21 02:23:58 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113367-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Received: (qmail 79148 invoked from network); 21 Jun 2004 02:23:58 -0000
Message-Id: <6.1.1.1.2.20040620183228.02411870@localhost>
X-Sender: apollo@localhost
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 6.1.1.1
Date: Sun, 20 Jun 2004 19:24:41 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_22686040==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Dhamaal

--=====================_22686040==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Last night I decided to once again step outside the musical treadmill I 
sometimes feel I'm on and experience something different.  This weekend it 
was the Dhamaal Sound System's "Asian Massive" at Club 6.  The featured 
performer was Sukhawat, one half of the New Delhi-based group MIDIval 
Punidtz, supported on the dancefloor by Janaka Selekta's EDM interpretation 
of his songs.

Sukhawat's songs reflect a tradition of Indian music that goes back to the 
16th century Sham Chorasi school of music in the court of Akber the Great.

There were abundant drummers, a Pakistani folksinger, Sukhawat Ali Khan, 
and DJ Cheb I Sabbah.

The music and evening were truly amazing.  These performers have stepped 
outside of traditional genre paradigms and focus, instead, on a "theme," in 
this case traditional South Asian folk music and beats morphed into 
electronic dance music.  Wonderful.  The beats were all over the 
place:  breaks, hip hop, drum 'n' bass, house and some trance in the mix.

The venue was packed.  I had for some reason expected a sort of New Age 
vibe and crowd.  What we found was authentically South Asian:  a heavy 
representation of the local Indian community.  Most of my personal 
experiences with the Indian community in the Bay have been 
business-oriented, but I am familiar with the ancient traditions of dance 
in this culture.  I also enjoy Indian films  --  the ones where people 
begin singing and dancing  joyfully to beats at the slightest 
provocation.  The Dhamaal dancers seemed to reflect those traditions, 
albeit a 21st century interpretation:  unselfconscious, sensual, and 
energetic.  There were dancers in traditional garb, some with turbans, as 
well as those in more hip gear, often with South Asian embellishment.

For a community that dances together regularly these folks are very open 
and friendly to newbies.  We made more new friends Saturday night than we 
normally do in our regular party circuit.

Props to Angel, the owner of Club 6.  He loves dance music, DJs himself, 
and brings much needed diversity and innovation to the club scene in San 
Francisco.

Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--=====================_22686040==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] review: shazbot "the control structure"


Damn there guy, I just space out and see spots when I listen to that mix.
And I mean that in the best way.

Good stuff, definitely a strong addition for anybody who likes a minimal
tech interpretation of house track flow and subby bass.  Clean, tasteful,
yet full of sounds blended in a way that sound fresh and increase in
dimension with repeated listenings... and it's very refreshing to hear a
mix that isn't shooting for a midnight peak hour slot... Shazbot's style
aims at a different target, a slot in a dark room somewhere as night gives
way to predawn or maybe last call, a pleasant re-entry for the dancefloor
faithful.

goodstuff!
andyw

On Sun, 20 Jun 2004, Li Sasaki wrote:
-&e->It's been almost 3 years since I bought my last techno record, but I
-&e->still appreciate the music.  I ran through Sean's (aka Shazbot) latest
-&e->CD, "The Control Structure" twice before being totally captivated by the
-&e->seamless fusion of soulful, minimal techno and deep, techy house.  I say
-&e->it took two times because the first time I listened to it I was at work
-&e->listening at low levels through crappy computer speakers.  The second
-&e->time I was able to experience the low rolling, bluesy bass notes of the
-&e->first track "Gbbbump" by Jeff Samuel continuing on through a well
-&e->contemplated set of peaks and valleys like the high speed straightaways
-&e->and enigmatic corkscrews of a well engineered rollercoaster ride.  The
-&e->heavy stompers, tracks: 6. "Drowning," by Jeremy P. Caulfield,  9. "Clip
-&e->Zwei," by Oliver Hacke and  11. "Outhouse ( Beaty Tool Mix)" were at the
-&e->top of my "grooving in the car on the way to work" list -- reaffirming
-&e->my belief that time travel *is* possible. "The Control Structure"
-&e->blurred the lines between techno and SF deep house, extracting the raw
-&e->essence of each and drawing a whole new mental picture.
-&e->
-&e->The good news is that I think you may still be able to get a copy.
-&e->
-&e->His email be: shazbot | @t | alterior.net
-&e->
-&e->-li
-&e->

-&e->~_ ~_ ~ _~_ ~__~ _~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~  ~

Hey all you groovy people,
We’re putting the word out to all the finest Bay Area
dance communities to bring us all together for a
rockin’ Dance event.  Please grab your dancing
partners, shoes & boo-tay and come on down to Oak-town
to shake it at:

SAVE BOB
A multi-community dance event
Raising awareness about medical marijuana legislation
&
Providing support for the SAVE BOB Legal Defense Fund.

Saturday, June 26th 8pm-4am
208 2nd Street @ Jackson, Oakland
Info:  (510) 325-2190

Brought to you by:
The SAVE BOB Foundation

Booty shakin’ sounds delivered by:
DJ Drag’nfly
Richard Summerhayes vs. Mark Campbell
Chris Jackson
Andy W
Melanie Summerhayes
Jonas Robledo
Derek Fieldsoe
Michael the Redstickman
StarDragon

Also Featuring:
Visuals by Okeanos
Lights & Effects by Radiant Atmospheres

Special Events:
The Save Bob Silent Auction: Bid on Art done by local
artists, tarot and energy readings, custom clothing
gift certificate, cannabis books and posters, and may
other wonderful items and services.
If you would like to donate goods or services to the
Silent Auction, please go to
www.blyssabyss.org/wiki/pmwiki.php/RonBenefit/SilentAuction

Kiss Bob! The Fun-raising Kissing Booth (featuring Bob
Jesse and Cheryl Foreman)
A Kiss a day will keep the cops away
A Kiss an hour will give you power
A Kiss a minute will help us win it!!

So come on down and shake it!  If you can’t come and
would still like to make a donation you can through
paypal at saveronnilson@yahoo.com

Help us raise the money and the energy.  Let’s all
come together and groove in support of Bob and the Bay
Area dance community.
Hope to see you there.
-The SAVE BOB Foundation

For additional information about the event, Ron’s
story and why it’s called SAVE BOB, or to volunteer
please surf to
www.blyssabyss.org/wiki/pmwiki.php/RonBenefit/RonBenefit


All proceeds benefit the SAVE BOB Legal Defense Fund.

Please forward this to your friends, family, and
community

Libertarian presidential candidate: private space launch shows the=20
Libertarian solution in action

AUSTIN, TEXAS =96- Libertarian presidential nominee Michael Badnarik=20
points to SpaceShipOne=92s successful flight as an example of the power=20=

of the Libertarian solution.

=93SpaceShipOne=92s successful flight shows the world a dramatic example =
of=20
how private enterprise outperforms government,=94 declared Badnarik.=20
=93NASA=92s space plane designs cost enormous amounts of money and took=20=

decades to develop. Free enterprise did the same job better with only=20
$20 million dollars -- because government is profoundly inefficient=20
whereas the free market is amazingly efficient.=94

SpaceShipOne=92s launch story perfectly illustrates the Libertarian=20
principles of strictly limited government, protection of private=20
property, and the power of free enterprise. Built by famed aircraft=20
designer Burt Rutan=92s company Scaled Composites, and funded by $20=20
million from Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, the completely reusable=20
SpaceShipOne is designed to compete for the $10 million Ansari X Prize.=20=

The contest organizers modeled their challenge after the Orteig Prize=20
that spurred aviator Lindbergh=92s famous flight. The X Prize mission=20
statement reads, in part:

=93We believe that spaceflight should be open to all -- not just an =
elite=20
cadre of government employees or the ultra-rich. We believe that=20
commercial forces will bring spaceflight into a publicly affordable=20
range. We will use our best efforts to achieve this goal.=94

Badnarik also noted how the SpaceShipOne project illustrates the=20
economic drag of government regulation. =93We had the first space planes=20=

many decades ago. We didn=92t have commercial space flight until today=20=

because of government interference. =46rom harassing high-power rocketry=20=

enthusiasts, to trying to stop Dennis Tito=92s private flight on a=20
Russian rocket, jealous government bureaucrats have stifled innovation=20=

in space. SpaceShipOne=92s launch shows what private enterprise can do=20=

when government gets out of the way.=94

Former Libertarian presidential candidate Barry Hess and Libertarian=20
talk radio host Ernest Hancock attended the launch. Rutan reportedly=20
handed the pilot a sign brought to the launch by Hancock shortly after=20=

the craft landed which read "SpaceShipOne - Government Zero."

Libertarian Party Presidential Nominee Michael Badnarik expects to be=20
on the ballot in all 50 states, more than Ralph Nader. [For third party=20=

verification contact Richard Winger, Editor, Ballot Access News - (415)=20=

922-9779]
###

=
</smaller></smaller></smaller></smaller></fontfamily></fixed><fontfamily><=

=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D</smaller></fontfamily><fi=
xed><fontfamily><param>Courier =
New</param><smaller><smaller><smaller><smaller>

</smaller></smaller></smaller></smaller></fontfamily></fixed>

<bold><bigger>Libertarian presidential candidate: private space launch
shows the Libertarian solution in action</bigger></bold>


AUSTIN, TEXAS =96- Libertarian presidential nominee Michael Badnarik
points to SpaceShipOne=92s successful flight as an example of the power
of the Libertarian solution.


=93SpaceShipOne=92s successful flight shows the world a dramatic example
of how private enterprise outperforms government,=94 declared Badnarik.
=93NASA=92s space plane designs cost enormous amounts of money and took
decades to develop. Free enterprise did the same job better with only
$20 million dollars -- because government is profoundly inefficient
whereas the free market is amazingly efficient.=94


SpaceShipOne=92s launch story perfectly illustrates the Libertarian
principles of strictly limited government, protection of private
property, and the power of free enterprise. Built by famed aircraft
designer Burt Rutan=92s company Scaled Composites, and funded by $20
million from Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, the completely reusable
SpaceShipOne is designed to compete for the $10 million Ansari X
Prize. The contest organizers modeled their challenge after the Orteig
Prize that spurred aviator Lindbergh=92s famous flight. The X Prize
mission statement reads, in part:


=93We believe that spaceflight should be open to all -- not just an
elite cadre of government employees or the ultra-rich. We believe that
commercial forces will bring spaceflight into a publicly affordable
range. We will use our best efforts to achieve this goal.=94


Badnarik also noted how the SpaceShipOne project illustrates the
economic drag of government regulation. =93We had the first space planes
many decades ago. We didn=92t have commercial space flight until today
because of government interference. =46rom harassing high-power rocketry
enthusiasts, to trying to stop Dennis Tito=92s private flight on a
Russian rocket, jealous government bureaucrats have stifled innovation
in space. SpaceShipOne=92s launch shows what private enterprise can do
when government gets out of the way.=94


Former Libertarian presidential candidate Barry Hess and Libertarian
talk radio host Ernest Hancock attended the launch. Rutan reportedly
handed the pilot a sign brought to the launch by Hancock shortly after
the craft landed which read "<italic>SpaceShipOne</italic> -
Government Zero."


Libertarian Party Presidential Nominee Michael Badnarik expects to be
on the ballot in all 50 states, more than Ralph Nader. [For third
party verification contact Richard Winger, Editor, Ballot Access News
- (415) 922-9779]

###

	boundary="=====================_6009671==.ALT"

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Cyberonics' Neuroelectronics Device to Relieve Depression

--=====================_6009671==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



June 18, 2004




Cyberonics' Neuroelectronics Device to Relieve Depression

<http://www.corante.com/brainwaves/archives/003842.html>Neuroelectronics 
device manufacturer <http://www.cyberonics.com/>Cyberonics received 
preliminary approval for a surgical implant to 
<http://www.cyberonics.com/5whatsnew_fs.html>treat severe depression. It is 
the first time an implanted device has been recommended for the treatment 
of a psychiatric disorder.

Using a technique known as <http://www.vnstherapy.com/aboutvnsfs.html>vagus 
nerve stimulation, the implanted device uses electrodes implanted in the 
neck to activate brain regions that are believed to regulate mood. The 
involves connecting a wire to the left vagus nerve in the side of the neck; 
a battery is implanted high in the left chest or under the armpit, and the 
amount of current can be regulated externally. Typically, the implant sends 
a 30-second pulse of current followed by a five-minute pause, 24 hours a day.

The 
<http://www.fda.gov/ohrms/dockets/ac/cdrh04.html#NeurologicalDevices>Neurological 
Devices Panel of FDA's Medical Devices Advisory Committee voted 5 to 2 to 
recommend approval with conditions of Cyberonics' VNS Therapy™ System "as 
an adjunctive long-term treatment of chronic or recurrent depression for 
patients over the age of 18 who are experiencing a major depressive episode 
that has not had an adequate response to four or more adequate 
antidepressant treatments. The stock, CYBX, 
<http://biz.yahoo.com/fool/040616/1087418820_1.html>surged 70% on the news.

While it is clear from the committee's recommendation that several 
<http://www.corante.com/brainwaves/archives/cat_emoticeuticals.html>emoticeuticals 
to treat depression must first be tried, the recommendation highlights an 
important trend in the emerging neurotechnology industry: neuroceutical 
makers and 
<http://www.corante.com/brainwaves/archives/000236.html>neuroelectronics 
manufacturers will increasingly compete for market share as they strive 
towards developing for better tools to treat mental illnesses. Indeed, 
Cyberonics already has pilot studies underway to evaluate 
<http://www.vnstherapy.com/>VNS Therapy as a potential treatment for 
anxiety disorders, Alzheimer's disease and chronic headache/migraine.

Posted by Zack at 6:34 PM

http://www.corante.com/brainwaves/archives/004457.htm



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Squid.com, in conjunction with DJDragnfly.com, Space Monkey, and
MollyMush.com, proudly present.


>> E N G A G E !!! <<


Friday, July 16th 2004
@ Kelly's Mission Rock in San Francisco
This is an 18+ event

This will be an event to remember.  Four crews come together under the same
roof for a single night to impress everyone.

* Four areas of music
* 100% Fully permitted venue
* Two bars for the 21+
* Indoor and Outdoor settings
* Plenty of parking

>MAIN ROOM<
[Booked By Squid.com]

* JON BISHOP
(Tidy Trax, One World, djjonbishop.com)
America's Premier Hard House DJ/ Producer

St John - (Wild 94.9 HouseNation, SoFierce) Felipe Avelar - (Wild 94.9
HouseNation, Select, BR) Dragn'fly - (Shaolin, Audio Metamorphosis,
djdragnfly.com) ("Breaking the Silence" CD Giveaway) MollyMush vs. Valerie
Sparks - (HCFTP, RaveNBeats, k00terk0re) vs. (Femme DJs, Bay Raves)


>DOWNSTAIRS<
[Booked by MollyMush.com]

* GRIDLOK
(p51, Violence, Virus)

Method One - (Method-One.com, Covert Operations, TestFlight Recordings) -
(Special Old Skool Set) CLANDESTINE MASH UP - (Clandestine Club) Shard vs.
Yagi - (OTC, HCFTP) DoubleDay - (Swatchdog Recordings) dj TriZkuT -
(Squid.com)

w/ MC's Ax1om and Fish for the night

 
>FAR DOCK<
[Booked by DJDragnfly.com]

* CHRIS JACKSON
(Resource Records, Jump Recordings, Refined Music)

Productions)

[Booked By Space Monkey]

(F8, Dancing Sprit, Wild 94.9 HouseNation)

Majere - (Elektrosorcery)

Timo - (Space Monkey)
 
 
 
Sound Provided By HARDSCIENCE
 
Tickets available May 21st at the following locations:
*        Solid Grooves (Santa Clara)
*        Skills (Berkeley)
*        Frequency 8 (San Fran)
*        Dimple @ Arden (Sac)
*        In Tha Mix (Sac)
 
Very limited $5 presales are available online at http://www.squid.com
http://www.squid.com/>.  Then prices will go to $10 and then $15.  Door
tickets will be $20.  For the 21+, door prices will be $10 before 10pm.


INFOLINE: 415-356-9845

regions.  Please contact nicholas@blasgen.com for further information.

BayRaves for helping out.

Subject: [sfraves] CD review Danny Howell's 24:7


> I purchased the progressive house/trance/ambient CD Danny Howell's 24:7 a
couple of weeks ago. I've been listening to it ever since. The last 6 tracks
on the "night" disk flow together so smoothly and accend the set so nicely
that I can only call it musical perfection. The first "day" disk is also
filled with down tempo and ambient gems that are sure to create bliss as a
soudtrack to your day to day life. The only negatives are a few filler
tracks that seem to drag in repitition at a couple of points.
>
> I give the album a 8/10 rating and I highly suggest you go buy it today!
>

Date: Tue, 22 Jun 2004 15:53:29 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040622225329.GD3454@hubble>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-F98tu5F8w6ziSx0008a884@hotmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] CD review Danny Howell's 24:7

quoth Van Mundegaarde:
> I wanna hear the Lee Burridge joint - he is a BEAST of a DJ.

Lee Burridge's mix isn't all that great, IMO. The "day" CD is good, a
nice selection of well-mixed house and tech-house, but the "night" CD
does absolutely nothing for me. Progressive crap.

> Speaking of which - when the fuck is TYRANT coming through? They are
> so damn good live.

Fuck yeah, though I prefer Craig Richards on his own. His Fabric 15
double CD mix (actually titled "Tyrant") is THE SHIT. Glitchy, abstract,
deep tech on one disc, and dirty funk and electro on the other. Tracks
by Michael Mayer, Carsten Jost, Falko Brocksieper, Morgan Geist, Joakim,
Ectomorph... you just can't go wrong.

And what's really great about this mix is that all the tracks aren't
limited-release promos that won't be out for years. Most of the stuff is
from the last 4 years, but there are a couple of pre-2000 gems as well
(check the Morgan Geist and Minimal Man tracks--both from '97, but still
*so* relevant!). Highly recommended mind-expanding material, this mix.

-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CD review Danny Howell's 24:7

I picked up this CD when it first came out being a howells fan and I have to 
say I was less then impressed. Of Course the mixng and production was tight 
but the tracks just didnt move me that much. I have the earlier works buy 
him and all his old CD's are just running.. I know this was a bit more 
"Artistic" in the respect of the ambient downtempo-esque house tunes but 
even those are boring (IMO) a good downtempo breaks ambient core type shit 
is Nick warren live in Raykejvit (SP)? GU series. I was a bit disappointed 
with the howells 24/7 matter of fact I only listened to it about 3 times and 
have never played it again. But he is no doubt still the man.

Has anybody heard the double CD by Kazell (sp)? that dood out of LA that is 
supposed to be pretty wicked. Most of the prog boards gave it good reviews 
but I still have not picked up my copy yet.

But the old/new Jedi mind tracks album is ok.. Violent by desing.. Not as 
good as visions of gandhi but ok.

That is about it on the CD front for me thus far..


Mac

From: Starchild <sfdreamer@earthlink.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Message-Id: <1ACAB757-C4A9-11D8-BF3D-003065DA480A@earthlink.net>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.553)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (NRR) Bush administration wants to screen all U.S. citizens for mental illness

Source: http://www.wnd.com/news/article.asp?ARTICLE_ID=3D39078


Bush To Screen Population For Mental Illness

Sweeping initiative links diagnoses to treatment with specific drugs
Posted: June 21, 2004 5:00 p.m. Eastern


=A9 2004 WorldNetDaily.com

President Bush plans to unveil next month a sweeping mental health
initiative that recommends screening for every citizen and promotes
the use of expensive antidepressants and antipsychotic drugs favored
by supporters of the administration.

The New Freedom Initiative, according to a progress report, seeks to
integrate mentally ill patients fully into the community by providing
"services in the community, rather than institutions," the British
Medical Journal reported.

Critics say the plan protects the profits of drug companies at the
expense of the public.

The initiative began with Bush's launch in April 2002 of the New
Freedom Commission on Mental Health, which conducted a "comprehensive
study of the United States mental health service delivery system."

The panel found that "despite their prevalence, mental disorders
often go undiagnosed" and recommended comprehensive mental health=20
screening
for "consumers of all ages," including preschool children.

The commission said, "Each year, young children are expelled from
preschools and childcare facilities for severely disruptive behaviors
and emotional disorders."

Schools, the panel concluded, are in a "key position" to screen the
52 million students and 6 million adults who work at the schools.

The commission recommended that the screening be linked with
"treatment and supports," including "state-of-the-art treatments"
using "specific medications for specific conditions."

The Texas Medication Algorithm Project, or TMAP, was held up by the
panel as a "model" medication treatment plan that "illustrates an
evidence-based practice that results in better consumer outcomes."

The TMAP -- started in 1995 as an alliance of individuals from the
pharmaceutical industry, the University of Texas and the mental
health and corrections systems of Texas -- also was praised by the=20
American
Psychiatric Association, which called for increased funding to
implement the overall plan.

But the Texas project sparked controversy when a Pennsylvania
government employee revealed state officials with influence over the
plan had received money and perks from drug companies who stand to
gain from it.

Allen Jones, an employee of the Pennsylvania Office of the Inspector
General says in his whistleblower report the "political/pharmaceutical
alliance" that developed the Texas project, which promotes the use of
newer, more expensive antidepressants and antipsychotic drugs, was
behind the recommendations of the New Freedom Commission, which were
"poised to consolidate the TMAP effort into a comprehensive national
policy to treat mental illness with expensive, patented medications
of questionable benefit and deadly side effects, and to force private
insurers to pick up more of the tab."

Jones points out, according to the British Medical Journal, companies
that helped start the Texas project are major contributors to Bush's
election funds. Also, some members of the New Freedom Commission have
served on advisory boards for these same companies, while others have
direct ties to TMAP.

Eli Lilly, manufacturer of olanzapine, one of the drugs recommended
in the plan, has multiple ties to the Bush administration, BMJ says. The
elder President Bush was a member of Lilly's board of directors and
President Bush appointed Lilly's chief executive officer, Sidney
Taurel, to the Homeland Security Council.

Of Lilly's $1.6 million in political contributions in 2000, 82
percent went to Bush and the Republican Party.

Another critic, Robert Whitaker, journalist and author of "Mad in
America," told the British Medical Journal that while increased
screening "may seem defensible," it could also be seen as "fishing
for customers."

Exorbitant spending on new drugs "robs from other forms of care such
as job training and shelter program," he said.

However, a developer of the Texas project, Dr. Graham Emslie, defends
screening.

"There are good data showing that if you identify kids at an earlier
age who are aggressive, you can intervene ... and change their
trajectory."

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
If you'd like to sound off on this issue, please take part in the
WorldNetDaily poll.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

rural Texas while publicly asserting your rights under the first ten
amendments to the Constitution.  You'll have terrorists coming out of
your ass."

From: "Steve Osteen"

Subject: [sfraves] CD review Danny Howell's 24:7


> I purchased the progressive house/trance/ambient CD Danny Howell's 24:7 a
couple of weeks ago. I've been listening to it ever since. The last 6 tracks
on the "night" disk flow together so smoothly and accend the set so nicely
that I can only call it musical perfection. The first "day" disk is also
filled with down tempo and ambient gems that are sure to create bliss as a
soudtrack to your day to day life. The only negatives are a few filler
tracks that seem to drag in repitition at a couple of points.
>
> I give the album a 8/10 rating and I highly suggest you go buy it today!
>
> Thanks,
> Steve Osteen
> www.tussinspace.com
>

the present day and voila, the magic of compound interest means you
are a multi-gazillionaire. Then you can just buy a helicopter.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) Bush administration wants to screen all U.S.
 citizens for mental illness


holy fucking brave new world of soma batman.
andyw

On Tue, 22 Jun 2004, Starchild wrote:
-&e->Source: http://www.wnd.com/news/article.asp?ARTICLE_ID=3D39078
-&e->
-&e->
-&e->Bush To Screen Population For Mental Illness
-&e->
-&e->Sweeping initiative links diagnoses to treatment with specific drugs
-&e->Posted: June 21, 2004 5:00 p.m. Eastern
-&e->
-&e->
-&e->=A9 2004 WorldNetDaily.com
-&e->
-&e->President Bush plans to unveil next month a sweeping mental health
-&e->initiative that recommends screening for every citizen and promotes
-&e->the use of expensive antidepressants and antipsychotic drugs favored
-&e->by supporters of the administration.
-&e->
-&e->The New Freedom Initiative, according to a progress report, seeks to
-&e->integrate mentally ill patients fully into the community by providing
-&e->"services in the community, rather than institutions," the British
-&e->Medical Journal reported.
-&e->
-&e->Critics say the plan protects the profits of drug companies at the
-&e->expense of the public.
-&e->
-&e->The initiative began with Bush's launch in April 2002 of the New
-&e->Freedom Commission on Mental Health, which conducted a "comprehensive
-&e->study of the United States mental health service delivery system."
-&e->
-&e->The panel found that "despite their prevalence, mental disorders
-&e->often go undiagnosed" and recommended comprehensive mental health
-&e->screening
-&e->for "consumers of all ages," including preschool children.
-&e->
-&e->The commission said, "Each year, young children are expelled from
-&e->preschools and childcare facilities for severely disruptive behaviors
-&e->and emotional disorders."
-&e->
-&e->Schools, the panel concluded, are in a "key position" to screen the
-&e->52 million students and 6 million adults who work at the schools.
-&e->
-&e->The commission recommended that the screening be linked with
-&e->"treatment and supports," including "state-of-the-art treatments"
-&e->using "specific medications for specific conditions."
-&e->
-&e->The Texas Medication Algorithm Project, or TMAP, was held up by the
-&e->panel as a "model" medication treatment plan that "illustrates an
-&e->evidence-based practice that results in better consumer outcomes."
-&e->
-&e->The TMAP -- started in 1995 as an alliance of individuals from the
-&e->pharmaceutical industry, the University of Texas and the mental
-&e->health and corrections systems of Texas -- also was praised by the
-&e->American
-&e->Psychiatric Association, which called for increased funding to
-&e->implement the overall plan.
-&e->
-&e->But the Texas project sparked controversy when a Pennsylvania
-&e->government employee revealed state officials with influence over the
-&e->plan had received money and perks from drug companies who stand to
-&e->gain from it.
-&e->
-&e->Allen Jones, an employee of the Pennsylvania Office of the Inspector
-&e->General says in his whistleblower report the "political/pharmaceutical
-&e->alliance" that developed the Texas project, which promotes the use of
-&e->newer, more expensive antidepressants and antipsychotic drugs, was
-&e->behind the recommendations of the New Freedom Commission, which were
-&e->"poised to consolidate the TMAP effort into a comprehensive national
-&e->policy to treat mental illness with expensive, patented medications
-&e->of questionable benefit and deadly side effects, and to force private
-&e->insurers to pick up more of the tab."
-&e->
-&e->Jones points out, according to the British Medical Journal, companies
-&e->that helped start the Texas project are major contributors to Bush's
-&e->election funds. Also, some members of the New Freedom Commission have
-&e->served on advisory boards for these same companies, while others have
-&e->direct ties to TMAP.
-&e->
-&e->Eli Lilly, manufacturer of olanzapine, one of the drugs recommended
-&e->in the plan, has multiple ties to the Bush administration, BMJ says. T=
he
-&e->elder President Bush was a member of Lilly's board of directors and
-&e->President Bush appointed Lilly's chief executive officer, Sidney
-&e->Taurel, to the Homeland Security Council.
-&e->
-&e->Of Lilly's $1.6 million in political contributions in 2000, 82
-&e->percent went to Bush and the Republican Party.
-&e->
-&e->Another critic, Robert Whitaker, journalist and author of "Mad in
-&e->America," told the British Medical Journal that while increased
-&e->screening "may seem defensible," it could also be seen as "fishing
-&e->for customers."
-&e->
-&e->Exorbitant spending on new drugs "robs from other forms of care such
-&e->as job training and shelter program," he said.
-&e->
-&e->However, a developer of the Texas project, Dr. Graham Emslie, defends
-&e->screening.
-&e->
-&e->"There are good data showing that if you identify kids at an earlier
-&e->age who are aggressive, you can intervene ... and change their
-&e->trajectory."
-&e->
-&e->~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
-&e->If you'd like to sound off on this issue, please take part in the
-&e->WorldNetDaily poll.
-&e->~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
-&e->
-&e->The biggest lie ever told: "We're from the government, and we're here
-&e->to HELP you."
-&e->
-&e->Ladies and gentlemen, the lunatics are running the nuthouse.
-&e->
-&e->"Wanna see real terrorism? Just 'hole up' in a 'compound' somewhere in
-&e->rural Texas while publicly asserting your rights under the first ten
-&e->amendments to the Constitution.  You'll have terrorists coming out of
-&e->your ass."
-&e->
-&e->

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.618)
