Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) Bush administration wants to screen all U.S. citizens for mental illness

Maybe Bush should be screened first.



On 2004/06/23, at 9:05, Starchild wrote:

> Source: http://www.wnd.com/news/article.asp?ARTICLE_ID=3D39078
>
>
> Bush To Screen Population For Mental Illness
>
> Sweeping initiative links diagnoses to treatment with specific drugs
> Posted: June 21, 2004 5:00 p.m. Eastern
>
>
> =A9 2004 WorldNetDaily.com
>
> President Bush plans to unveil next month a sweeping mental health
> initiative that recommends screening for every citizen and promotes
> the use of expensive antidepressants and antipsychotic drugs favored
> by supporters of the administration.
>
> The New Freedom Initiative, according to a progress report, seeks to
> integrate mentally ill patients fully into the community by providing
> "services in the community, rather than institutions," the British
> Medical Journal reported.
>
> Critics say the plan protects the profits of drug companies at the
> expense of the public.
>
> The initiative began with Bush's launch in April 2002 of the New
> Freedom Commission on Mental Health, which conducted a "comprehensive
> study of the United States mental health service delivery system."
>
> The panel found that "despite their prevalence, mental disorders
> often go undiagnosed" and recommended comprehensive mental health=20
> screening
> for "consumers of all ages," including preschool children.
>
> The commission said, "Each year, young children are expelled from
> preschools and childcare facilities for severely disruptive behaviors
> and emotional disorders."
>
> Schools, the panel concluded, are in a "key position" to screen the
> 52 million students and 6 million adults who work at the schools.
>
> The commission recommended that the screening be linked with
> "treatment and supports," including "state-of-the-art treatments"
> using "specific medications for specific conditions."
>
> The Texas Medication Algorithm Project, or TMAP, was held up by the
> panel as a "model" medication treatment plan that "illustrates an
> evidence-based practice that results in better consumer outcomes."
>
> The TMAP -- started in 1995 as an alliance of individuals from the
> pharmaceutical industry, the University of Texas and the mental
> health and corrections systems of Texas -- also was praised by the=20
> American
> Psychiatric Association, which called for increased funding to
> implement the overall plan.
>
> But the Texas project sparked controversy when a Pennsylvania
> government employee revealed state officials with influence over the
> plan had received money and perks from drug companies who stand to
> gain from it.
>
> Allen Jones, an employee of the Pennsylvania Office of the Inspector
> General says in his whistleblower report the "political/pharmaceutical
> alliance" that developed the Texas project, which promotes the use of
> newer, more expensive antidepressants and antipsychotic drugs, was
> behind the recommendations of the New Freedom Commission, which were
> "poised to consolidate the TMAP effort into a comprehensive national
> policy to treat mental illness with expensive, patented medications
> of questionable benefit and deadly side effects, and to force private
> insurers to pick up more of the tab."
>
> Jones points out, according to the British Medical Journal, companies
> that helped start the Texas project are major contributors to Bush's
> election funds. Also, some members of the New Freedom Commission have
> served on advisory boards for these same companies, while others have
> direct ties to TMAP.
>
> Eli Lilly, manufacturer of olanzapine, one of the drugs recommended
> in the plan, has multiple ties to the Bush administration, BMJ says.=20=

> The
> elder President Bush was a member of Lilly's board of directors and
> President Bush appointed Lilly's chief executive officer, Sidney
> Taurel, to the Homeland Security Council.
>
> Of Lilly's $1.6 million in political contributions in 2000, 82
> percent went to Bush and the Republican Party.
>
> Another critic, Robert Whitaker, journalist and author of "Mad in
> America," told the British Medical Journal that while increased
> screening "may seem defensible," it could also be seen as "fishing
> for customers."
>
> Exorbitant spending on new drugs "robs from other forms of care such
> as job training and shelter program," he said.
>
> However, a developer of the Texas project, Dr. Graham Emslie, defends
> screening.
>
> "There are good data showing that if you identify kids at an earlier
> age who are aggressive, you can intervene ... and change their
> trajectory."
>
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
> If you'd like to sound off on this issue, please take part in the
> WorldNetDaily poll.
> ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
>
> The biggest lie ever told: "We're from the government, and we're here
> to HELP you."
>
> Ladies and gentlemen, the lunatics are running the nuthouse.
>
> "Wanna see real terrorism? Just 'hole up' in a 'compound' somewhere in
> rural Texas while publicly asserting your rights under the first ten
> amendments to the Constitution.  You'll have terrorists coming out of
> your ass."
>
>
>

> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: no lollapalooza :(

I think the lineup is way too backward looking for a festival show. The
old folks (ahem) don't want to battle the crowds all day to see bands
they've most likely seen before. When Lollapalooza started in 91, the
headliners were Jane's Addiction, Ice-T, Nine Inch Nails, Rollins Band...
all acts that were in their prime back then.

This year's headliners were mostly bands from that same era, ie. more than
10 years ago! Even Modest Mouse, whose new album has finally broken
through, have been around since 93. This lineup was put together by
promoters who booked their favorite bands, but they missed the demographic
boat IMO. The fact that Coachella sold out both days for the first time
(50,000 a day @ $75 a pop) goes to show that people will go to big shows,
if you give them something special.

Subject: [sfraves] la dj movie premiere tickets...


we're helping some young film makers with the debut of their movie on the 
25th and we have some extra tix to give away.  it might be something fun if 
you're a fan of the larger dance music scene and independent 
films...especially the renegade temporary drive-in movie aspect:

Enter to win tickets to the premiere of LADJ the Movie by going here: 
http://www.thumpradio.com/index.cfm?eventid=1954

This Friday night be one of the few to see LADJ the Movie in its
entirety, with the producers and actors that made it happen, at the top
level of an undisclosed downtown San Francisco Parking Garage. The
private showing will be done Drive-IN Style with the film projected
onto a large outdoor screen. Each Winner will be admitted with one
vehicle and as many friends as they fit in or on that vehicle. This is
a bring your own refreshments event (Pack it in, Pack it out!)
Afterward, the party continues at Ruby Skye with DJ Dan and more...

LADJ the Movie is about some friends living in a trailer park that
decide to move to Los Angeles to become big time DJ's. Antics and chaos 
unsue. The movie stars, Tim
Scarne and Thomas Ian Nicholas with cameo appearances from DJ Dan, Carl
Cox, Danny Howells and others, promising to be a lot more fun than the
other movies in its genre. For more info 
http://www.thumpradio.com/index.cfm?eventid=1954

plus winners are also get Free Admission into the official party at Ruby 
Skye with Dave Aude and DJ Dan after the movie.

join us at the driiiiiiiiiiive thru.  ;)

>From ‘will you?’ to ‘I do,’ MSN Life Events is your resource for Getting 
Married. http://lifeevents.msn.com/category.aspx?cid=married

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: The Last ATP aka I just took the Red Pill


Just want to give some love to all of you out there that have made my time
spent here that much more enjoyable. I am truly in debt to SFR for allowing
me to connect with all of you and, if nothing else, at least keep things
interesting. The beers enjoyed, tunes shared, conversation's had and the
friendships I have made are truly some of my fondest memories and will be
for some time.

Fate's dealt me a new hand. Wish me luck on my journey's. Perhaps some of
our path's will cross not too far down the line.

Mad love to the Bay and all her children. ;)
--
DJ Jack Triumph

On Tue, Jun 22, 2004 at 09:07:38PM -0700, Dan Haskovec wrote:
> I think the lineup is way too backward looking for a festival show. The
> old folks (ahem) don't want to battle the crowds all day to see bands
> they've most likely seen before. When Lollapalooza started in 91, the
> headliners were Jane's Addiction, Ice-T, Nine Inch Nails, Rollins Band...
> all acts that were in their prime back then.
> 
> This year's headliners were mostly bands from that same era, ie. more than
> 10 years ago! Even Modest Mouse, whose new album has finally broken
> through, have been around since 93. This lineup was put together by
> promoters who booked their favorite bands, but they missed the demographic
> boat IMO. The fact that Coachella sold out both days for the first time
> (50,000 a day @ $75 a pop) goes to show that people will go to big shows,
> if you give them something special.
> 
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: The Last ATP aka I just took the Red Pill

quoth Jack Triumph:
> Fate's dealt me a new hand. Wish me luck on my journey's. Perhaps some
> of our path's will cross not too far down the line.

Good luck with the punctuation! And to commemorate your new life
adventure, here's a collection of classic Jack Triumph quotes.

On women:

> When will women realize that they don't live on the set of a romantic
> comedy? Unless making you smile involves me playing video games while
> you cook me a steak, you're in for a disappointment.

> I happen to have the uncanny ability to massage breasts. With my
> mouth.

On dancing:

> Let's face it: there are few things in this world more stupid than
> dancing. Except break dancing, which pirates and lumber jacks would
> agree is awesome. Other than that, dancing makes me envy cripples.

> I like to dance, and I dj.

On the state of American government:

> 8 years of trickle down politics, open borders, failed social
> programs, focusing on bj's instead of work, and overall bleeding heart
> liberalism got us in this spot folks; Bush didn't create this, he
> inherited it.

On the Iraqi war:

> The UN is a socialist organization hell-bent on passing their own
> agenda.                                                                     

> Have fun finding a cave to hide in. Great deals on Iraqi property
> coming up.

> PS: Almost forgot. I do not car about, nor would I follow the UN
> either. That gets my pal George W major points in my book. If you want
> to preach defiance, there is a feces-infested street corner in SF with
> your name on it.

> I have no problem turning countries into huge Wal-Mart's

> We are not citizens of the world, we are American's. 

On social welfare:

> jesus man, why don't you eat first, then worry about other's. I swear
> and I am having a good laugh at this...it drips with bleeding heart
> mentality...lol. Tell you what, better give em double of what you
> have, can't Jackie ain't throwin' into the pot.

> Eventually I hope you'll come to realize the more you give, the more
> they'll want. Ever fed a starving dog a piece of beef?  Guess what
> happens next.

On himself:

> I see myself as the new wave, no the only one smart ass, but part of
> the new generation.

Thanks for the good times, Jack!

--

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Peyote Case Decided by Utah Supreme Court

--=====================_9716381==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Peyote Case Decided by Utah Supreme Court

Peyote is a psychotropic cactus that has been used as a religious sacrament 
for centuries. Today, the Utah Supreme Court ruled that a federal exemption 
for peyote-using members of the Native American Church must be interpreted 
as applying to non-Indians and Indians alike. Utah's Controlled Substances 
Act incorporates the federal exemption, ruled the court, and because the 
plain language of the federal exemption is not limited to Indians, it must 
be read as applicable to Linda and James Mooney, both of whom are 
non-Indian members of the Native American Church.

<http://en.groundspring.org/en/go?j=4130093&u=17278>>> Read more, including 
the Court's opinion



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

>
>On women:
>
> > When will women realize that they don't live on the set of a romantic
> > comedy? Unless making you smile involves me playing video games while
> > you cook me a steak, you're in for a disappointment.
>
> > I happen to have the uncanny ability to massage breasts. With my
> > mouth.
>
>On dancing:
>
> > Let's face it: there are few things in this world more stupid than
> > dancing. Except break dancing, which pirates and lumber jacks would
> > agree is awesome. Other than that, dancing makes me envy cripples.

> > I like to dance, and I dj.

> > to preach defiance, there is a feces-infested street corner in SF with
> > your name on it.
>
> > I have no problem turning countries into huge Wal-Mart's
>
> > We are not citizens of the world, we are American's.
>
>On social welfare:
>
> > jesus man, why don't you eat first, then worry about other's. I swear
> > and I am having a good laugh at this...it drips with bleeding heart
> > mentality...lol. Tell you what, better give em double of what you
> > have, can't Jackie ain't throwin' into the pot.
>
> > Eventually I hope you'll come to realize the more you give, the more
> > they'll want. Ever fed a starving dog a piece of beef?  Guess what
> > happens next.
>
>On himself:
>
> > I see myself as the new wave, no the only one smart ass, but part of
> > the new generation.
>
>Thanks for the good times, Jack!

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: no lollapalooza :(



I guess I am thinking of the more non-commercial hiphop.. I guess you
could almost call it the "alternative" hiphop... Jurassic 5, Blackalicious,
The Streets, Ray and Christian, ect.

Jurassic 5 was apparently one of the most successful acts of the last
lollapalooza.

Yeah, the bling-bling hiphop is certianly akin to hair metal.  

The term "hip-hop" just casts *way* too wide of a net these days...

-troy

Subject: [sfraves] taking quotes out of context  (nrr)

i had to comment on this out of context quote:

"8 years of trickle down politics, open borders, failed social
> > programs, focusing on bj's instead of work, and overall bleeding heart
> > liberalism got us in this spot folks; Bush didn't create this, he
> > inherited it."

trickle down politics is a Reaganism.  i did not shed a tear when he died.
the southern border of the u.s. is only open one way.  americans can go to
mexico.  mexicans can't come to the U.S.

i like jack too and although he kids a ton and likes to rile people up, i
think he is alot more conservative than me.  politically that is. 
musically he is much more progressive. ;)

don't worry Jack, there aren't any bleedings hearts in arizona.  it's a
state filled with workers.  in fact everyone there works on Martin Luther
King Day.

Jonas

you can tune a piano, but you can't tuna fish.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: no lollapalooza :(

I have an objection to calling bling-bling ghetto trash. First of all,
real ghetto types draw the line at wearing makeup in front of a
camera. Second, Detroit ghetto-tech is ghetto trash, and it is
goooooooooooooooooooooooooooooood.

Bling-bling became the number-one selling genre in 2000, displacing
country for the first time in like thirty years. But there is a
bizarre inexplicable coincidence that makes no sense at all here,
which is that at the same time that this black music owns the
airwaves, if you took a look at black **movies** you'd think the
entire country had gone backwards in time. Soul Plane? How can a movie
like Soul Plane be made at a time when black musicians are making so
much money? Isn't economic power political power?

And why don't black musicians in England make bling-bling, too? Why
are they still churning out jungle and house and garage like everybody
else in England? Can't they see their unique opportunities? Don't they
want to be rich?

I haven't been this confused since I moved to a Chicago ghetto and
found out rap had more listeners in the suburbs of Chicago than it did
in the ghettoes...

I wonder if that's still true today...

---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] taking quotes out of context  (nrr)

	Although Reagan once used the phrase "trickle down," he didn't 
originate or popularize it. His critics jumped on the language as a way 
to ridicule free market concepts such as the Laffer Curve (see 
http://www.investopedia.com/terms/l/laffercurve.asp) that they didn't 
understand (not that Reagan always understood them that well either). 
If anything really deserves to be called "trickle-down economics," it's 
the big government welfare state itself.

	Think about it: Government sucks up a whole bunch of money in taxes, 
then after salaried officials and special interests have taken their 
cut and a certain percentage is simply lost and wasted, the remainder 
"trickles down" to the people via various dignity-destroying and 
conformity-building programs administered by soulless bureaucracies. 
This description fits not only AFDC, Medicare, Social Security and the 
like, but everything from the military to the government schools.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] Breaky tech-house...

------=_NextPart_000_006D_01C45945.60333280
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

How could I forget some of the newer "4xBreak" stuff???

District (which is Meat Katie & Christian J) - they have a couple tracks =
out on KINGSIZE

Meat Katie - The Answer (original & Force mass Motion mixes) - Kingsize =
(really sick acidy tech-house/breaks)

Derrick Carter - Where U At? (Meat Katie & Elite Force mixes) - white =
label (funky chunky style!)

Elite Force - Jack The Joint/Melodik Hypnotik - W9Y (tech-house/breaks)

Hybrid - I'm Still Awake (Christian J/Sud mixes) - Distinctive (the =
Christian J side is a beast!)

Obviously yo can see who in the breaks world is working with =
tech-house/4x4 shit - but it's all really damn good (IMHO). Atomic =
Hooligan does some sjhit that leans more towards a 4x4 beat as well, but =
you have to look around for it (they're on Botchit & Scarper). Aquasky =
is even doing some housier shit these days as well, but often times it's =
either more "electro-house" or just plain ol' funked out house - all =
hard as shit tho.=20

Enjoy!

M-








------=_NextPart_000_006D_01C45945.60333280--

>>> metal orthodontia, and mansions, cars, boats, and helicopters rented  
>>> for
>>> the shoot.

>>> :)

Maybe it's not so much about race, as it is about class... as in:  some 
people have it, and some don't.

I'm not the biggest fan of ANY of those three genres.  But I've got a 
fuck of a lot more respect for the guys producing that music, than I do 
for the ghetto-trash that you see rapping on MTV and such (And yes, 
that includes white ghetto-trash like m&m.).


cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: no lollapalooza :(

	I don't know, I'm not generally a fan of "gangsta rap," but Eminem is 
quite talented imho. His style of rapping really has spawned a lot of 
imitators, and his lyrics are a lot more interesting and intelligent 
than those of the average rapper. I don't like that he still has a lot 
of the ego/tough-guy bullshit typical of the genre, but you have to 
give him credit for putting his fears, vulnerabilities and insecurities 
out there in his music too. And his movie "Eight Mile" is definitely 
worth watching. Some of the MC battle scenes in particular are powerful 
and intense.

Groove on,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: [sfraves] BSP??? an epiphany of sound

I ***THINK*** I'm playing today at 9am on An Epiphany Of Sound at KZSU
90.1FM, broadcasting out of Stanford University and streamable here:

http://kzsulive.stanford.edu/
(channel KZSU-1)

I say "I think" because until about ten minutes ago I was under the
impression that today was Wednesday, not Thursday.

Anyway, tune in, you should be able to hear it. From the home page:

"On a good day, our 500-watt signal reaches from Oakland and parts of
San Francisco in the north, to Fremont and points beyond in the east,
and down to around Gilroy in the south. It's just about the whole Bay
Area -- most of the coverage of commercial stations which broadcast at
50,000 watts and more. KZSU broadcasts in full stereo, and without
much of the compression favored by most Bay Area commercial stations."

-- 
Giles Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com [spiderman]
www.bowkett.net [peter parker]

Only put off until tomorrow what you are willing to die having left undone.
(Pablo Picasso)

PS -- I'll be playing a range of breaks records, from funky to techy,
with a good strong dose of British-Jamaican styles thrown in for good
measure, including that "Hot Stepper" Ini Kmoze bootleg I was drooling
so much about a while back. Depending on how friendly the KZSU CDJs
turn out to be, I might work in a few original tracks, including a
political hip-hop instrumental that samples George Bush, and possibly
some other material as well. Boh! And stuff.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] was: OT:  Damn...I HATE DJ Seven... Is: NRR: Spam

Here's some info on the CAN SPAM ACT of 2003:

http://www.spamlaws.com/federal/108s877.html


The enrolled (final) text of S. 877 as it was passed by the Senate on 
November 25, 2003, and agreed to by the House of Representatives on 
December 8, 2003, appears below (also available in PDF).  The bill was 
signed by the President on December 16, 2003, and takes effect on January 
1, 2004.

The final text of the bill is very similar to that approved by the House 
of Representatives on November 22, 2003 (available here), with relatively 
minor technical corrections. The version of the bill that was approved by 
the Senate on October 22, 2003, is available here, and the original text 
of the bill as it was introduced on April 10, 2003, is here.

http://www.spamlaws.com/federal/108s877enrolled.pdf
http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d108:s.00877:
http://www.whitehouse.gov/news/releases/2003/12/20031216-4.html
http://www.wilsonweb.com/wmt9/canspam_comply.htm
http://www.gripe2ed.com/scoop/story/2003/11/24/02356/143
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Can_Spam_Act_of_2003

In a Nutshell, ...

"...Can Spam Act of 2003
>From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia.

The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003, signed into law by President Bush on December 
16, 2003, establishes the first national standards for the sending of 
commercial e-mail and requires the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to 
enforce its provisions. The bill's full name is an acronym: Controlling 
the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act of 2003.

It also requires the FTC to promulgate rules to shield consumers from 
unwanted mobile service commercial messages.

The bill permits e-mail marketers to send unsolicited commercial e-mail as 
long as it contains all of the following:

     * an opt-out mechanism;
     * a functioning return e-mail address;
     * a valid subject line indicating it is an advertisement; and
     * the legitimate physical address of the mailer.

The legislation also prohibits the sale or other transfer of an e-mail 
address obtained through an opt-out request. It criminalizes the use of 
automated means to register for multiple e-mail accounts from which to 
send spam. It prohibits sending sexually-oriented spam without clear 
markings.

It pre-empts existing state anti-spam laws, and makes it a misdemeanor to 
send spam with falsified header information. It sets out civil penalties 
for a host of other common spamming practices used to obtain e-mail 
addresses, including harvesting, dictionary attacks, Internet protocol 
spoofing, hijacking computers through Trojan horses or worms, or using 
open mail relays for the purpose of sending spam..."

<3 Karina

Troy,

	First of all, Eminem isn't always talking about bling-bling the way a  
lot of rappers are. His name came up not in connection with that, but  
with the "ghetto-trash" label -- which I thought would have provided a  
lot more fuel to anyone wanting to make a prejudice issue out of any of  
this, but anyway...

	Second, there's a whole long list of black hip hop artists whose music  
and talent I appreciate: Public Enemy, Too Short, Grandmaster Flash,  
RUN-DMC, Dr. Dre, Ice T, Ice Cube, LL Cool J, Queen Latifah, Will  
Smith, Eric B & Rakim, Notorious BIG, De La Soul, Conscious Daughters,  
etc. But we weren't talking about them.

	If someone had been dissing Eminem for being materialist while  
praising lots of black rappers pushing the same image, and you had  
reason to believe most of the folks on this list were black, I doubt  
you would have said something like "Ya'll a bunch of black boys on this  
list, dissin' white bling bling but praising black bling bling. Yeah,  
it's all cool, as long as it's a nigga making the cash."

	No, I don't think you would've have said that. But you probably think  
it's OK to say what you said, because accusing white people of racism  
is more politically correct. There's more social protection for making  
that accusation. And apparently you'd rather jump to slanderous  
conclusions than ask more and find out.

Tired of such nonsense,
						<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP??? an epiphany of sound

God that was fun! Not particularly skilled on my part, but fun all the same.

Actually...self-indulgent DJ self-analysis begins here...recommend
skipping if easily bored:

Long time ago a DJ friend told me I was DJing wrong, said I needed to
get the mix right in the headphones and then bring it in with the
faders, instead of doing what I do normally, which is just play by ear
the whole time (literally), throwing a record ahead or pulling it back
whenever the hell I feel like it. Every single trainwreck I did today,
and there were a lot, came about when I followed that guy's advice,
whoever he was. (It's been a long time, I forgot who it was, all I
remember is he got more gigs than I did so I figured he knew what he
was talking abt. And actually he probably did, but true for him and
true for me are different kinds of true.)

Anyway. Self-indulgent yadda yadda over! JC thanks a ton, apologies
for getting there late but I hadn't been to the radio station in abt 5
years and I've never gotten out of bed that early in my life before!
In fact I just woke up from a nap.

-- 
Giles Soundwave
www.djsoundwave.com [spiderman]
www.bowkett.net [peter parker]

Only put off until tomorrow what you are willing to die having left undone.
(Pablo Picasso)

At 08:30 PM 6/23/2004, John B. wrote:
>Maybe it's not so much about race, as it is about class... as in:  some 
>people have it, and some don't.
>
>I'm not the biggest fan of ANY of those three genres.  But I've got a fuck 
>of a lot more respect for the guys producing that music, than I do for the 
>ghetto-trash that you see rapping on MTV and such (And yes, that includes 
>white ghetto-trash like m&m.).
>
>
>cya,
>john


tat...tat....tat...tat...tat.  Ah, john, Eminem is not from the "ghetto," 
although he has carefully constructed this marketable image.  I know your 
thinking well enough, I hope, to assume you don't equate ghetto with 
trash.  I'm not sure what you mean by "class."

Back to the hip hop context.  Perhaps we should make a distinction between 
what I see as pop hop and genuine hip hop.

Hip hop's origins go back to the seventies and the genre grew up right 
along with disco, punk, glam rock and, later, house.  One really can't 
equate the likes of Eminem, 50 Cent, and Nelly (MTV pop hop) with hip hop 
greats like Public Enemy, the Sugerhill Gang, Africa Bambaataa, Grand 
Master Flash, and A Tribe Called Quest to name a few.  What differentiates 
pop hop from hip hop?

Pop hop is the child of corporate marketing and "targeted" music 
programming.  This stuff arose in the nineties.   I would think that those 
of you who worship our economic system and resultant philosophy of life 
would be avid pop hop fans:)  From what I can gather from pop hop lyrics, 
the meaning of life, the good life, is:  making lots of money;  buying an 
acceptable ride;  dressing in flash clothes and esoteric shoes;  and doing 
whatever needs to be done to assure this lifestyle.  That's really the 
consensus reality of America right now for many, is it not?  The drug 
dealer is the quintessential entrepreneur -- no ethics, no compassion, a 
Darwinian money-making machine.  Then there is the sex.  Since the market 
for pop music is teenagers one layers on steamy sexuality, with a 
misogynistic, often homophobic cast that is especially appealing to teenage 
males.  Pop hop artists sell clothing lines, accessories, and must have 
footwear.  Big bucks.  Sharp marketing.

Music that arises from marketing research and corporate manipulation, 
however, becomes stale rather quickly.  Thus, the growing boredom with much 
popular music beyond pop hop and the decline of events like 
Lollapalooza.  The decline in CD sales has little to do with downloading, 
IMO.  People are tired of paying for programmed mediocrity.  One of the 
bright spots in CD and music sales, I understand, is sixties rock purchased 
by those in their early teens.

Hip hop, on the other hand, was and is not a carefully crafted marketing 
device.  Much early hip hop was politically radical and arose from the 
frustrations of an oppressed minority.  It had, and still has, the edgy 
feel of authentic punk and early rock.  For every Eminem there are hundreds 
of "underground" hip hop artists of high quality making and distributing 
music outside the system -- some literally on street corners.  There is a 
vibrant hip hop community in the Bay Area that bears no resemblance 
whatsoever to the materialistic, corporate pop hop scene.

Love,

Apollo





Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Your License, Your Urine




By Paul Armentano, AlterNet
Posted on June 21, 2004, Printed on June 24, 2004
http://www.alternet.org/story/19008/

Imagine if it were against the law to drive home after consuming a single 
glass of wine at dinner. Now imagine it is illegal to drive after having 
consumed a single glass of wine two weeks ago. Guess what? If you smoke 
pot, it's time to stop imagining.

Legislation weaving its way through the US Congress demands all 50 states 
pass laws granting police the power to drug test drivers and arrest anyone 
found to have "any detectable amount of a controlled substance ... present 
in the person's body, as measured in the person's blood, urine, saliva, or 
other bodily substance." Though the expressed purpose of the law is to 
target and remove drug-impaired drivers from US roadways, the proposal 
would do nothing of the sort.

Continued:

http://www.alternet.org/drugreporter/19008/



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

	I could give a damn if someone is from the ghetto or not. I =
don't care=20
how many copies their records sell. And I don't care if they're=20
distributed through Warner Brothers or by standing out on a street=20
corner hawking tapes (OK, maybe I care a little bit about that, but not=20=

much). What primarily matters is whether the music sounds good or not.

	Substance, sure, we can talk about that too. Based on the lyrics =
of=20
the following two classic tracks, one from Eminem and one from Afrika=20
Bambaata (see below), which would you say "has, the edgy feel of=20
authentic punk and early rock?" Which one seems more about just getting=20=

a groove on, in a straight-up, pop/dance music style? Make your own=20
call.

Groove on,
					<<< Starchild >>>

P.S. - Get your Afrika Bambaata t-shirts here, only $22.=20
http://www.fabric8.com/bazaar/product.f8ml?PID=3DRZ0100. I remember when=20=

those continent-of-Africa-shaped necklaces like he has on were quite=20
popular too...

P.P.S. - I'm not trying to hate on Afrika or say pop/disco/house/funk=20
is bad. He seems to be generally regarded as a good guy with integrity.=20=

But trying to slam pop music and flashy style by holding up someone as=20=

an example who leaned more in that direction than the guy you're=20
dissing, or portray one as commercial and the other not, makes no sense.

On Thursday, June 24, 2004, at 03:16  PM, Apollo wrote:

> tat...tat....tat...tat...tat.  Ah, john, Eminem is not from the=20
> "ghetto," although he has carefully constructed this marketable image.=20=

>  I know your thinking well enough, I hope, to assume you don't equate=20=

> ghetto with trash.  I'm not sure what you mean by "class."
>
> Back to the hip hop context.  Perhaps we should make a distinction=20
> between what I see as pop hop and genuine hip hop.
>
> Hip hop's origins go back to the seventies and the genre grew up right=20=

> along with disco, punk, glam rock and, later, house.  One really can't=20=

> equate the likes of Eminem, 50 Cent, and Nelly (MTV pop hop) with hip=20=

> hop greats like Public Enemy, the Sugerhill Gang, Africa Bambaataa,=20
> Grand Master Flash, and A Tribe Called Quest to name a few.  What=20
> differentiates pop hop from hip hop?
>
> Pop hop is the child of corporate marketing and "targeted" music=20
> programming.  This stuff arose in the nineties.   I would think that=20=

> those of you who worship our economic system and resultant philosophy=20=

> of life would be avid pop hop fans:)  =46rom what I can gather from =
pop=20
> hop lyrics, the meaning of life, the good life, is:  making lots of=20
> money;  buying an acceptable ride;  dressing in flash clothes and=20
> esoteric shoes;  and doing whatever needs to be done to assure this=20
> lifestyle.  That's really the consensus reality of America right now=20=

> for many, is it not?  The drug dealer is the quintessential=20
> entrepreneur -- no ethics, no compassion, a Darwinian money-making=20
> machine.  Then there is the sex.  Since the market for pop music is=20
> teenagers one layers on steamy sexuality, with a misogynistic, often=20=

> homophobic cast that is especially appealing to teenage males.  Pop=20
> hop artists sell clothing lines, accessories, and must have footwear. =20=

> Big bucks.  Sharp marketing.
>
> Music that arises from marketing research and corporate manipulation,=20=

> however, becomes stale rather quickly.  Thus, the growing boredom with=20=

> much popular music beyond pop hop and the decline of events like=20
> Lollapalooza.  The decline in CD sales has little to do with=20
> downloading, IMO.  People are tired of paying for programmed=20
> mediocrity.  One of the bright spots in CD and music sales, I=20
> understand, is sixties rock purchased by those in their early teens.
>
> Hip hop, on the other hand, was and is not a carefully crafted=20
> marketing device.  Much early hip hop was politically radical and=20
> arose from the frustrations of an oppressed minority.  It had, and=20
> still has, the edgy feel of authentic punk and early rock.  For every=20=

> Eminem there are hundreds of "underground" hip hop artists of high=20
> quality making and distributing music outside the system -- some=20
> literally on street corners.  There is a vibrant hip hop community in=20=

> the Bay Area that bears no resemblance whatsoever to the=20
> materialistic, corporate pop hop scene.
>
> Love,
>
> Apollo
>
>
>
>
>
> Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org
>
> House Music 101: =20
> http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm
>
>
> "I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and=20
> causes me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the=20=

> war, corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high=20=

> places will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor=20=

> to prolong its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people=20
> until all wealth is aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is=20
> destroyed."
> -Abraham Lincoln
>
> "Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of=20=

> the rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will=20
> gradually become visible."
> -Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"
>
>  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects=20=

> of life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on=20=

> the beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no=20=

> club, party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything=20
> close to that..."
> -Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

--Apple-Mail-4-289704547--

	The United States Senate voted this week to increase the penalties for  
violations by television and radio broadcasters of the prohibitions  
against transmission of "obscene," "indecent," and "profane" language.  
The bill raises the amount of fines that can be imposed not just  
against companies but against individual DJs as well up to $3 million  
per offense.

	The sole member of the Senate to vote against this disgusting attack  
on free speech was John Breaux, a conservative Democrat from Louisiana.  
Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, who has missed 90% of his votes  
this year in the Senate, decided not to miss this one and voted for it.  
CSPAN has the record of the vote here:

http://capwiz.com/c-span/issues/votes/ 
?votenum=134&chamber=S&congress=1082

For liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>
--Apple-Mail-8-298897931--

From: John B. <SvnLyrBrto@yahoo.com>
Date: Thu, 24 Jun 2004 21:08:16 -0700

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: no lollapalooza :(..and hip hop


On Jun 24, 2004, at 3:16 PM, Apollo wrote:
> I hope, to assume you don't equate ghetto with trash.  I'm not sure 
> what you mean by "class."

Not by a long shot.  By "class", I mean something more nebulous than 
someone's net worth.  I know poor people who live in "the getto" who 
have far more class than many rich people.  To me, "class" is something 
more about how you conduct yourself, self-respect, and respect for 
others.  Suffice it to say, the glorification of violence, the 
misogyny, the homophobia, and a long list of other issues endemic to 
today's rap, demonstrate a total lack of "class", IMO.

> hip hop greats like Public Enemy, the Sugerhill Gang, Africa 
> Bambaataa, Grand Master Flash, and A Tribe Called Quest to name a few. 
>  What differentiates pop hop from hip hop?

Don't forget Run DMC, Biz Markie, and of course, the Beastie Boys.  
It's not that I hate ALL rap...  just what it's become today.

Come to think of it, everyone on your list, and my own additions, got 
their start in the '80s.  And I actually DO like a LOT of '80s rap.  
But there seems to be a period, somewhere in the early to mid '90s when 
rap changed.  It was no longer a good time and good music.  It was no 
longer about fighting for your right to party, busting a move, walking 
this way, and how parents just don't understand.  It was no longer 
happy and fun.

Somewhere, in those early to mid '90s, it became about who's the 
baddest MF-er, popping caps in asses, doing all the chronic you can, 
smacking the bitches and hoes, living in a gangster's paradise, and so 
on.  Not too long after, rap began to look like a bad parody of 1920's 
mafioso...  Stupid, contemptible, hateful lyrics became stupid, 
contemptible, hateful behavior.  You've got east-coast rappers shooting 
at west-coast rappers, and vice versa, rap labels being run out of 
prison cells, rap "artists" running around with big "posses" of thugs 
to beat people up FOR them, and ghetto-trash showing at rap shows with 
guns (And, oh yeah, carrying a gun in public makes them trash, 100%, no 
exceptions.), shooting at each other, and screwing things up for 
EVERYONE, even those of us who, otherwise, wouldn't give 2 shits about 
the rap scene.  (Witness the closure of that Campbell venue, and the 
cancellation of that dance-music thing at Great America a while back, 
for examples.)

For a good example of which rap groups have class, and which don't:  
Remember the Tibetan Freedom Festivals?  A project of The Beastie Boys, 
they were.  Can you imagine m&m, sugar knight, the notorious big, snoop 
doggy dog, 50 cent, or any of their ilk putting something like that 
together not for their personal gain, but to help the denizens of an 
oppressed nation that most Americans probably can't find on a map?  I 
sure can't.

Sure, put Grand Master Flash on stage with the Sugarhill Gang and 
Africa Bambaataa, follow it up with Run DMC and the Beasties, and I'll 
happily go, and scrounge my bottom dollar for the privilege.

Fill a stage with the trash that constitutes post-mid-'90s rappers?  
Not a chance.


cya,
john


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Kerry votes to increase penalties for "obscene" speech on TV and radio

wow, congress passes a bill that changes the penalties
from the origional 1934 penalties to something a
little more fiscally current along with actually
holding the person saying such words or showing such
images responsible. OH THE HORROR!!!

i didn't see anything in there (thow, i don reed sew
goud, sew i kooda mist it) that changed the policies
of anything. i'm pretty sure "free speech" and "free
language" are two diffent things. if you can't get yer
point across without offending someone (based on
choice of words, rather than view), yer probably
speaking the wrong language. try french, then no one
will care what you say so you can say anything you
want anyway.

and it's not 3 million an offense, at the most it's
$500,000 per offense. i doth qoute: "the amount of
forfeiture penalty shall not exceed $275,000 for the
first violation, $375,000 for the second, and $500,000
for the third and any subsequent violation, with a
24-hour period limit of $3 million." that's 6
violations in 24 hours. oh and it: "Requires the FCC,
when determining a penalty, to consider the violator's
ability to pay."

i'm pretty sure that college radio dj's won't be
gettin jacked for 3 mil. although, if yer at stanford,
hmmmmm.

damn the french are dumb. and i get to say that since
i'm part french. i hate me.............d'j...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] BSP...fLOORCRAfT, Iyad & J.C. at 1015 this Friday...guestlist

Yes, 1015 is trying to transform. And we'll be helping. Beginning this
Friday, FREEFORM will be hosting the upstairs VIP room one Friday a
month. They're wanting to work their magic and play their part in
transforming 1015 back into a kick-ass club! As such, this Friday will
feature Iyad, Floorcraft and J.C., as well as YOU! And in the main room
it's none other than Max Graham (http://www.spundae.com/fls/sf4.html).

It's only with YOUR help that we can see 1015 return to it's days of
old! Join us Friday as we begin that journey!

There is a way for you to get on the guestlist to receive half price
admission (only $10) by emailing either floorcraft@progressiveflow.com
or iyad@progressiveflow.com no later than Friday at 4pm. The half off
price is good until 12 midnight. ALSO, it is FREE to get in B4 10:30, so
if you arrive early enough, you won't have to pay!

Hope to see lots of you there!

Subject: [sfraves] turntable help. please?

ok, so i've been noticing that my mixes at home have been majorly sucking at 
times, so i decided to blame it all on my turntables.  however, upon close 
inspection, i believe the problem IS my tables!

one of my 1210mk2s, when the pitch is set close to zero, tends to nudge 
itself forward in small, random intervals.  i noticed because i stared at 
the red LED and watched the little dots move by themselves.

anyhow, does this mean my tables need tuning?  could fluctuations in my 
electrical current be a cause (our wiring in our place is old and shotty).  
any other suggestions?

I have a deck that does this occasionally.  Its about 20 years old and
I'm too lazy to get it fixed so when it starts acting the fool I just
spray some lube in there.  I don't have the stuff in front of me.. but
there are a number of products designed to lubricate electrical parts
like the pitch control.  I'm sure someone on here knows the best kind to
get.  When its all lubed up it works just fine...

Breast wishes,
p a t

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

From sfraves-return-113558-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Jun 25 22:41:16 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113558-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 32425 invoked by uid 1103); 25 Jun 2004 22:41:14 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 32411 invoked from network); 25 Jun 2004 22:41:14 -0000
Date: Fri, 25 Jun 2004 15:41:10 -0700
From: Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org>
To: Eleanor Judis <ellerockit@yahoo.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <20040625224110.GE10910@cloudfactory.org>
Mail-Followup-To: Eleanor Judis <ellerockit@yahoo.com>,
	sfraves@hyperreal.org
References: <20040625202910.74270.qmail@web52106.mail.yahoo.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <20040625202910.74270.qmail@web52106.mail.yahoo.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] CDJ/mp3js vs. Vinyl>give me your comments/opinions- djs and such-

Eleanor Judis <ellerockit@yahoo.com> said...
> how do you feel about Final Scratch and the whole cdj/mp3j
> phenomenon?  bad for vinyl diggers/collectors/producers or great
> for not having to lug around records and wear out a gem?  great
> for more people to play out their music or destroying the dj rep? 
>  
> any feedback would be great. email me back, full name and city if
> you dont mind but not necesary. 

The visceral hands-on interface to digital music is going to
get a lot better. The "works like a turntable" top of the line
digital players are getting close to turntable ability. At
some point, they're going to surpass and eventually blow away
turntables for their ability to manipulate sound, their ease
of use, and other features that will allow DJs to be that much
more effective.

As this happens, more and more people are going to see a lot of
advantages over vinyl, and will start using more digital formats.

Beatmatching is going to get nearly automatic. Interfaces will
improve, and allow one to dig into a huge music library with
ease. Software is going to show you a pretty track layout while
it's playing. Mixes will get a lot more creative as anticipating
that killer drop 32 measures ahead will be cake.

(Hey, anyone wanna fund me to design the killer interface??? :))

I don't think the DJ rep is going to be destroyed. Oh, yeah,
there will be a lot more "DJs", that's for sure. We'll be as
saturated with bad DJs as we currently are with bad tracks.

DJing has almost nothing to do with technical skills though,
and everything about the very black art of working a groove and a
crowd at the same time. Almost any dufus can learn to beatmatch,
but reliably making a crowd dance and scream is still something
not that many, even here in the bay area, can do.

The future...

What if a track was released in a multi-track common format that
was very amenable to remixing and other tweaking? What if you
wanted to mix in, but precisely kill the new drums and haul over
just *then*? What if a remixing console gave you the ability
to do this on the fly? What if there were several alternate
drumlines you could use? What if this was REALLY easy to use?

I think there will always be room to expand one's skills and
ability to manipulate a groove. At some point, anyone will be
able to beatmatch (I bet tracks will be released with beat
markers to make this perfect). But the people with serious
skill and creativity are going to have tools to do awesome
one-of-a-kind performances. They're going to be manipulating
tracks and your ass and good DJing will still be the art it
always was.

And there will still be vinyl :). But digital is going to be
a big wonderful world of sound and manipulation to play in.

Sean
(Berzerkley)

outdoor day party on Treasure Island. Come dance in the sun to
celebrate how lucky we are to live in this beautiful place.

DJ Luke with Steve M on guitar * House Live PA *
Pyd Piper * Trance *
Phaedrus (Moksha/HIProject) * Drum n Bass *

turntables, mixers, laptops, keyboards and other fun things. We're
doing this because we love music and people and people who love music.

afternoon with us!

Oh yeah.. while i was @ school, i checked my email & saw Lunatic on there.. hmmmmm.. so @ the risk of not sleeping 'til I get home @ &M bu missing the last commute 2 Hercules, I stayed 2 check out Li & Andy spin @ Luna Lounge... unfortunaely, I was havin' suck a Groovy time hangin' out w/ the Jungle DJ homies, that i lost track of time & got 2 Luna only 2 C Li spin.. oh well... & from what Chris told me, Andy's set was yummy w/ some 80's booty music & stuff.. grrrrrr.. oh well.. I'll catch him spin that another time...

But Li's set was Sick.. YUMMY.. ok.. he played some Acid breaks & some Future from what I could tell.. but man.. alota his shit was just I dunno... broken 4 a lack of a better term.. LoL.. BUt it was Groovy!!  I Loved it!  NOt 2 many peple were there lastnight, but i'm sure there wil be soon!

So then I walked over 2 Urban Montage.. Good shit man.. ooooooh my goodness.. I Love it... I mean... I Lov3 seein' any varied portion of my Jungle Fam & when we're all 2gether man.. I Love.. I mean.. the vibe is Dope 'cause there's bad ass DJs on the decks.. la la la, I mean.. I'm sayin'  this gooey shit 'cause well.. as soon as i got down stairs, fuck man.. the vibe was just soooooo dammn thick * the energy was fuckin' ooh yeah.. lastnight.. Rando was on.. but i missed his set though..ooops... but caught this Groovy tag set w/ Sharp & Mal... it was fun man!  I mean.. they threw in hella yummy surprises in their set.. it Was SO Dope!

It was Bad Ass 'cause Audio Angel & The Colonel were on on the mics, yes, 2 MC @ the same time, it was fuckin' Grreat.. Loved it!  As always, Ms. Angel scared me when i 1st got in 'cause she said my name & I heard it over the speakers.  LoL

It was fun.. I was all wearing my Top Hat lastnight 'cause well.. i ain't wore it in a long time, so it was time 2 wear it last night... hmmm.. it was a groovy accesorie, I think i may wear it again 2n ight.. la la la...

OK.. I Love U all!!!  See whoever's out this weekend!!!  Good shit.. so many things 2 do..

Fun Fun Fun
Take Care,
Peace-> O§bY {8O)

Date: Fri, 25 Jun 2004 17:21:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Sean Casey <sean@cloudfactory.org>
cc: "Brandon S." <invibe@hotmail.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20040625215937.GC10910@cloudfactory.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0406251714050.12375-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] turntable help. please?


Probably a dirty pitch slider.

No, it's not power fluctuations.  I've run decks off of really bad power,
the sound system is browning out, the lights will stop working, but
the mix still sticks.

Hit the slider with the Caig stuff.

If it's near your 0 point, it's likely that you're drifting between the
pitch being locked and not locked (looking at the platter dots, is it
going from perfectly motionless to a slight drift?).  Basic zero adjust
(the easiest service to do on 1200s, you can do it yourself) should help
or fix it altogether.  Also, get in the habit of leaving your tables at 0
lock when not playing them.  That way, any wear at the point the slider is
left at is at a point where it's not being used.

Those things are surprisingly durable.  Mine have been to at least a 100
parties/outdoors/clubs/houseparties and never have required service.  I've
pitched them up and down again (although ALWAYS TURN OFF THE DECK WHEN YOU
TAKE OFF THE PLATTER... you can kill a 1200 that way), and they feel
better than when I brought them home new.

vinyl, whoooo!
andyw

-&e->> the red LED and watched the little dots move by themselves.
-&e->>

-&e->

bigger picture which is....

These people DON'T LIKE US and want to legislate us out of existence.

They are well on the way to doing so, and it makes no difference what
their party affiliation is

wedding, partygoers commented on how chill the cops were being, and i
was like, of course they are, they got that shite in their back
pocket, now, and they know it, so why get all aggro?

books, which is why last year's ROAR protest was so *pointless,* is
that somebody has to get ARRESTED and then take it all the way up to
the US Supreme Court.

Who wants to go first?

It'll be 20 years before this law goes away, unless America undergoes
a pretty radical shift, starting like, right now, and it needs to run
significantly deeper than just putting bush out of office, or going to
see Michael Moore's latest.

in this year's State of the Union Address to combat steroid use, now
did you?

That's because they want to keep the populace drugged up on their

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A Democrat introduced the anti-rave RAVE act (was: [sfraves] poof! nrr)

1. Democrats vs Republicans:

I used to think they were equally bad. Then Bush got elected.

I mean come on. Schwarzenegger believes we're not killing puppies fast
enough. Republicans are EVIL.

That being said, it'd be kinda cool, in a sick and wrong way, if Bush
won the election legitimately this time, instead of stealing it like
he did last time, AND that happened because Nader ran and got a ton of
votes AGAIN. These guys lost the election because they weren't liberal
enough. Then they run another neo-conservative? What are they fucking
stupid?

2. Gay marriage:

I realize nobody actually brought it up, but we were on politics, so:
I believe the gay marriage issue is really a separation of church and
state issue. When all those anti-gay-marriage oafs go on TV spouting
this and that, the term "sanctity" is inevitably raised, by them.
Sanctity is a matter of religion, not of government. If those people
are telling the truth, and the issue for them is the sanctity of
marriage, then obviously it means that the issue is a religious issue,
and government has no place in the matter at all. If your religion or
set of spiritual beliefs sanctifies same-sex unions, then they have
sanctity; and if not, then you must simply agree to live and let live.
Since the separation of church and state is one of the founding
principles of this country, laws protecting the alleged sanctity of
specific types of marriage are probably unconstitutional and certainly
anti-American.

-- 
Giles Soundwave

www.bowkett.net [peter parker]

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A Democrat introduced the anti-rave RAVE act (was: [sfraves] poof! nrr)

OK, I have to throw in on this one- to me it's not so much about
people's true intents, it's about what their party dictates that they
do.  Bush is a Republican.  The GOP is based upon a policy of sticking
to old traditions, lowered spending on social services, a
not-in-my-backyard attitude, and looking with a suspicious eye upon
youth culture.  The Democrats, liberal though they may not be at
current, are bound to a policy of tolerance, celebration of diversity,
and a more "youthful" attitude.

That doesn't mean a hip young rep couldn't come along and change all
that, or that the neo-con dems currently skulking around aren't fast
eroding what one thinks of when the term "liberal" comes to mind.

However, at the end of the day, if Bush says, "We are going to drill
for oil in Alaska and push for more clearcutting in the northwest",
nobody is surprised.  This is classic conservative policy- take what
America needs to sustain its lifestyle and worry about the
political/environmental repercussions later.  

If Kerry gets into office and immediately says, "I want to loosen
regulations on greenhouse gases and cut prisoner-for-oil deals with
hostile nations", his consituents, nay, his entire party, would jump to
counter him.  That's just "not how Democrats act", right?

So even ignoring individual actions, there is a certain amount of
security in the party of one's choice.  Tenuous though it may seem,
there's a tangible link between the graven-in-stone philosophies of
each party, and the course of action the leaders who identify with them
must take.

Can you imagine the shitstorm if Bush were to free a bunch of drug
offenders in his lame-duck period, or help to vote in a piece of
pro-abortion legislature?  He'd be absolutely toast- much the same way
a liberal candidate would be if they chose to continue on in the
current path, business as usual once they took office.

In choosing between two dishonest, dubiously-qualified people to head
my country, I'll choose the one backed by the left every time.  It's a
sad choice, but a neccesary one.

..and jesus christ, Nader..  A lesson is a lesson but if you help Bush
into office again..  Ooh boy.  A pair of pliers and a blowtorch are too
good for you. ;)

(just kidding)

George C
www.djorigami.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A Democrat introduced the anti-rave RAVE act (was: [sfraves] poof! nrr)

	There's a political expression that says "Only Nixon can go to China." 
It means that only someone who is trusted by opponents of something has 
the political ability to get away with doing that very thing. For 
example, look at how government spending has gone up faster under Bush 
than it did under Clinton. Look how Bush has proposed spending billions 
of dollars for things like fighting AIDS in Africa. If a Democrat had 
done these things, Republicans would be raising a shitstorm, but 
because it's happened under "one of their own," they let Bush get away 
with it.

	Similarly Bush would be more likely to be criticized for the actions 
you mention below than Kerry, because the opponents of those 
environmental policies already hate Bush. If Kerry were to do something 
like propose more clearcutting, many leftists would give him a pass 
because they wouldn't want to undermine what they considered a 
"friendly" administration. He would find a clever way of justifying it 
to them, and they'd want to believe his explanation.

	Because leaders of both establishment parties put power and political 
expediency over principle, you can't really count on Kerry to act like 
an honest liberal once in office any more than Republicans have been 
able to count on Bush behaving like an honest conservative.

	If you're a leftist, you ought to vote for the Green Party candidate 
(who will probably be David Cobb). Forget Nader, he's running as an 
independent -- building the Green Party will better advance left-wing 
interests in the long term. If you're a conservative, vote for Michael 
Peroutka of the Constitution Party. He's much more of a real 
conservative than Bush. And if you want social tolerance and less 
government, vote for Libertarian Michael Badnarik.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] A Democrat introduced the anti-rave RAVE act (was: [sfraves] poof! nrr)

	For those who've said in the past that I promote the Libertarian Party 
too much, well, this is Exhibit A of why it's necessary. Many people 
are so fixed on thinking of Bush and Kerry as their only choices that 
even after everything I've posted, all it takes is one message 
criticizing a Democrat for me to be mistaken for a Bush supporter! For 
the record, yes I think Bush deserves a second term -- but this one in 
jail instead of the White House. Preferably with Bill Clinton as his 
cellmate.

	My recommendation is vote Libertarian -- Michael Badnarik for 
President (http://www.badnarik.org). Michael expects to be on the 
ballot in at least 48 states, more than Ralph Nader or any other 
candidate except Bush and Kerry. Hopefully he'll be on in all 50 if the 
party wins our lawsuits against the fucked-up ballot access laws they 
have in Oklahoma and Ohio which make it difficult for people to vote 
for alternative candidates in those states. Please sign the petitions 
at http://www.e-thepeople.org/petition/11367/view and 
http://www.opendebates.net/yourrole/petition/ to allow other candidates 
besides Bush and Kerry into the presidential debates.

	We shouldn't resign ourselves to the fact of no political party 
supporting rave culture. The LP may not be explicitly pro-rave so much 
as rave-neutral, but the difference between us and other parties is 
that Libertarians are not going to go after and try to shut down 
peaceful people doing their own thing, whether it's music, sex, drugs, 
or whatever. It's none of the government's damn business. Michael 
Badnarik as president would stand up for people who are getting busted, 
censored, and otherwise screwed, and try to put an end to such actions 
by the authorities. Bush and Kerry on the other hand will aid and abet 
the people trying to screw us.

Peace, love & liberty,
					<<< Starchild >>>

"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

From sfraves-return-113578-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Jun 26 22:40:30 2004

Received: (qmail 61558 invoked from network); 26 Jun 2004 22:40:29 -0000
Date: Sat, 26 Jun 2004 15:40:26 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0406261419260.20018-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] On Hip Hip/Bling


I know why some of you hate hip hop.  You're jealous (as Vlad would say,
"ya playa hatin")!

Well, you can have the look without smoking up all your cashish:
http://www.icedoutgear.com/CB55.php

Jokes aside, you might not like it, but some of the production you hear
from Neptunes, Premier, Timbaland, Dan the Automator, Numark, Peanut
Butter Wolf, DJ Shadow or Outkast is sick as fuck.  Sorry, but there's
creativity there you don't hear in what we gather round (being breaks,
house, techno, etc).  A lot of the fans just like to sum it up as a
difference between hip hop and rap.  Tell you the truth, I would never be
caught dead at an Eminem show (music might even be ok, but I sure as fuck
don't want to put up with the assholes in the crowd who rally behind a guy
who talks about his mom like that *oh the pain of growing up white and
misundestood*)... but one of my best times musically lately was an outdoor
free show with Del at the Berekely campus... or when I dropped some
Handsome Boy Modeling School during soundcheck at a party and someone
there hands me a phone and puts me on with Dan the Automator (who produced
the record along with Prince Paul).

Underground hip hop is accessible, human and feeling... more about a
message and not about talking shit, wearing stupid jewelry and all that
crap you see on MTV.  Same goes on the DJ aspect, having met Qbert, Yoga
Frog, Radar...  they're all mellow individuals who are successful on their
own terms, not busting their balls trying to prove it to someone else.

Hip hop definitely has some stupid rap stars in it (who tend to have the
videos, the press, and often a lion's share of the money), but throwing
out the baby with the bathwater shorts you a *lot* of great music and I
know I don't listen to music that's locked in at a hectic 140 bpm 24/7.

Try out some J5, Living Legends, De La Soul.. and know better.
andyw

p.s. In related news, I went to the warehouse of the label that put out
the first Invisbl Skratch Piklz album last night... saw some weird french
musique concrete done in ridiculous surround sound, heard some deep
hypnotic drone ambient, and of course, a member of Matmos spanking the
other member's bare ass with one hand and holding a mic with the other as
a form of percussion.  San Francisco is a damn weird town, but it's my
damn weird town.


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] turntable help. please?


Good to know!  We used to get such crappy power out of Gabber Dave's old
Coleman genny that you'd get a free light show (the blacklights would all
go on and off at the weirdest times from the flouro ballast going in and
out of phase with the power).  Hrm, maybe that's why I'd trainwreck at
those beach parties.... heheheheh.  But I never did notice a problem like
what he's describing from power, especially if it's specific to a part of
the slider range/just one turntable, etc.

andyw

On Sat, 26 Jun 2004, Erik W Gilling wrote:
-&e->On Fri, Jun 25, 2004 at 05:21:38PM -0700, AndyW wrote:
-&e->> No, it's not power fluctuations.  I've run decks off of really bad power,
-&e->> the sound system is browning out, the lights will stop working, but
-&e->> the mix still sticks.
-&e->
-&e->I on the other hand have run turntables on crapy power (40hz) and had
-&e->excatly the same problem.  We fixed the genny and the turntable went
-&e->back to normal.
-&e->

Subject: [sfraves] 1015 was soooo much fun lastnight =) Oooh My Goodness man... LoL

OK.. so like earlier in the week, I called Gianni on the phone 2 like well.. we like talk once a month 2 catch up on things & stuff, ya know.. so it was a Groovy conversation & he told me 2 go out 2 1015 on Friday 'cause it's the last Spundaes that their gonna do there... he also made me a promise that he was gonna get me soooo drunk after he was done spinning... OK... sure, yeah...  so I ended up going since i ain't been there since like like year & 1/2 ago when I helped out w/ SFLNC there 4 an event & I totally missed hanging out w/ G & hearing 1 of his sets...

So like the remodleing jobs they did in the club are pretty Groovy... the front room is totally turned around from ho it used 2 B... the bathroom is now a seating area like when U 1st walk in the club.. there was this like top 40 DJ -playing R&B, Hip Hop.. it was fun!

Main room opened up kinda late.. Gianni opened that room.. WOW.. his set was fuckin' Awesome.. I Loved it!!  He started out like progressive Breakbeats, really mellow, chill, it was fun...then he got in2 a lil bit of progressive house which was pretty Groovy... ofcourse it ain't a Gianni set until he starts adding his signiture progressive trance.. Heeeeeeello 2Day... he played the most yummy prog trance songs that had all these rad vocals... good shit man.. LOOOOVED IT!!! mmmmmm =)  Oh yeah.. there was even this 1 breakdown from this song he spun that oooh my gosh, BREAKBEATS... YUMMY!!!  

(Gianni, U dork, where'd U go???  Around 3, the bartender told me he saw U w/ your back pack & record case & cut out!!  Grrrrr >:O  Well.. I got a ride home from my friend Will (Thank Will if you're still on here <3 =) & now u owe me 2 dinners fool!)

LoL.. Oh yeah.. ok... I can sxay this about Gianni... OK.. so like while he spinning, he's always moving.. & it's on beat.. it could be a foot his head, shoulders legs, or even hip.. but it was funny watching him & LMAO 'cause Wow man.. Giannirobics all the way man.. I Loved it!!

Upstairs... AuraSF was spinning prog house all night pretty much... OK... well.. Hello 2Day.. LoL... DJ Whatnot or whatever the fuck his name is... (sorry, I 4got) & Iliyad (sp) like mainly took the decks & played a long continuous Awesome Prog house set.. Oooooooh yeah!!  Loved it!!  Illiyad even busted out some Prog Breaks.. Thanks guys.. I Loved it!!!

OK.. but what totallly trip me out was JC when he spun up there... OK.. He was up on the prog stuff 4 a while, Groovy.. LoL... OK... but HEEEEEEEEELLO 2DAY... (& he admitedly admits doing this), but after a while in2 his set, he busted out FOOOOOOOOOOOO FOOOOOOOOO... LOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLOLMAO.. I'm telling ya man... JC really layed on thick & I guess around 3:45 in the mondo AM, that's all U can spin 4 a crowd that's like totally well... etarded!  JC man.. Like I said dude.. I got a whole lotta new respect 4 U in accomplishing this feat!!!  Seriously man.. JC did keep the floor packed & it was like WOW!!!  Congrats JC & Congrats AuraSF on the 1st installment of your monthly there!!!  Jeff, crew, y'all did a Groovy Good & I'm soooo glad i was there.. Jeff... keep that smile Dude.. Love seein' it!  LoL

Oh yeah.. there was that Max Weinberg Grhahm dude who spun lsstnight in the main room after Gianni.. OK.. total prgressive trance as well, but ya know.. I really wasn't impressed by his set 'cause well.. I dunno... it was fun 2 dance 2 as much as i could & the begining of it waxs really fuckin' Awesome & full of well.. it had alota UMPH... then he started getting like more & more chill w/ his trance selection.. it was kinda well.. it was still fun... I kinda made the mistake of like welll... by that time Gianni filled me up w/ hella drinks & well.. i did have like hella drink tickets also... but man.. i was so drunk... so like i said 2 him, " I know u kinda cleared the room, but I I heard a rumor that you'll pack house 2 morrow in LA".. & I dunno, after i said that, I realized I was like ummmm.. yeah.. but i haven't been that drunk in soooooooo long man... Hello 2day... But he's a fun guy 2 talk 2 & ya know.. I Love watchin him spin 'cause he totally like like does all these 
 Aw3esome hand gestures when like mondo well.. like a conductor of a symphony.. it was neat 2 watch how he feels his music...

OK... so like the crowd, well.. they should seriously consider naming that club ASIASF 'cause man... it was like all well... yead, the asain etards are pretty much a permanent fixture @ that club.. LoL.. OK.. Hello 2day,,, I counted like 13 people who asked me if I had any pills... it was fun the 1st like 3 times, but it got annoying afterthat... 

BUt none the less... I had fun... I finally had the balls 2 approach Dave (the head of security) well.. c'ause I was drunk.. & I told him that I thought he looked really Awesokme on the news a few months ago when i saw him... fuckin' Gianni was outside when i said that & started laughing @ me & I meant that sincerely, but Wow.. I was drunk... LoL

It was a fun Friuday night!!  I had hella fun!  Hmmm...  LoL  Wow man.. i was drunk 4 a long time!
