----- Original Message -----
From: "AndyW" <andy@saturn5.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Saturday, June 26, 2004 3:40 PM
Subject: [sfraves] On Hip Hip/Bling


>
> I know why some of you hate hip hop.  You're jealous (as Vlad would say,
> "ya playa hatin")!
>
> Well, you can have the look without smoking up all your cashish:
> http://www.icedoutgear.com/CB55.php
>
> Jokes aside, you might not like it, but some of the production you hear
> from Neptunes, Premier, Timbaland, Dan the Automator, Numark, Peanut
> Butter Wolf, DJ Shadow or Outkast is sick as fuck.  Sorry, but there's
> creativity there you don't hear in what we gather round (being breaks,
> house, techno, etc).  A lot of the fans just like to sum it up as a
> difference between hip hop and rap.  Tell you the truth, I would never be
> caught dead at an Eminem show (music might even be ok, but I sure as fuck
> don't want to put up with the assholes in the crowd who rally behind a guy
> who talks about his mom like that *oh the pain of growing up white and
> misundestood*)... but one of my best times musically lately was an outdoor
> free show with Del at the Berekely campus... or when I dropped some
> Handsome Boy Modeling School during soundcheck at a party and someone
> there hands me a phone and puts me on with Dan the Automator (who produced
> the record along with Prince Paul).
>
> Underground hip hop is accessible, human and feeling... more about a
> message and not about talking shit, wearing stupid jewelry and all that
> crap you see on MTV.  Same goes on the DJ aspect, having met Qbert, Yoga
> Frog, Radar...  they're all mellow individuals who are successful on their
> own terms, not busting their balls trying to prove it to someone else.
>
> Hip hop definitely has some stupid rap stars in it (who tend to have the
> videos, the press, and often a lion's share of the money), but throwing
> out the baby with the bathwater shorts you a *lot* of great music and I
> know I don't listen to music that's locked in at a hectic 140 bpm 24/7.
>
> Try out some J5, Living Legends, De La Soul.. and know better.
> andyw
>
> p.s. In related news, I went to the warehouse of the label that put out
> the first Invisbl Skratch Piklz album last night... saw some weird french
> musique concrete done in ridiculous surround sound, heard some deep
> hypnotic drone ambient, and of course, a member of Matmos spanking the
> other member's bare ass with one hand and holding a mic with the other as
> a form of percussion.  San Francisco is a damn weird town, but it's my
> damn weird town.
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

"With the vast uncensorable network of communication media, obstacles to=20
the free flow of information will become progressively more difficult to=20
erect and enforce. Traditional human power structures and their reign of=20
darkness are about to be rendered obsolete. If humanity realizes its=20
potential in time, we shall witness strong competition among individuals=20
to be allowed to serve on humanity's research, development, and production=
=20
teams. People's sense of accomplishment will derive from showing their=20
peers and demonstrating to the great intellectual integrity of Universe,=20
which we speak of as God, that they vastly enjoy doing their best in the=20
unselfish production of service for others rather than just for the=20
survival needs of themselves and their families."
R. Buckminster Fuller

--=20

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.

Saturday, June 26, 2004 ** Electric Daisy Carnival by Insomniac **

Venue and Location :
The NOS Center
689 South E Street
San Bernardino, California
Time :
June 26, 2004, Saturday, 04:00 PM
to
June 27, 2004, Sunday, 02:00 AM
Description :
This year the Insomniac family brings you an Electric Daisy Carnival that=
=20
is sure to please. The festival grounds provide plenty of room to spread=20
out and enjoy five musical areas, a vendor village, carnival attractions,=
=20
and the many talented performers that will be strolling about. Expect fat=
=20
beats, cotton candy, and full-size carnival rides, combined with=20
Insomniac's attention to detail and love for creating a positive=20
atmosphere. Join us in celebration of summer as we once again flip the=20
script and come with an event that bumps both day and night. Daisy kicks=20
off at 4pm and rocks it well into the moonlight. Show up early to enjoy=20
the sun and stay late to goove under the stars. Electric Daisy Carnival=20
2004 will be an aural and visual delight. So, don't sleep, come down and=20
share the vibe! All you have to do is be there. The first festival of the=
=20
summer is back! Super blooming beats, funkdafied freaks and full size=20
carnival rides! Gates open at 4:00pm and close at 2:00am. (Previous events=
=20
have sold out, so plan to arrive early and be sure to carpool.) 10=20
carnival hours! All ages welcome!
6 massive stages blooming with only the freshest of beats! Join us in a=20
magic place where nobody ever wears a frown, a place where everyone is=20
equal and free to get down, scream it out to all your freaky friendz=20
around! The Electric Daisy Carnival has finally come to town.
Melodic Stage: (House/Electro - Outside stage located near a one acre=20
lagoon and surrounded by lush landscaping.) MIGUEL MIGS [Naked=20
Music/Salted, SF], DOC MARTIN (True Skool cd release tour) [Sublevel, LA],=

[Future House/ Heading Home/System, LA].

Squad, LA], EON [H2OH, LA], DJ SONIK [H2OH DJ Squad, LA], EXODUS [H2OH/Dub=

LA].
Dream Circus Village: DCT's goal is to create a visual and audio=20
spectacle, also to tickle the imagination of the comfortably numb=20
individuals beyond their own belief. DCT would like to humanize the=20
dehumanized through forms of Music, Art & Dance. Carnival Attractions: All=
=20
aboard our high flyin', death defying, scream supplyin' full size carnival=
=20
rides. FORCE TEN, THE ORBITER, CLIFF HANGER, THE YO-YO, TORNADO, & GIANT=20

daisy dee-light! Freak show! The NOS Events Center is a safe and secure=20
location centrally located in Southern California. Insomniac will=20
transform the spacious indoor/outdoor festival grounds into a delightfully=
=20
unique carnival atmosphere where you'll be free to roam about throughout=20
the five musical areas. Take some time to relax on the grass and later,=20
take a stroll by the lagoon under the starlit sky. 689 South E Street, San=
=20
Bernardino, CA 92408. www.electricdaisycarnival.com

Lounge every 4th Saturday of the month for mOOv. We'll be bringin' you=20
talent from around the city and around the globe to wUrk ya like a part=20
time job. The main room is sweet 'n funky house (this is San Francisco,=20
afterall). The back room caters to our retro junkies with the best of the=
=20
70's & 80's all night long.

We're offering a limited number of VIP passes for this party. Sign up for=

an opportunity to win. You'll be notified by Friday, June 25th.

Thursday, July 1, 2004 ** The Phoenix Festival 2004 **

The Phoenix Festival 2004
www.phoenixfest.com

July 1st to July 5th
The Phoenix Farm -- Trout Lake, Washington
www.phoenixfest.com/images/adams1.gif

Ticket info: www.phoenixfest.com/tickets.html

In the re:evolutionary spirit of festivals such as Burning Man, Tribal Gath=
ering, Woodstock 1 & Earthdance, PHOENIX FESTIVAL is an annual autonomous m=
usic and arts festival which takes place over the Fourth of July
weekend in the scenic Pacific Northwest.

Featuring simultaneous performances on multiple stages by regional, nationa=
l and internationally recognized performers, Phoenix Festival provides a sa=
fe
and fun environment for thousands of participants to freely express themsel=
ves through the creation of theme camps, participatory workshops, special e=
vents, performance art, and a stunning variety of audio,
video, visual & interactive art installations.

Be sure to check out the webpage (www.phoenixfest.com) to get the full skin=
ny on art projects, theme camps, the marketplace, volunteer
opportunities and other community based events.

This year we have chosen to experiment a bit with the musical format. We've=
 dropped the main stage, opting instead to hand the reigns over to the comm=
unity and foster a totally autonomous environment. You will see
that these folks really took the ball and ran with it.

Below you will find the lineups for all of the stages, each broken up into =
their respective themes.

Live (Hip-Hop, Dub, Live Bands, Spoken Word, Culture Jam)
www.phoenixfest.com/live.html

Friday, July 2, 2004 ** Atmosfere (The closing party of the Black President=
 exhibition **

Join us for the closing party of the Black President: The Art and Legacy Of=
 Fela Anikulapo Kuti  exhibition at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, an=
d a book release (Fela: From West Africa to West Broadway) by Trevor Schoon=
maker, the Black President exhibition curator.

Black President:The Art and Legacy Of Fela Anikulapo - Kuti
                         Closing  July 4th,  2004

Yerba Buena Center for the Arts,701 Mission Street @ 3rd

                                 San Francisco

                                    Atmosfere
                            Friday, July 2nd @ Mighty
                119 Utah Street, (between 15th & 16th)

                  An underground spiritual jam session.

                           With Resident DJ: Said
                                 &
                                   Special Guest
                                Jerome Sydenham
                            (Ibadan Recordings, NY)
The founder of Ibadan recordings was born and raised in Ibadan, Nigeria to =
an English father and Jamaican mother. As a teenager, he migrated to Englan=
d as a scholar and later to New - York in the early 80's. Here, he became d=
eeply involved in the underground dance music scene both as a DJ and a prom=
oter. He later succeeded in crossing over to the main stream through a unif=
ied approach with Joe Claussell and Kerri Chandler on the prestigious Ten C=
ity's catalogue project. Sydenham's work today is largely influenced by the=
 cultural diversity of his up bringing, echoes of indigenous African and co=
ntemporary western music.

                                             +

                            Soji Odukogbe ( Live guitar)
Nigeria's Soji Odukogbe was for five years the lead guitarist for the late =
Fela Kuti. He draws on an extensive
background in Nigerian Afro - beat, highlife and spiritual music, bringing =
unique sensibility to the highlife guitar interpretation.

                                              &

Rasaki Aladokun(Live drum, bongo, conga & talking drum)
Rasaki is a miracle percussionist with over 25 years of experience.  He has=
 been a featured artist in the recording of many notable musicians such as =
King Sunny Ade, Stevie Wonder and Babatunde Olatunji to name a few. Don't m=
iss his extraordinary fusion of talking drum, conga, bongo and Afro-house m=
usic.


Afro-Beat  aesthetic dance performance by  Go Go Pro

                Front Image design by: HONEST

                  $12 / 10pm-4am / 21+  with ID

                          www.fatsouls.com,
      www.mighty119.com,  www.yerbabuenaarts.org

A portion of the proceeds will benefit Yerba Buena Center for the Art, a no=
n profit organization and the Bay Area's premier venue for adventurous art.

There will be lots of giveaways. Early arrival is strongly recommended.

Friday, July 2, 2004 ** *****TOKYO ELECTRIC***** **

Matthew Curry, aka Safety Scissors, has never been a purist when it comes t=
o musical styles. He would much rather destroy them and glue them back toge=
ther to his own gusto only to bring us his fresh take on pure, quirky, elec=
tric funk that is truly beyond genre definitions. Call it Italo Disco, Elek=
tro, Techno or Berlin-o-tronix and you'll still wonder about the rest. Alon=
g with releases/remixes on FORCE TRACKS, BPITCH CONTROL, CONTEXT, with his =
own platform, PROPTRONIX, getting the well deserved recognition, he must be=
 really after little funk monsters that are messing up the dance floor.

Hear the latest in Electro, Techno, Synthpop, EBM and 80s!
This months Special guest: Safety Scissors along with residential dj pressu=
re from Julian DeStrukt, TeflonJacket and Caltrop.

Saturday, August 7, 2004 ** Kidz at Play by Kidz at Play **

Hello boys and girls. It is that time again for us to pull out our childhoo=
d games from the past and that youthful spirit that we all remember and lov=
e, where we had no responsibilities but to be Kidz at Play. So Paul the Fan=
man and Dingo (Kidz at Play) would like to invite you to our 1 Year Anniver=
sary Party titled Kidz at Play on August 7th, 2004. Fellow kidz playing wil=
l be: DYNAMIC INTERVENTION aka Mik Cree [UK Dip] - is one of the most infam=
ous producers in the scene today. His trademark hard house/nrg meets acid/t=
rance sound had influenced the very foundation of the underground nu-nrg sc=
ene. He has produced tracks for all the best labels including DIP, TidyTrax=
, Honey Pot, Mohawk and E-Traxx as well as engineered tunes for the most re=
nowned producers such as Andy Farley, Paul Glazbe, Chris C, Madam Zu, and S=
ol Ray. His tunes have been picked up for various worldwide compilations in=
cluding The Nukleuz Hard House Anthems Series, Trade, and Hard House Nation=
=2E Mik is now taking his underground 303 driven style global, with tours o=
f Europe, Australia, South Africa, Asia and North America. TOM SLIK and DYL=
OOT [Skills/Dancing Spirit] - The master minds behind the infamous Skills P=
arties will show us why they have stayed on top for so long. From their out=
 of this world parties to the impeccable presence on stage with their maste=
rful blends of hard and melodic trance. They promise to take you on a journ=
ey never traveled before. MORGAN [Lotek/hardnrg.com/Audio Metamorphosis] - =
Co-owner of the first UK hard house label in America. Lotek Records is gett=
ing mad respect from the other global heavyweights. Along with running an i=
nternational record label, Morgan has produced tracks on Kaktai Records and=
 DIP. Morgan has never failed to bring the house down, so expect the same f=
or this show. KIDZ AT PLAY [Paul the Fanman and Dingo] - For over a year, P=
aul the Fanman and Dingo have joined forces as Kidz at Play, and have been =
shredding the decks together ever since. They blend classic hard house trac=
ks with modern nrg and a twist of psychedelic trance to create their own di=
stinguishable sound. With their solid friendship and dedication to the scen=
e's positive development, they are sure to continue throwing quality partie=
s for everyone to enjoy. MICHAEL LIU and LUKASZ [Illumination Records/Audio=
 Metamorphosis] - The legendary Michael Liu and the rising star Lukasz are =
going to snap the dance floor in half with their hard psychedelic sound. Th=
ey will leave the crowd begging for more. AUDIO ASSAULT [Fury and Cooraw] -=
 These two rising future superstars have created a unique sound all their o=
wn. Taking hard, bouncy, nrg from Cooraw and Fury's hard driving tech nrg w=
ill bring absolute mayham on the dance floor. DJ GIRLIE and CARLOS ALFONSO =
[BR Productions/LiquidVinylDJs] - These two long time best friends and BR P=
roductions Residents have talked and wanted to do a 2x4 set for a long time=
=2E So why keep the public waiting. ERICK! [Audio Metamorphosis] - Making h=
is solo debut, Erick! has a promising future in the SF Bay area scene. So l=
et him show you for himself why his skills behind the decks has landed him =
a deserving spot on the Audio roster. ON-IT [Audio Metamorphosis/Preserve P=
roductions] - Also making his solo debut, the name says it all. From props =
to promotion and finally djing, he will show you why his name is On-It. Pro=
duction for the party: 6 stacks of thundering JK Sound, 4 studio spots and =
2 green eye rippin lasers by Stimulights, and childhood decore created by A=
udio Preservation. Tickets available July 1st. Limited $5, $10, and $15 pre=
sales and $20 at the door. Tickets available at the following locations: Sk=
ills - 510.704.9876, Frequency 8 - 415.221.4142, Solid Grooves - 408.248.63=
99, Beaucoup Beatz - 650.344.8060. Party details: 1000+ capacity, all respo=
nsible ages, east bay location.

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

--- AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
> 
> I know why some of you hate hip hop.  You're jealous
> (as Vlad would say,
> "ya playa hatin")!
> 
> Well, you can have the look without smoking up all
> your cashish:
> http://www.icedoutgear.com/CB55.php
> 
> Jokes aside, you might not like it, but some of the
> production you hear
> from Neptunes, Premier, Timbaland, Dan the
> Automator, Numark, Peanut
> Butter Wolf, DJ Shadow or Outkast is sick as fuck. 
> Sorry, but there's
> creativity there you don't hear in what we gather
> round (being breaks,
> house, techno, etc).  A lot of the fans just like to
> sum it up as a
> difference between hip hop and rap.  Tell you the
> truth, I would never be
> caught dead at an Eminem show (music might even be
> ok, but I sure as fuck
> don't want to put up with the assholes in the crowd
> who rally behind a guy
> who talks about his mom like that *oh the pain of
> growing up white and
> misundestood*)... but one of my best times musically
> lately was an outdoor
> free show with Del at the Berekely campus... or when
> I dropped some
> Handsome Boy Modeling School during soundcheck at a
> party and someone
> there hands me a phone and puts me on with Dan the
> Automator (who produced
> the record along with Prince Paul).
> 
> Underground hip hop is accessible, human and
> feeling... more about a
> message and not about talking shit, wearing stupid
> jewelry and all that
> crap you see on MTV.  Same goes on the DJ aspect,
> having met Qbert, Yoga
> Frog, Radar...  they're all mellow individuals who
> are successful on their
> own terms, not busting their balls trying to prove
> it to someone else.
> 
> Hip hop definitely has some stupid rap stars in it
> (who tend to have the
> videos, the press, and often a lion's share of the
> money), but throwing
> out the baby with the bathwater shorts you a *lot*
> of great music and I
> know I don't listen to music that's locked in at a
> hectic 140 bpm 24/7.
> 
> Try out some J5, Living Legends, De La Soul.. and
> know better.
> andyw
> 
> p.s. In related news, I went to the warehouse of the
> label that put out
> the first Invisbl Skratch Piklz album last night...
> saw some weird french
> musique concrete done in ridiculous surround sound,
> heard some deep
> hypnotic drone ambient, and of course, a member of
> Matmos spanking the
> other member's bare ass with one hand and holding a
> mic with the other as
> a form of percussion.  San Francisco is a damn weird
> town, but it's my
> damn weird town.
> 
> 
>

Tonight Jerel and I will be joined by two stellar junglists, to bring you
yet another tight ass show.  Representin' the Mantis Sound System, F8 will
be comin thru to bless us with the dark and dirty, as well as some
original production.  Comin' all the way down from Fredrick area is Abe
Froman, returning from baby hiatus.  Abe brings the danga' with big
dancefloor ch00nz and wicked mixing skills.


Here's the timeslots, in EDT:

07-09pm - ODJ & Jerel
09-10:30pm - F8
10:30-12am - Abe Froman
12-?? - Afterhours

Looks like we'll be graced by another of the MSS crew, Psykofly, also
swingin in with some fresh dubs of his own, for some afterhours action!

From: JonnyR@aol.com

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: [sfraves] Doesn't anybody have a review of 1999 (or 1998)? 

-------------------------------1088444606
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I had a great time at 1999 (and also the after party nearby, "2000"). I got  
there a little after 7 and was therefore able to enjoy almost the whole event. 
 Telene opened, and it was great to see her since she hasn't been at very 
many  parties recently. All the DJs seemed to be having a great time, especially  
Denise. There were soooo many classic songs played. Of course!  Denise said  
something about having all kinds of cool obscure songs from the 1999 era that  
she could play, but this was a party for the big, best remembered songs. We 
got  to hear songs like "Save the Rave," and yes, they did play "Imagine," but 
with a  bunch of people including Duckeee on the stage, the finale seemed more 
like a  tribute to the Unity parties of days past, than an attempt to co-opt 
their good  will. 
 
It was great to see a lot of people who hadn't partied in a long  time!
 
This is just a quick mini-review, hoping to hear from some other people.  
I'll have pictures posted on Deciblast but i don't know if it'll be tonight or  
tomorrow. 

-------------------------------1088444606--

From sfraves-return-113605-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jun 28 21:31:51 2004
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-113605-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 46812 invoked by uid 1103); 28 Jun 2004 21:31:50 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 46789 invoked from network); 28 Jun 2004 21:31:49 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [4.42.226.40]
X-Originating-Email: [macadio@hotmail.com]
X-Sender: macadio@hotmail.com
From: "Macadio G." <macadio@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Mon, 28 Jun 2004 21:31:44 +0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <BAY1-F31TfeDTvZKQUR0002f675@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 28 Jun 2004 21:31:44.0389 (UTC) FILETIME=[4F1A7B50:01C45D57]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Other world Review!!

ok so it has been FOREVER since I have been out and even longer since I have 
done  party review.
But I have slack time at my new job so I figured I would lay it out for ya..

The sound Top notch Gateway with there Mccauley Speakers were hitting just 
right not to loud or low. Well maybe a bit on the loud side since I did not 
have earplugs with me.
Decor.. Minimal yet effective the 4 screens with the visuales was pretty 
cool at several points they were synched to the live PA the guy on the 
screen would say the sample that was being played live, unless it was an 
actual voice feed via the visuals over the live PA? either way neat effect.
Full on fountain in the chill area very nice ambience to the room. No fancy 
intelligent lighting or anything like that but somehow they made it work.

Now to the music, I was a bit skeptical about the live PA thing at a party I 
didn't know it would go over and all but for the most part it worked out 
pretty cool. Some minor complaints. I think the group Cat 5 should have been 
put on at a later time. I give them the utmost props for being able to 
create music and being versatile. But there sound was not right for the time 
slot they played let alone it was not even dance floor friendly. Who wants 
to hear downtempo in the main room at like 12am. I sure don't. It was more 
like a "Jam session" which I felt detracted from the "vibe" of a party and 
it showed people were just milling around and talking it was more like a 
social gathering then a party.  Next complaint. The guy near the end playing 
Live Happy hardcore,breakscore or noise core.. Whatever it was parts were ok 
but then he would go on this expermental tangent that just killed it. Once 
again back to the "Jam session" type of sound at party goer's expense..

Highlights though. Freaky chakra and Single cell orchestra can We all say 
plays bad ass tunes breaky funky tekno weirdness at its best.. very good 
sets..

And Tino-corp rocked the Mutha fuckin house!!! there set was just insane 
buck-nutty samples galore with tekno mania I did not get to see much of them 
cause I was chit chatting with old friends that I have not seen at parties 
in ages!! but overall very good party with a wicked older ravey,hippie FnF, 
tech-geek  kind of crowd.

You will fo sho see me at the next otherworld party, gotta love that space 
too :)

Mac

Married. http://lifeevents.msn.com/category.aspx?cid=married

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Originating-IP: [206.169.32.152]

From: "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>

	<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <BAY1-F31TfeDTvZKQUR0002f675@hotmail.com>
Date: Mon, 28 Jun 2004 15:57:23 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
Message-ID: <BAY9-DAV28q6DqaJY4k0001ec3a@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 28 Jun 2004 22:56:56.0834 (UTC) FILETIME=[365BAE20:01C45D63]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Other world Review!!

I'll just never forget seeing someone that appeared to be jack dangers run
to the front door area screaming about *a fire in the bassment* while he
tried to get into the fire hose thing on the wall. Got him to not bust the
glass out and then checked the guys bathroom to see if the basement was on
fire. Turns out he meant *bass bin* or I just heard him wrong. Apparently
Kid606 was screwing with the sound guy and basically appeared to be trying
to blow up the system. Then some water was splashed onto some gear and
apparently caused damage.

I agree 100% with the time slot placement of Cat5. Well, perhaps maybe room
placement. Had the second room been setup as a second room with independent
sound I would have surely stuck them in there. Until Freaky Chakra and
Single Cell came on people were just milling about. Rather killed things in
the beginning for me. It was great running into so many people I know. That
made things a hell of a lot better. I do have to say I loved the Little 15
remix that Cat5 did on the fly. I was in the smoking area singing along.
Hahaha.

Tino Corp stole the night. Jack Dangers was doing full visuals in time with
the music they were creating. Not often you see an act that does its own
music and live visuals. Musically the shit was awesome. I hung around that
massive sweatbox of a room just because I was hooked on what I heard. Damn
it got hot during their set. Sadly once Tino Corp was off everything turned
to noise crap.

Sorry to those that like that shit, but it licked major balls. Cleared the
fucking room pretty damn well too. Hell it cleared the party out within an
hour. That crap just plain hurt. Seemed like the noise kids were doing
everything they could to cause sound distortion on their end and the
system's end. What a fucking joke. When the sound got turned off on one of
the noise kiddies I had to yell *LOOK WHAT YOU DID. YOUR NOISE BROKE THE
SOUND* Kid just looked like a dear in headlights. Hell I was only kidding
too. But I was GLAD that the plug got pulled for a bit.

I didn't stick around much longer after that. Most of the time during the
noise shit was spent chatting it up in the halls. That was the only refuge
from the main room. All in all worth the $10 to see Tino Corp alone. It was
even better seeing friends out that night.

:: r ::

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Shazbot Minimalism TONIGHT, 6-8pm

Hey folx,

Tonight I'll be testing out a new weekly timeslot at the In House
Records red room. Unfortunately Minimal Monday and Teknotika SF are
gone, but if you enjoyed those nights I think you'll like what I've got
in store: deep techno and house, electro, dub, and everything in
between. Labels like Playhouse, Sub Static, Mosaic, Trapez, Seasons,
Burial Mix, Poker Flat and Morris Audio. Artists like Morgan Geist,
Isolee, Villalobos, Phonique, Carls Finlow & Craig, and much much more.

So if you appreciate stuff like this, if you don't know what the hell
I'm talking about and you'd like to hear something new, or if you're
just bored out of your skull... hit this up at 6pm tonight:

<http://throwdown.com/throwdown/live/in_house_records.asp>

or tune your Windows Media Player to:

<mms://www.throwdown.com/InHouseRecords>

Then swing by the live chat and make fun of me. Or just sit back, light
one up and listen. See? Mondays don't have to suck.

Chili cheese fries,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

PS: I'll be out of the town for the 4th so I won't be doing this next
week, but when I get back it will be a weekly thing. Thanks for
listening!

Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Cactus extract lessens hangovers

--=====================_939561==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Cactus extract lessens hangovers
Cactus extract lessened the symptoms of a hangover

If you want to drink but you don't want a hangover, a plant extract could 
be the answer, a study suggests.

US researchers at Tulane University found extracts of a prickly pear cactus 
lessened hangover symptoms such as nausea and a dry mouth.

They believe the extract works by reducing stress caused to the body by 
impurities in alcoholic drinks.

http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/3846957.stm




Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

below.

asked me to help out on their inaugural event at 1015.

> OK... well.. Hello 2Day.. LoL... DJ Whatnot or whatever the fuck his
> name is... (sorry, I 4got) & Iliyad (sp) like mainly took the decks &

> Loved it!!!

> dude.. I got a whole lotta new respect 4 U in accomplishing this

On 26 June 2004, Giles Soundwave wrote:

> JC gave me the usual DJ bs abt "I'm unprepared, I dunno what to spin,
> I've never heard these records in my life before, hey who are you
> anyway?" -- all the things DJs say before they go on. or at least all

'Twas true.  I'm doing the sublet hop right now, and I realized all too
late that the records I really needed for the gig were in storage, and
my storage unit was inaccessible at that hour.  So, off to Open Mind and
Amoeba I went!!  I had just enough time to categorize my finds before
heading out for the set.

And now that I'm back in town, I'll be able to see just what I played.

Oh, and I also don't joke about what record I'm going to start a set
with. ;)

> the things they say to me. despite all that he did indeed hold it
> down, the floor was packed when I left at 4am. (rave geezers like me
> need to get to sleep earlier than the resta y'all.)

Wah!!!  I was up at 9a getting ready for a trip to Black Rock.  Good to
see ya though!

"glad you had fun, ig."
"oh, i didn't say i had fun."
"oh, glad to see you, ig."
"i guess i am glad to see you too."
"did you read that book i asked you too yet, ig?"
"yes. i learned not to try anymore."
"cool, ig. so far, you are the only one i know who understands."

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Lollapalooza Goes Down – Again

--=====================_1144265==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



Lollapalooza Goes Down – Again




By Scott Thill, AlterNet
Posted on June 29, 2004, Printed on June 30, 2004
http://www.alternet.org/story/19082/

"Our plight is a true indication of the general health of the touring 
industry and it is across musical genres...We are taking Lollapalooza back 
and plan on rebuilding and recreating the festival in surroundings more 
conducive to the cultural experience we've become known for." – Perry Farrell

In 1997, Lollapalooza – Perry Farrell's alternative music and lifestyle 
road show – shut down after a strong seven-year run. The traveling festival 
ended on a dissonant note, squeezing underwhelming bands like Prodigy, 
Korn, The Orb, and Orbital onto the stage that once housed giants like 
Pearl Jam, Sonic Youth, Wu Tang Clan, Ice Cube and the Beastie Boys.

The tour was revived in 2003 with a lackluster lineup – with Farrell's 
Jane's Addiction, supergroup Audioslave, Jurassic 5 and the Donnas 
headlining. The reduced starpower contributed to weak ticket sales, but 
Farrell still carried the torch: Fast forward to 2004, and Lollapalooza 
seemed to be burning bright.

Farrell and company believed, some would argue rightly so, that a line-up 
consisting of the Pixies, Morrissey, PJ Harvey, The Flaming Lips, Modest 
Mouse, Sonic Youth (again) and Wilco would be enough to get iPod Nation up 
off its recliners this summer. Apparently, they guessed wrong. Lollapalooza 
2004, citing million dollar losses and anemic sales, had to pull up stakes 
on the two-month, cross-country sonic spree.

Whether or not this is a massive bummer depends on whom you're talking to. 
If you're talking to the MTV-addled bubble-poppers who've made tired Gs 
like 50 Cent and Us Weekly-selling starlets like J.Lo into platinum 
superstars, well, they'll get over it. And if you're talking post-slackers 
that helped explode alternative music through the Lollapalooza aorta since 
the festival took its first breath in 1991, it seems that they might not 
have the economic clout they had in the '90s.

But whomever you're talking to, either they're not interested, not aware, 
or not in possession of the ample funds it takes to gain access to a 
festival concert these days. As Perry notes above, the health of the 
touring industry is bordering on convalescent, and it's not just 
Lollapalooza that has breathed its last gasp. Last year, the diverse indie 
rock festival All Tomorrow's Parties – curated by Matt Groening (you may 
remember him from such hit TV shows as The Simpsons or Futurama) and 
featuring compelling acts like Patti Smith, The Breeders, Nick Cave and a 
host of innovative bands – had to cancel its Los Angeles date due to 
sluggish ticket sales.

Not all is lost when it comes to blockbuster package tours. Vans Warped is 
still going comparatively strong, and it's landing in just as many cities 
as Lollapalooza. But Vans Warped, as the name implies, is heavily 
sponsored; everyone from big guns like Vans, Hurley, MTV and Dodge to small 
fries like Slim Jim, Ernie Ball and Hot Topic are lending their weight and 
support to the skateboarding phenomenon. Plus, with what looks like – 
according to the event's official site – around 200 bands along for the 
ride, most of them skewed to a much younger demographic, they're arguably 
giving more bang for your buck.

But demographics don't tell the whole story. Consider OzzFest, which is 
still going strong – though Ozzy Osbourne himself has been running on empty 
for years and his TV show is a shadow of its former self. If critics of 
Lolla think Sonic Youth and The Pixies are too old, then how to explain the 
attraction of OzzFest's 2004 headliner, a reunited Black Sabbath? They've 
got the Pixies beat by two decades in the age category. True, OzzFest 
remains relevant by lumping in younger acts like Slipknot, Hatebreed and 
others, but their main stage acts in 2004 – Sabbath, Judas Priest and 
Slayer – reads like a headbanger's history book.

As usual, age doesn't explain everything. Sure, Lollapalooza fans are 
getting old, but they're still getting involved. In addition to the stellar 
headliners, the tour had partnered with MoveOn.org to provide, as the 
festival always has, discussions, solutions, and avenues for change during 
what's shaping up to be the Armageddon of election years. This year's model 
was going to be the Revolution Solution Tent, a teach-in of sorts focusing 
on environmental concerns, workers' rights, media deregulation, free speech 
and other issues vital to the arts community; they even had a solar-powered 
stage geared up for action, featuring punk veteran and Minutemen bassist 
Mike Watt as a headliner. The always engaging Watt also penned a running 
diary for Lollapalooza on their official site, but a quick click of the 
site's "Sponsors" tab tells the whole story. Blank page.

Some of the blame may lie with Farrell, who had similar problems launching 
2003's comeback Lollapalooza. Originally planning to kick off the festival 
in Ionia, Michigan on July 3rd, Rolling Stone reported that Farrell 
cancelled the date and rescheduled; in what may be debated as a symbol of 
Farrell's ego or a funny coincidence, the Lollapalooza party line argued 
that the Jane's Addiction's set simply couldn't fit on the Fairgrounds 
stage. But officials at the venue replied that Farrell's excuse was a red 
herring; the show had only sold 4,000 tickets and the Fairgrounds main 
stage had played anywhere from two to five times that capacity before. 
Making matters worse, the tour had a scheduled stop in Detroit, which, some 
asserted, cut into Ionia's sales. No matter how you slice it, that show had 
problems before the curtain ever lifted.

And they continue. The problem of "poor ticket sales" takes its place with 
the others – "too mainstream," "too old," "too masculine," "too white" – 
plaguing Lolla since it more or less ended in 1997. Which is truly a sorry 
State of the Slacker Union address, considering the impressive firepower 
Farrell amassed for 2004's old college try. After all, the Pixies have sold 
out almost all of their other reunion dates within minutes; but even they 
couldn't keep the Lolla boat afloat. Which if you ask diehard fans (like 
myself, I admit), it just goes to show that Farrell should've tabbed them 
for his journeying think piece back when they were changing music forever.

Which is another way of saying that Lolla's 2004 line-up might have caused 
a Who-like stampede had it hit the stage in 1991 or 1992, when most of the 
headliners were at their best. But now yesteryear's teenagers and 
twenty-somethings are well on their way to middle age, and shelling out a 
Trump-load of cash for water bottles and bad fries to sit in the blazing 
sun for two days straight amongst drunks and frat boys just doesn't sound 
like fun anymore.

So whether you're blaming Farrell, the aging lineup and its older 
demographic, the ailing "health of the touring industry," Clear Channel's 
stranglehold on the live show circuit, or the fact that most Americans just 
don't have the kind of disposable income they possessed last decade, 
Lollapalooza's cancellation is a wake-up call to all of those who think 
that crafting an attractive lineup is all is takes to pack them in.

Lollapalooza 2004's brilliant lineup is perhaps too little, too late. Too bad.


© 2004 Independent Media Institute. All rights reserved.
View this story online at: http://www.alternet.org/story/19082/


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm




"A human being is part of a whole, called by us the 'Universe,' a part 
limited in time and space. He experiences himself, his thoughts and 
feelings, as something separated from the rest--a kind of optical delusion 
of his consciousness. This delusion is a kind of prison for us, restricting 
us to our personal desires and to affection for a few persons nearest us. 
Our task must be to free ourselves from this prison by widening our circles 
of compassion to embrace all living creatures and the whole of nature in 
its beauty."
-Albert Einstein









--=====================_1144265==.ALT--

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 23321 invoked from network); 30 Jun 2004 16:27:21 -0000
Date: Wed, 30 Jun 2004 09:24:04 -0700 (PDT)
From: Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>
To: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
cc:  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <6.1.1.1.2.20040630082927.02042060@mail.speakeasy.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0406300919030.29246-100000@charm>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8BIT
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: =?ISO-8859-1?Q?Re=3A_=5Bsfraves=5D_NRR=3A_Lollapalooza_Goes_Dow?=
 =?ISO-8859-1?Q?n_=96_Again?=

Interesting read. I don't think he got it all right though. One of his
major points is that people aren't going to see concerts because they
don't have disposable income they had 10 years ago. He doesn't give any
supporting evidence for this, and I think he's wrong on this point. For
example:

> Even though the record business is in trouble, the business of music is
> experiencing an explosive growth, thanks in part to the concert
> business. Concert ticket sales revenues in North America have been on the upswing
> for the past four years, with 2003 revenues jumping 20 percent to $2.5
> billion, according to industry watchers, and there are signs that 2004
> could be an even bigger year.
>
> http://abcnews.go.com/sections/Entertainment/WorldNewsNow/summer_concerts_040601-1.html

Bottom line, people don't want to go to a big festival with a bunch of
indie bands from the 80s and 90s. Lollapalooza blew it on their
demographics.

Subject: =?ISO-8859-1?Q?Re:_[sfraves]_NRR:_Lollapalooza_Goes_Down_=96_Again?=

I say it was purely a matter of choice in lineup. If that lineup had
rolled in back in the first years of Lollapalooza (91+) it *would*
have gone off. Fast-forward to today and it becomes a nostalgic show
for a limited audience that has since moved on. What is remarkable
about the first years of Lollapalooza is the lineups that show brought
to town at that time. I would think that Perry needs to retool
Lollapalooza and apply that formula to this day and age. Not too many
high school kids with limited income are going to shell out hard
earned cash for groups that they don't really know. Warped Tour gets
it right. The lineup of uber-popular pop-punk draws in the kids. Toss
in a media blast and you can damn well bet it's going to sell out.

I see certain parallels between raves and concerts here. Cater to the
demographic that will attend.

:: r y a n ::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Lollapalooza Goes Down 
     =?iso-8859-1?Q?=96_Again?=

i'm still mad that i don't get to see Morrissey.

i don't care that he is over his prime or that his "new" music is just
re-vamped old music with hot new producers. (see "how can you possibly
know how i feel?", new cut, but classic morrissey / smiths style lyrics)

when i discovered the Smiths in '86 they were already over.  they hadn't
attained commercial success or noteriety (sp?), but their best music was
already made.

by the time a band makes it to a festival, they are already played out.

i know this.  i don't expect to goto a festival to find cutting edge new
music or to see artists that would drive ticket sales for that matter.

i just wanna see Morrissey.

heaven knows i'm miserable now,
Jonas





> I say it was purely a matter of choice in lineup. If that lineup had
> rolled in back in the first years of Lollapalooza (91+) it *would*
> have gone off. Fast-forward to today and it becomes a nostalgic show
> for a limited audience that has since moved on. What is remarkable
> about the first years of Lollapalooza is the lineups that show brought
> to town at that time. I would think that Perry needs to retool
> Lollapalooza and apply that formula to this day and age. Not too many
> high school kids with limited income are going to shell out hard
> earned cash for groups that they don't really know. Warped Tour gets
> it right. The lineup of uber-popular pop-punk draws in the kids. Toss
> in a media blast and you can damn well bet it's going to sell out.
>
> I see certain parallels between raves and concerts here. Cater to the
> demographic that will attend.
>
> :: r y a n ::
>
> On Wed, 30 Jun 2004 09:24:04 -0700 (PDT), Dan Haskovec <dan@pry.com>
> wrote:
>> Interesting read. I don't think he got it all right though. One of his
>> major points is that people aren't going to see concerts because they
>> don't have disposable income they had 10 years ago. He doesn't give any
>> supporting evidence for this, and I think he's wrong on this point. For
>> example:
>>
>> > Even though the record business is in trouble, the business of music
>> is
>> > experiencing an explosive growth, thanks in part to the concert
>> > business. Concert ticket sales revenues in North America have been on
>> the upswing
>> > for the past four years, with 2003 revenues jumping 20 percent to $2.5
>> > billion, according to industry watchers, and there are signs that 2004
>> > could be an even bigger year.
>> >
>> > http://abcnews.go.com/sections/Entertainment/WorldNewsNow/summer_concerts_040601-1.html
>>
>> Bottom line, people don't want to go to a big festival with a bunch of
>> indie bands from the 80s and 90s. Lollapalooza blew it on their
>> demographics.
>>
>> On Wed, 30 Jun 2004, Apollo wrote:
>>
>> >
>> >
>> > Lollapalooza Goes Down – Again
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > By Scott Thill, AlterNet
>> > Posted on June 29, 2004, Printed on June 30, 2004
>> > http://www.alternet.org/story/19082/
>> >
>> > "Our plight is a true indication of the general health of the touring
>> > industry and it is across musical genres...We are taking Lollapalooza
>> back
>> > and plan on rebuilding and recreating the festival in surroundings
>> more
>> > conducive to the cultural experience we've become known for." – Perry
>> Farrell
>> >
>> > In 1997, Lollapalooza – Perry Farrell's alternative music and
>> lifestyle
>> > road show – shut down after a strong seven-year run. The traveling
>> festival
>> > ended on a dissonant note, squeezing underwhelming bands like Prodigy,
>> > Korn, The Orb, and Orbital onto the stage that once housed giants like
>> > Pearl Jam, Sonic Youth, Wu Tang Clan, Ice Cube and the Beastie Boys.
>> >
>> > The tour was revived in 2003 with a lackluster lineup – with Farrell's
>> > Jane's Addiction, supergroup Audioslave, Jurassic 5 and the Donnas
>> > headlining. The reduced starpower contributed to weak ticket sales,
>> but
>> > Farrell still carried the torch: Fast forward to 2004, and
>> Lollapalooza
>> > seemed to be burning bright.
>> >
>> > Farrell and company believed, some would argue rightly so, that a
>> line-up
>> > consisting of the Pixies, Morrissey, PJ Harvey, The Flaming Lips,
>> Modest
>> > Mouse, Sonic Youth (again) and Wilco would be enough to get iPod
>> Nation up
>> > off its recliners this summer. Apparently, they guessed wrong.
>> Lollapalooza
>> > 2004, citing million dollar losses and anemic sales, had to pull up
>> stakes
>> > on the two-month, cross-country sonic spree.
>> >
>> > Whether or not this is a massive bummer depends on whom you're talking
>> to.
>> > If you're talking to the MTV-addled bubble-poppers who've made tired
>> Gs
>> > like 50 Cent and Us Weekly-selling starlets like J.Lo into platinum
>> > superstars, well, they'll get over it. And if you're talking
>> post-slackers
>> > that helped explode alternative music through the Lollapalooza aorta
>> since
>> > the festival took its first breath in 1991, it seems that they might
>> not
>> > have the economic clout they had in the '90s.
>> >
>> > But whomever you're talking to, either they're not interested, not
>> aware,
>> > or not in possession of the ample funds it takes to gain access to a
>> > festival concert these days. As Perry notes above, the health of the
>> > touring industry is bordering on convalescent, and it's not just
>> > Lollapalooza that has breathed its last gasp. Last year, the diverse
>> indie
>> > rock festival All Tomorrow's Parties – curated by Matt Groening (you
>> may
>> > remember him from such hit TV shows as The Simpsons or Futurama) and
>> > featuring compelling acts like Patti Smith, The Breeders, Nick Cave
>> and a
>> > host of innovative bands – had to cancel its Los Angeles date due to
>> > sluggish ticket sales.
>> >
>> > Not all is lost when it comes to blockbuster package tours. Vans
>> Warped is
>> > still going comparatively strong, and it's landing in just as many
>> cities
>> > as Lollapalooza. But Vans Warped, as the name implies, is heavily
>> > sponsored; everyone from big guns like Vans, Hurley, MTV and Dodge to
>> small
>> > fries like Slim Jim, Ernie Ball and Hot Topic are lending their weight
>> and
>> > support to the skateboarding phenomenon. Plus, with what looks like –
>> > according to the event's official site – around 200 bands along for
>> the
>> > ride, most of them skewed to a much younger demographic, they're
>> arguably
>> > giving more bang for your buck.
>> >
>> > But demographics don't tell the whole story. Consider OzzFest, which
>> is
>> > still going strong – though Ozzy Osbourne himself has been running on
>> empty
>> > for years and his TV show is a shadow of its former self. If critics
>> of
>> > Lolla think Sonic Youth and The Pixies are too old, then how to
>> explain the
>> > attraction of OzzFest's 2004 headliner, a reunited Black Sabbath?
>> They've
>> > got the Pixies beat by two decades in the age category. True, OzzFest
>> > remains relevant by lumping in younger acts like Slipknot, Hatebreed
>> and
>> > others, but their main stage acts in 2004 – Sabbath, Judas Priest and
>> > Slayer – reads like a headbanger's history book.
>> >
>> > As usual, age doesn't explain everything. Sure, Lollapalooza fans are
>> > getting old, but they're still getting involved. In addition to the
>> stellar
>> > headliners, the tour had partnered with MoveOn.org to provide, as the
>> > festival always has, discussions, solutions, and avenues for change
>> during
>> > what's shaping up to be the Armageddon of election years. This year's
>> model
>> > was going to be the Revolution Solution Tent, a teach-in of sorts
>> focusing
>> > on environmental concerns, workers' rights, media deregulation, free
>> speech
>> > and other issues vital to the arts community; they even had a
>> solar-powered
>> > stage geared up for action, featuring punk veteran and Minutemen
>> bassist
>> > Mike Watt as a headliner. The always engaging Watt also penned a
>> running
>> > diary for Lollapalooza on their official site, but a quick click of
>> the
>> > site's "Sponsors" tab tells the whole story. Blank page.
>> >
>> > Some of the blame may lie with Farrell, who had similar problems
>> launching
>> > 2003's comeback Lollapalooza. Originally planning to kick off the
>> festival
>> > in Ionia, Michigan on July 3rd, Rolling Stone reported that Farrell
>> > cancelled the date and rescheduled; in what may be debated as a symbol
>> of
>> > Farrell's ego or a funny coincidence, the Lollapalooza party line
>> argued
>> > that the Jane's Addiction's set simply couldn't fit on the Fairgrounds
>> > stage. But officials at the venue replied that Farrell's excuse was a
>> red
>> > herring; the show had only sold 4,000 tickets and the Fairgrounds main
>> > stage had played anywhere from two to five times that capacity before.
>> > Making matters worse, the tour had a scheduled stop in Detroit, which,
>> some
>> > asserted, cut into Ionia's sales. No matter how you slice it, that
>> show had
>> > problems before the curtain ever lifted.
>> >
>> > And they continue. The problem of "poor ticket sales" takes its place
>> with
>> > the others – "too mainstream," "too old," "too masculine," "too white"
>> –
>> > plaguing Lolla since it more or less ended in 1997. Which is truly a
>> sorry
>> > State of the Slacker Union address, considering the impressive
>> firepower
>> > Farrell amassed for 2004's old college try. After all, the Pixies have
>> sold
>> > out almost all of their other reunion dates within minutes; but even
>> they
>> > couldn't keep the Lolla boat afloat. Which if you ask diehard fans
>> (like
>> > myself, I admit), it just goes to show that Farrell should've tabbed
>> them
>> > for his journeying think piece back when they were changing music
>> forever.
>> >
>> > Which is another way of saying that Lolla's 2004 line-up might have
>> caused
>> > a Who-like stampede had it hit the stage in 1991 or 1992, when most of
>> the
>> > headliners were at their best. But now yesteryear's teenagers and
>> > twenty-somethings are well on their way to middle age, and shelling
>> out a
>> > Trump-load of cash for water bottles and bad fries to sit in the
>> blazing
>> > sun for two days straight amongst drunks and frat boys just doesn't
>> sound
>> > like fun anymore.
>> >
>> > So whether you're blaming Farrell, the aging lineup and its older
>> > demographic, the ailing "health of the touring industry," Clear
>> Channel's
>> > stranglehold on the live show circuit, or the fact that most Americans
>> just
>> > don't have the kind of disposable income they possessed last decade,
>> > Lollapalooza's cancellation is a wake-up call to all of those who
>> think
>> > that crafting an attractive lineup is all is takes to pack them in.
>> >
>> > Lollapalooza 2004's brilliant lineup is perhaps too little, too late.
>> Too bad.
>> >

> i'm still mad that i don't get to see Morrissey.
> 
> i don't care that he is over his prime or that his "new" music is just
> re-vamped old music with hot new producers. (see "how can you possibly
> know how i feel?", new cut, but classic morrissey / smiths style lyrics)

A sad fact widely known
How the most impassionate song
To a lonely soul
Is so easily outgrown
But don't forget the songs
That made you smile
And the songs that made you cry
When you lay in awe
On the bedroom floor
And said: "Oh, smother me, Mother..." 

Morrisey said it best...

--Patrick.

Subject: [sfraves] *HAPPY TOGETHER 3! Saturday, September 4th! $1 Presales / ALL AGES  <bsp>

Yeah, we know. It's been almost 2 years since the last one. There hasn't 
been a single party we get asked more about, so here it is, the finale.. 
Liquidvinyldjs.com is unbelieveably proud to present:

HAPPY TOGETHER 3
SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 4TH 2004
LABOR DAY WEEKEND
ALL AGES | 9:00pm-6:00am
2000+ CAPACITY BAY AREA LOCATION!


We've taken great pride in putting together this once in a lifetime lineup! 
Prepare for one of the biggest hard lineups the West Coast has ever seen!


SCOTT BROWN
|| Evolution Records - Scotland || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
Considered by many around the world as Hardcore's #1 DJ and Producer, Scott 
Brown has achieved more in his career than many in any other genre. He's 
developed his Evolution Records label into what many reguard as the top 
Hardcore label in the world, along with releasing tracks with many of 
Hardcore's top Producers. With massive hits like "ELYSIUM", "NOW IS THE 
TIME", "TURN UP THE MUSIC", and "ICE COLD", chances are if you've been to a 
party in the past 10 years, you've heard his music. As a DJ, he is known for 
his rock solid skills on the decks, often building his sets into energetic 
frenzies that result in mayhem after it's all said and done! This will be 
Scott Brown's first Bay Area Appearance, please join us to make it 
memorable!

DJ HIXXY
|| RaverBaby / HTID / Bonkers - U.K. ||
>From his novice DJ days in 1991 to his International Hardcore Superstar 
status of today, Hixxy has worked long and hard making a name for himself in 
the Hardcore circuit. From his early releases "TOY TOWN" and "WANTING TO GET 
HIGH" to his current hits "TANTRIC" and his remix of "FALLING IN", Hixxy has 
enjoyed enormous success as a Producer. As a DJ, Hixxy helped launch the 
enormously popular "BONKERS" series on React, which continues to break sales 
records for Hardcore CD compilations. His mixes are known to be uplifting 
and energetic, so be ready as we bring Hixxy for a very rare USA appearance!

TOMMYKNOCKER
|| Traxtorm Records - Italy || *FIRST BAY AREA APPEARANCE!*
As one of the fastest rising Hardcore producers today, we are extremely 
excited to bring you Tommyknocker for his first Bay Area Appearance. Hailing 
from Italy, his unique sound has been in demand by all of the world's top 
Hardcore DJs, with hard hittin' releases like "THE AFTERMATH", "REVOLUTION", 
and "DEMOLITION". He is also an accomplished DJ, playing huge events like 
Love Parade, Hellraiser, Megarave, and Masters of Hardcore. If you like your 
Hardcore rough and rugged, Tommyknocker is your man!

DELTA 9
|| Psychotik Records / Adam Recordings - Chicago, IL || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Quite possibly the biggest name in American Hardcore, Delta 9 is widely 
respected and admired throughout the world of Hardcore. With his early 
releases like "HARDCORE CHICAGO", "HATE TANK", and "REAL HARDCORE", to his 
present material like "DONKEY PUNCH", "NO ESCAPE", and "PUNK LOSER", he 
continues to evolve his style to the Hardcore massive. He has appeared all 
around the globe showcasing his incredible DJ skills and crowd control, 
often taking crowds beyond their peak and back again. We are proud to 
present to you Delta 9 for his first Bay Area Appearance!

DJ VENOM
|| Volume Productions / Topaz Records - Providence, RI || *FIRST BAY AREA 
APPEARANCE!*
Looked upon as one of the most talented Hard DJ's in America, Venom's style 
and persona are only comparible to his music: wild and crazy! He goes 
seamlessly from US Hard House to Hardcore in his mixes, as showcased on such 
top-selling CD compilations as his "RAISE THE VOLUME" series, his "STRAIGHT 
BANGIN" series, and the immensely popular "HOUSE BLEND VOLUME 7-8". From his 
jaw-dropping scratching to his crowd rockin stage displays, it's no wonder 
why Venom is in such huge demand all around the country. We are hyped to 
bring you DJ Venom's first Bay Area Appearance!


CLOUDSKIPPER
|| Raw Elements / KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The one, the only. Cloudskipper is widely recognized and respected as one of 
the top Hardcore DJ's in America. With his recent tour of the U.K. as well 
as his very busy touring here in North America, crowds all around the world 
continue to be amazed and captivated by his upfront Hardcore sets. Often 
immitated, never duplicated, Cloudskipper sets the bar other Hardcore DJ's 
will be trying to reach... next year.

DJ TRONIC
|| Resistance Recordings / Liquidvinyldjs.com / BeatSupreme.com ||
Label owner. Producer. DJ. Promoter. Is there anything he doesn't do? 
Probably not. DJ Tronic has continued to build his label Resistance 
Recordings from the ground up, watching it become one of the premiere Hard 
labels in the world with many top DJ's playing his material. All this along 
with his recent touring of France and Spain, as well as his busy touring 
schedule in the USA, it's no wonder why Tronic is such a rising talent.


THE NICE GUYS [NO LEFT TURN & DJ REESE]
|| KFA / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
When they're not out being nice somewhere, they're out getting drunk. All 
jokes aside, these two are starting to make waves in the Hardcore world, 
with their two upcoming releases on KFA, as well as other material released 
on Raw Elements and Bedlam. Prepare for the Nice Guys, dropping a 
not-so=nice set!

THE NATURAL DISASTERS [THE DOCTOR & RECLIPSE]
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com ||
The Doctor and Reclipse, forces in their own right come together to form the 
Natural Disasters. While they're not wrestlers, they drop some of the 
hardest hittin material in the Bay, ranging from DrumNBass to Hardcore to 
Gabber, these two will be shaking the dancefloor HARD!

J-MARR & CARLOS ALFONZO
|| Bayraves.com / Liquidvinyldjs.com / Soop Recordings / BeatSupreme.com || 
[/b]
Alright, the last time we had these two together during a set, they did more 
passing out of food than actually playing. While we can't promise the same 
feast, we can promise a rockin set that only these two can bring!

_____________________


| This will be our BIGGEST and BEST event to date! Better than Overload, 
Overload 2, Overload 3, Happy Together, and even Happy Together 2! Where 
will YOU be on September 4th??

| Happy Together 3 will be an ALL AGES EVENT running from 9:00pm-6:00am! 
Make sure to get there early so you don't miss out on any of the action! The 
perfect event to end your summer right!

| Our capacity will be 2000+! One big ass room filled with the BIGGEST and 
BEST Hard lineup Northern California has ever seen! The event will be 
located in the IMMEDIATE BAY AREA.

| Hard hittin audio provided by: HARDSCIENCE | Multi-Screen Screen Visual 
Display by: Connected Systems |

| Having a birthday within 2 weeks of September 4th? E-mail us at: 
djtronic@resistancerecordings.com and we'll add you to our special birthday 
celebration!


Ticket Info:

The first 50 Presale Tickets will be only $1.00! That's right, first 50 
Presale Tickets will be $1.00! After those are gone, tickets will go up to 
$10.00. After those $10.00 Presales are gone, tickets will go up to $15.00. 
After those are gone, tickets will be available at the door. What's that 
mean? BUY A PRESALE TICKET - GUARANTEE YOUR ENTRY! Every event we've done 
has SOLD OUT, and we fully expect Happy Together 3 to SELL OUT!


Presale Tickets go on sale Wednesday, July 14th at the following locations:

SKILLS DJ WORKSHOP | BERKELEY :: 510.704.9876
SOLID GROOVES | SANTA CLARA :: 408.248.6399

IN THA MIXX | SACRAMENTO :: 916.442.0499

ONLINE TICKETS :: HTTP://WWW.GROOVETICKETS.COM

*For anyone traveling from outside of the state of California, we will be 
offering $15 admission at the door, plus an exclusive CD from DJ Tronic and 
Cloudskipper!

years, he plays good old' american midwest warehouse/barn/legionhall paint
peeling hardcore without the happy.

Subject: [sfraves] Re: Republicans for Nader/Democrats for Badnarik?

Michael Badnarik and the Libertarian Party take voters who believe in 
limited government away from the Republicans.

that he could lose a lot of votes on that issue.

P.S. - It's a mistake to assume that everybody who votes for Nader 
would otherwise vote for Kerry. The second choice of many Nader 
supporters would be David Cobb, the Green Party candidate. Growing 
numbers of people are coming to realize that both the establishment 
parties are the problem, and won't vote for Bush or Kerry no matter 
what.

Subject: [sfraves] delta 9 changed my life

delta 9 poisoned me when i saw him play in L.A. (orange show complex) (1996)

i was horrified by his intense evil nature.

it was 6am.  i was coming down and looking fwd to some morning house.

he deprived me of such a comfort and proceeded to split my skull / psyche
/ personality until i felt like i might do things that were terribly
wrong.

i wanted the onslaught to stop, but that just made him pound me more.

i had know idea that such music existed before that.

if techno is the music of the devil, delta 9 must be the devil's own
torture dementia master.

Jonas

>
> On Wed, 30 Jun 2004, DJ Tronic wrote:
> -&e->DELTA 9
> -&e->|| Psychotik Records / Adam Recordings - Chicago, IL || *FIRST BAY
> AREA
> -&e->APPEARANCE!*
> -&e->Quite possibly the biggest name in American Hardcore, Delta 9 is
> widely
> -&e->respected and admired throughout the world of Hardcore. With his
> early
> -&e->releases like "HARDCORE CHICAGO", "HATE TANK", and "REAL HARDCORE",
> to his
> -&e->present material like "DONKEY PUNCH", "NO ESCAPE", and "PUNK LOSER",
> he
> -&e->continues to evolve his style to the Hardcore massive. He has
> appeared all
> -&e->around the globe showcasing his incredible DJ skills and crowd
> control,
> -&e->often taking crowds beyond their peak and back again. We are proud to
> -&e->present to you Delta 9 for his first Bay Area Appearance!
>
> Delta9 used to make these videos that are a sorta low budget Jackass...
> with awesome gags like having their pictures taken with big names DJs with
> their cocks hanging out of their pants, interviewing kids at parties that
> are puking off their E, snowboarding into bushes and faking car accidents.
>
> Seems immature, sure... but's it's great how well these things are edited
> and funny as all hell.  And shy of some weird change in the last few
> years, he plays good old' american midwest warehouse/barn/legionhall paint
> peeling hardcore without the happy.
>
> whoot!
> andyw
>
>

Subject: [sfraves] Sound With Space and Motion

--=====================_1535157==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Sound With Space and Motion

June 29, 2004


  A conversation snaps around you. A string trio plays in front of you as 
you turn your attention from cello to violin. A soprano walks across the 
stage, and you turn your head to follow her voice. Conventional sound 
recording cannot capture those experiences -- but an invention by audio 
engineers at the University of California, Davis is changing that.

  Motion-tracked binaural sound (MTB) captures cues for direction, distance 
and movement and the subtleties of natural, ambient sound that other 
systems don't. Developed by Ralph Algazi, Richard Duda and Dennis Thompson 
at the Interface Laboratory in the UC Davis Center for Image Processing and 
Integrated Computing (CIPIC), the patent-pending technique uses 
off-the-shelf equipment that won't break the bank.

For the listener, it's an eerie experience of listening to invisible people 
talking, playing music or singing around you while you can turn your 
attention from one to another.

  "Conventional audio playback doesn't reflect how you hear in real life," 
Algazi said. "Your body, the shape of your head and the room acoustics all 
affect how you hear."

  Conventional binaural recording uses microphones embedded in a dummy head 
to record sound, so that playback through headphones mimics the recording. 
That method does a fair job of reproducing sounds to the left and right but 
not to the front, where sounds appear to come from immediately in front of 
or behind your head. Furthermore, it doesn't allow for movement, Duda said.

  "The problem is that people do not keep still," Duda said.

  The new method records through multiple microphones (eight for voice, 16 
for music) spaced around a head-sized ball or cylinder. The sound is played 
back through headphones with a small tracking device attached to the top to 
follow head movements. As you turn your head while listening, the system 
mixes sound from different microphones, reproducing what you would hear if 
you were in the room.

  Listeners can move their heads to locate a sound source, turn to "face" a 
person speaking and tell when sound sources are nearby or far away. In 
addition, MTB captures the ambient sounds of the location, so you recognize 
the echoes in a church or the confines of a conference room.

The engineers have made sample recordings with musicians from the UC Davis 
music department and visiting classical and bluegrass musicians.

  "The system can capture the sound of instruments much more fully than a 
conventional single microphone. It captures changes in sound and the 
effects of a room in a way that is much closer to reality," Algazi said.

"I think they have something really wonderful," said Pablo Ortiz, chair of 
the Department of Music at UC Davis.

  "The thing that's interesting to me is the way that it records space," 
Ortiz said.

  William Beck, a composer of electronic music and lecturer in the music 
department, said that live recordings could be a major application.

  "The 'being there' feel is something people would really like," Beck said.

  The technique could also be used for teleconferencing, computer games and 
virtual- or augmented-reality systems. The work, which is supported by 
grants from the National Science Foundation, was presented at the 116th 
Convention of the Audio Engineering Society held in May 2004 in Berlin, 
Germany.

  The CIPIC Interface Laboratory is a multidisciplinary research center 
that studies human perception and its role in the interface between humans 
and machines.

http://www.news.ucdavis.edu/search/news_detail.lasso?id=7058



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.org

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm


"I see in the near future a crisis approaching that unnerves me and causes 
me to tremble for the safety of my country.  As a result of the war, 
corporations have been enthroned and an era of corruption in high places 
will follow, and the money power of the country will endeavor to prolong 
its reign by working upon the prejudices of the people until all wealth is 
aggregated in a few hands and the Republic is destroyed."
-Abraham Lincoln

"Music is prophecy, its style and economic organization are ahead of the 
rest of society. It makes audible the new world that will gradually become 
visible."
-Jacques Attali in his seminal text "Noise"

  "I loved the focus in the early days of Wicked on the pagan aspects of 
life. The natural cycles of the full moons, being out in nature, on the 
beach, free, alive, unbridled, wild and spontaneous. There is no club, 
party or other sound system that has ever achieved anything close to that..."
-Jeno, on the early days of Wicked and the Full Moon Raves

Subject: RE: [sfraves] delta 9 changed my life

hahahahah this is a solid story. I'll never forget the first time I saw him, 
Invasion 2 in 1997 in SoCal at the San Bernardino Sports Arena. Absolute 
mind blowing set, I always said if I ever threw parties, I'd have him come 
play.. and low and behold, I'm having him come play.

Anyone who likes it rough and rugged, make sure to come out and see D9 rock 
it on September 4th!



andy
tronic

>delta 9 poisoned me when i saw him play in L.A. (orange show complex) 
>(1996)
>
>i was horrified by his intense evil nature.
>
>it was 6am.  i was coming down and looking fwd to some morning house.
>
>he deprived me of such a comfort and proceeded to split my skull / psyche
>/ personality until i felt like i might do things that were terribly
>wrong.
>
>i wanted the onslaught to stop, but that just made him pound me more.
>
>i had know idea that such music existed before that.
>
>if techno is the music of the devil, delta 9 must be the devil's own
>torture dementia master.
>
>Jonas
